Abstract of ref. 1534:
Phosphorite grains were authigenically precipitated within
precursor marl and biosiliceous deposits during high water level and
intense upwelling within the Tethys Ocean to the north of Jordan. With
falling sea level, the oyster Lopha villei colonized bathymetric highs in the shallow shelfal environments in east-central Jordan during the uppermost Campanian--Lower Maastrichtian (Late Cretaceous). The oyster bioherms in the epeiric southern shelf of the Tethys formed small basins several hundreds of meters across and about 40--50 m deep. Under these lowstand conditions, oyster shells were shed off the bioherms and deposited as large cross-bedded units on the flanks of the basins. At the same time, precursor phosphatic sediments were reworked and winnowed to form high-grade phosphorite sand. More than 250 million metric tons (250 x 109 kilograms) of phosphorite sand were deposited basinward of the oyster beds. As sea level continued to fall, the oyster bioherms formed partially silled basins with low biological diversity in which marl and/or bituminous marl was deposited. The marls are overlain by the transgressive phosphatic marl and chalk of the Muwaggar Formation, which were deposited under open marine conditions.

name: E Canning Basin
remarks:

Abstract ref. 1551:
Miospores from boreholes through the earliest sediments associated with the onset of the formation of reef complexes on the Lennard Shelf of northern Western Australia include representatives of the Geminospora lemurata-Cymbosporites magnificus and Contagisporites optivus-Cristatisporites triangulatus Assemblage Zones. The palynofloral evidence indicates that deposition of the reef sequence began in the mid-Givetian, rather than latest Givetian as previously thought. Palynomorphs become sparser with increase in carbonate content and consequently middle Frasnian to Famemmian palynomorph zones cannot be distinguished in the reef complexes.

name: Molong High, New South Wales

name: Fombuena
remarks:
Largest mounds 1.8 m thick, 6 m wide. Complexes up to 5 m thick.
Baffling most important, second is biocementstone.

Three stages of community development: Stabilization, colonization, diversification, but no domination.

Abstract of ref. 1560:
Mud-mound complexes identified within the early to middle Ashgill Cystoid Limestone Formation of northeastern Spain are the first fossil build-ups to be described in the high latitude north-facing margin of Gondwana. Mud-mound complexes comprise individual lenticular mounds (composed of floatstones, cephalopod-rich mudstones and cementstones), flanks and intermound deposits (including pelmatozoan packstones and floatstones). The small mounds are mainly composed of bryozoans, cystoids and crinoids, and were developed on outer ramp environments. Mound initiation depended upon the stabilization and colonization of densely packed lenses of pelmatozoan-rich sediments. In a mid-ramp setting, pelmatozoan-bryozoan meadows were episodically degraded by common wave- and storm-induced processes, the
development of semi-consolidated substrates, and the periodic influx of terrigenous material. Finally, during the Hirnantian regression, the Iberian mixed (carbonate-siliciclastic) platform was exposed to subaerial conditions sufficiently for erosion and karstification to occur.
From a palaeogeographical point of view, the pattern of the Ashgill Iberian platform deposition is characterized by episodic exclusion of carbonates from most nearshore environments by a shoreline source of siliciclastic sediments. A similar interpretation to that made on the Iberian Cystoid Limestone Formation, in terms of gradual proximality-distality changes, is proposed for comparable facies types in Ashgill limestones described in southwestern Europe.

name: Manzanares, Huancayo
remarks:
7 m thick sponge-coral bank.
Stylothalamia and three coral species (two solitary: Stylophyllopsis spp., one colonial Hispaniastraea).
Two additional species probably present.
No calcareous algae, some serpulids.

Abundant sponge spicules, radiolarians and ammonites in matrix.

Some Stromatactis.

name: Sierra Gorda, Puente Genil, Cordoba

name: Bulleys Lump, Judge Daly Promot., Nunavut
remarks:
Member A
Outer Shelf edge buildup.
Together with upper Member B about 1.5 km syndepositional relief.
Fenestral pelmicrite and fenestral pelsparite predominate. Calcimicrobes associated: Halysis, cf. Hedstroemia, Epiphyton, Renalcis, Girvanella. 
Up to 30 % early marine cement.

Abstract of ref. 1574:
Four Lower Ordovician buildup categories occur in carbonate platform strata in the Canadian Arctic Islands: outer and inner shelf-margin buildups and outer and inner shelf-interior buildups. The outer shelf-margin buildup in the Bulleys Lump Formation consists mainly of calcirnicrobial biolithite and early marine cement, forming a structure that probably had a depositional relief of more than 1.5 km over contiguous basinal chert and mudrock. The length of the outer shelf-margin buildup is probably more than 1400 km, although it is discontinuously exposed. Inner shelf-margin buildups are smaller, mounded structures, attaining thicknesses in excess of 100 m and widths of several kilometres. A representative inner shelf-margin buildup comprises four distinct microbial facies; the stratigraphically lowest and deepest water facies contains up to 4 m-thick thrombolite mounds surrounded by Conophyton-like stromatolitic pinnacles. The two middle facies consist of numerous, aligned ovoidal thrombolites with thromboidal or columnar stromatolitic interiors and stromatolitic margins. Thrombolites were built mainly by benthic microbial communities, but fleshy and locally well-sclerotized sponges were probably important constructors as well. These thrombolites are overlain by the shallowest water and youngest buildup facies, consisting of cerebroform stromatolites and thrombolites, but which lack the distinctive ovoidal thrombolites of the underlying facies. Zoned inner shelf-margin microbial buildups such as these are previously undocumented. Shelf-interior buildups are composed of thrombolites and stromatolites, forming isolated, I to 5 m-high mounds and coalesced mounds in buildups more than 2.0 km wide. The distribution of the four buildup categories implies a shelf-margin embayment in the central part of the Arctic Islands.

name: Cliefden Caves, N.S.W.
remarks:
Kalimna Limestone Member of Fossil Hill Limestone.
1.2 m thick sheet-like biostrome.
Large (60x30 cm) Tetradium cribiforme colonies (Tabulate). 3 % of biovolume composed of Nycropora (T) and Cystistroma (S). 1.5 % composed of Bajgolia (T), Hillophyllum (R) and encrusting Dualites (T).
1 % are bryzoans.
Collection of Miller

Abstract ref. 1597:
The Cliefden Caves area of central New South Wales has a well preserved Late Ordovician sedimentary succession that formed in an offshore, near-equatorial, volcanic island setting. Initially fringing deposits (the Fossil Hill Limestone) accumulated, with occurrences of corals such as Tetradium cribriforme, Nyctopora, Bajgolia, Dualites, Hillophyllum, and stromatoporoids like Cystistroma, Rosenella and Stratodictyon. These were particularly characteristic of the shoal-type, mid-shelf T. cribriforme biofacies, and were contributors to a number of bioherms and biostromes. The succeeding, massive Belubula Limestone accumulated mainly in shallow lagoonal phases of the planated island with only sparse heliolitine corals, Aulopora, Bajgolia?, the stromatoporoids Cystostroma and Alleynodictyon? and the sphinctozoan sponge Belubulaia. The overlying deeper platform carbonates of the Vandon Limestone have a more diverse fauna with T. cribriforme, numerous heliolitines, Palaeophyllum, the sphinctozoan Cliefdenella, and stromatoporoids (Ecclimadictyon, Clathrodictyon), but no indubitable 'reefs'. Deep water assemblages of the overlying Malongulli Formation include reworked and in situ siliceous sponge associations. Limestone breccias include: (1) clasts with corals (Favistina and favositids) and rare silicified sphinctozoans, presumed to be derived from the adjacent shallow platform; and (2) clasts eroded from the slopes, with a diverse assemblage of demosponges, hexactinellids and discrete spicules. The in situ Malongulli assemblage occupied a lower slope/basin position, and includes undescribed hexactinellids and abundant spicules. A striking onshore-offshore faunal differentiation exists, with (1) the corals and stromatoporoids, most diversified and abundant in the mid-shelf island settings above wave base, (2) the sphinctozoans, rare constituents of lagoonal to subtidal 'level bottom' carbonate platform habitats, (3) the demosponges, most common and diversified in the upper slope, and (4) the hexactinellids, well represented in both upper and lower slope /basin habitats.

name: Boonderoo, N.S.W.
remarks:
Dunhill Bluff Limestone Member of Fossil Hill Limestone.
2.6 m thick coral/stromatoporoid biohermal mass.
85 % of biovolume formed by Tetradium cribriforme (up to 40x30 cm diameter) at base. Takeover by stromatoporoids up section reaching 50 % of biovolume at top.
Other corals: Nycropora, Bajgolia, encrusting Dualites, cerioid Eofletcheria, solitary Hillophyllum.
Stromatoporoids: Cystistroma, Labechia, Stratodictyon, Rosenella.
Skeletal wackestone matrix, although sediments above and below are grainstones.
Additional mound occur in Taplow limestone member, Transmission limestone member.

name: Serratosa, Vic, Ebro Basin

Bryozoan mud mounds. 
Predominantly small sized vinculariiform colonies or hollow cylindrical colonies (Metrarabdotos), overturend but not transported.

name: Upper Keg River, NE British Columbia
remarks:
Pinnacle reefs seaward of Presqu'ile Barrier.
Varaibly dolomitized.

Rugose corals represent by small branching forms (particaularly Dendrostella trigemme) enlosed in stromatop.

Abstract of ref. 1600:
Rugose corals of mid-late Eifelian age are diverse and relatively abundant in widespread open shelf carbonates of Northeastern British Columbia (lower Keg River and Dunedin formations) and District of Mackenzie (Lonely Bay, Nahanni, Headless and Hume formations). The overlying Givetian carbonate complex of northeastern British Columbia and southern District of Mackenzie (Presqu'ile Barrier) has only sparsely developed rugosans, but beds flanking the barrier (upper Dunedin, Pine Point, Sulphur Point formations) locally develop more diverse faunas of early-mid Givetian age. Downslope from the barrier complex, numerous early-mid Givetian pinnacle reefs (upper Keg River, Hom Plateau formations) bear particularly diverse and abundant rugose coral assemblages. In the lower Mackenzie River valley of northern District of Mackenzie a series of reefal complexes of mid-late Givetian age (Ramparts Formation) carries significant rugosan faunas, especially in platform and flanking beds.

name: Horn Plateau, NWT
remarks:
One of 13 drilled subsurface reefs from Horn Plateau.
Dominated by large bulbous and tabulate stromatoporoids and scarce branching rugosans.

name: Gipsdalen, Pyefjellet, Spitzbergen
remarks:
Phylloid algal buildups and banks.
Some rugose corals.

name: Seewarte, Carnic Alps
remarks:
Diverse brachiopods associated.

Abstract ref. 1606.
In the following 31 brachiopod genera and 56 species from the Heller Crinoidenschutt- und Riffkalk of the Seewarte
    Mt. are described. They belong to the superfamilies Pentameracea, Rhynchonellacea, Atrypacea, Retziacea,
    Athyridacea, Cyrtiacea, Spiriferacea, Crytinacea and Reticulariacea. Pugnax ? scupini is erected as a new species.
    Uncinulus sp., Parapugnax sp., Stenorhynchia aff. nympha, Atrypa (Planatrypa) n. sp., Carinatina n. sp., Rhynchatrypa
    aff. thetis and Striispirifer sp. are listed under open nomenclature because they require a future more complete
    investigation based on additional material. The brachiopod-fauna of the Carnic Alps is closely related to that of the Barandian area. This relation becomes most obvious when compared to the brachiopod community of the Pragian Koneprusy Limestones of Central Bohemia. Furthermore the connections to Lower Devonian brachiopod assemblages of the Ural, Altai and Salair (USSR) can be demonstrated. The faunas of the Armorican Massiv (Limestones of Erbray, Trench of La Lezais), Marokko (Limestones of the Tafilalt) and the Harz Mts. (Princeps-Limestone) are also comparable to that of the Carnic Alps.

Reef-mounds with lithistid sponges, receptaculids (Calathium) and microbialite. Girvanella dominant 20-30 % (up to 70 %) of mound volume.
4 sponge species are common.

name: Onoura, Amakusa-Shimo-shima
remarks:
Oyster reef

Abstract of ref. 1610:
The Member U-III a of the Upper Himenoura Subgroup distributed in Kumamoto and Kagoshima Prefectures is composed mainly of cross-bedded sandstone, which yields two oyster beds. Autochthonous oyster reefs can be observed at two outcrops exposed at Onoura in Amakusa-Shimojima and Hirasezaki in Shimokoshikijima (Fig.1). These oysters are 'mudstickers' (Seilacher et al., 1985), and are assigned to one of the Crosssostrea species. They are divided into two distinct morphotypes, namely, a stocky form (Onoura type; about 30 cm in shell height) and a stick-like elongated form (Hirasezaki type; less than 100 cm in height). The Onoura type seems to adopt 'relay-strategy', and one clump usually consists of three or four generations. On the other hand, the Hirasezaki type resembles morphologically solitary mudstickers such as Konbostrea. However, this Hirasezaki type also make the clump composed of three or four generations. The Hirasezaki type may, therefore, adopt not only 'elongated-strategy' but also 'relay-strategy'. This is an intermediate mode of life between Crassotrea and Konbostrea. Sedimentological analysis suggests that the Cretaceous strata exposed at Onoura represent more nearshore facies than those at Hirasezaki. The Onoura type might be adapted to nearshore, lagoonal environments, while the Hirasezaki type might be an adaptive form to offshore bar in open marine environments. Cretaceous gigantic oyster beds are confined to three stages in Japan: middle Cenomanian, upper Turonian to lowest Santonian, and upper Campanian.

name: Hirasezaki, Shimo-koshiki-shima

remarks:
Bryozoan biolithite rare stromatactis micrite.
Total reef mass almost 100 m thick.
Lithification by binding activity on encrusting bryozoans.

Monotrypa and Mesotrypa subdominant.
18 genera in reef core, 18 in reef flank (4 missing, 4 additional).
Flank beds important (75 % of reef mass), but containing mostly pelmatozoan debris and virtually no enrusters.

name: Los Navalucillos-Pena Hueca, Toledo
remarks:
Abstract ref. 1614:
We have studied the carbonates with Archaeocyatha in the outcrop of Los Navalucillos-Pena Hueca (Montes de Toledo occidentales), that belong to Los Navalucillos Limestone. These organic carbonates are, for the most part, of algae activity, and to a smaller extent to that of other organisms. Archaeocyatha and Trilobites. On the whole it is a trans-reef area with small mounds of algae and archaeocyatha, and levels with cups and organic debris accumulations. We described the species: Rotundocyathus salebrosus (Vologdin, 1931); Sibirecyathus disepimentalis Vologdin, 1940b; Afiacyathus alloiteaui Debrenne, 1964; Rasetticyathus iglesiensis DebrenneE, 1971; Inessocyathus spatiosus (Bornemann, 1887); Protopharetra polymorpha Bornemann, 1887; Pycnoidocyathus toledani Perejon, 1976, and Anthomorpha sisovae (Vologdin, 1940a); this association is characteristic of the Upper Ovetiense.

name: Lander Co., Nevada
remarks:
Nevadella zone.
One meter thick and 200 m long Spygoria biostromes (problematic organism, probably metazoan).
Short lived experiment in metazoan reefs according to ref. 1616
Probably aragonite

name: Cheyne Point, Griffith Is., Nunavut
remarks:
Abundant heliotids in mud mound flanking beds.
Collection of Alroy with only 2 coral species indicated.

Abstract of ref. 1617:
Heliolitine corals occur in Upper Silurian strata of the topmost Douro, lower Barlow Inlet, and lower Somerset Island formations in the Boothia Uplift region. The fauna includes Heliolites (nine species), Propora (two species), the stelliporellid genera Ponollites (three species) and Stelliporella (one species), and the plasmoporid Squameolites (one species). Species present but not previously reported from the region include Heliolites arcuatus Bondarenko, Heliolites uksunayensis Mironova, Stelliporella ilensis Bondarenko, Podollites assitus new species, Podollites parryi new species, Podollites plectilis new species, Propora tubulata (Lonsdale) and an unidentified species of Propora. All species occur in reef and reef-associated facies of open carbonate shelf and ramp settings. In restricted nonreefal carbonate shelf settings, diversity attenuates to a minimum, exemplified by numerically abundant monospecific assemblages of Heliolites uksunayensis. Six of the 16 morphotaxonomic units recognized compare with species reported previously in Silurian faunas of Kazakhstan and Mongolia. Combinations of characters in the species attributed to Podollites support revision of the genus, possibly to include Derivatolites and Tarbagatailites, in a group morphologically intermediate between Stelliporella and Heliolites.

name: Trinidad
remarks:
Sr age: 11.2-15 Ma
50 coral species recorded in total.
Contrasting earlier statements diversity and fanal tunover rates high in the middle Miocene.

Ref. 1902 recorded only 5 genera and 8 species of corals.

Abstract of ref. 1862:
Caribbean coral reefs were widespread, well developed, and highly diverse during the Late Oligocene. In contrast, the Early Miocene was marked by decline in both reef building and reef-coral diversity. Increasing planktonic productivity has been implicated in this regional collapse of the coral reef ecosystem. Reduction of extensive reef development makes it difficult to find early Neogene corals to sample, but the abundant and well preserved corals from the Tamana Fm. of Trinidad are one exception. The goal of this study was to more fully document this important fauna and better constrain the timing and effects of the Oligocene/Miocene biotic transition. Large new collections from the Tamana Fm. indicate that extinction was nearly complete and that recovery of coral species diversity was well under way by the beginning of the Middle Miocene. A total of 33 species were recovered from the Tamana Fm. Thirteen of these species are first occurrences (40 percent), but only four are last occurrences (12 percent). Three of the four last occurrences have only been recognized from the Tamana Fm., and may represent taxonomic uncertainty. The first occurrences include taxa destined to be major constituents of Miocene and Pliocene coral communities, including several species of Montastraea, Caulastraea portoricensis, Agaricia undata, and Siderastrea siderea. In spite of this increasing diversity, significant reef tract development did not return to the Caribbean until after a major episode of extinction during Plio/Pleistocene time. This second extinction decimated the diverse Late Pliocene fauna, and is associated with oceanographic changes caused by the emergence of the Isthmus of Panama and intensification of northern hemisphere glaciation. Therefore the Oligocene/Miocene transition was characterized by a decline in both reef building and reef-coral diversity but the Plio/Pleistocene transition was associated with decreasing diversity and increasing reef development. Both reef coral diversity and reef-tract development are strongly influenced by oceanographic conditions, but their responses are not in phase.

name: Fourth Chute, Ottawa Valley, Ontario
remarks:
Small (1 m long, 15 cm thick mounds) composed of strophomenid brachiopods and/or bryozoans.
Anoxic conditions prevail in surrounding carbonate sediments.

name: Maumee, Ohio
remarks:
Lockport dolomite.
Microbialite-coral reef.
Only microbes and small Favosites.
Favosites showing evidence of stress (stress bands, small size).
High sedimentation rates indicated by growth form and in situ preservation. 
Nutrient-rich setting.

name: Rambla Quebrada, Almeria
remarks:
Coral banks on debris flow conglomerates. 
Banks of ahermatypic zooxanthellate Cladocora caespitosa. Oysters cemented on corals.
Guild overlap (constuctor and baffler).
Most reef builders in situ.
Macroborings rare, no evidence for microborings.

Abstract of ref. 1628:
Cladocora caespitosa is a common zooxanthellate, ahermatypic, constructional scleractinian coral in shallow waters of the present-day Mediterranean. Extensive coral banks in Upper Pliocene shallow marine deposits of the Almería-Níjar Basin (SE Spain) contain the same species. These banks occur on debris-flow conglomerates deposited in a fan delta, or on bioclastic accumulations interpreted as storm deposits. Direct relationships of coral beds with coastal facies indicate that C. caespitosa colonized shallow settings near the paleocoast, probably not deeper than 20-30 m. Low turbulence allowed corals to colonize substrates, which remained stable for long periods. Activity of organisms in the coral community, storms, and detritic discharges from the fan delta were the most significant mechanisms disturbing the coral development. The hard substrata provided by coral banks promoted colonization by cemented and epibyssate organisms. Coral banks marked maximum flooding surfaces at the end of transgressive systems tracks. They were suddenly buried by sediment input into the basin. Taphonomic signatures measured on components of the coral bank communities indicate a low turbulence environment, probably a bay. The low hydraulic energy further inhibited post-burial reworking, thus promoting the in situ preservation of a great part of the organisms inhabiting the bioconstructions.

name: Lawrence Co., Indiana
remarks:
Echinoderms and fenestrate bryozoans as main constituents. Common only at basal lense core.
85 % micrite in central lense core.
Lenses developed at or above fair-weather wave base on a relatively shallow carbonate platform.

name: Belaya River, Urals
remarks:
Mid ramp position.
m-scale patch reefs. Smaller biostromes.
Reef debris slightly micritized.
Boundstones with corals, bryozoans, pseudo-algae, Syringopora.
Framestone with corals and bryozoans, framestone with Syringopora and pseudo-algae, bindstone and bafflestone with pseudo-algae and bryozoans.
Biohermal bafflestones also present.

name: Askyn. Urals
remarks: Micrite-rich bioherms with pseudo-algae and bryozoans, well below wave base,

Originally assigned to the Famennian, but dating from fissure fills. Reef is Frasnian (Joachimski, pers. comm. 2000).

Ref. 1635:
Vilémovice Limestone
Upper part of Palmatolepis crepida zone.
Reefoid limestone as continuation of Frasnian reef.
Stromatoporoids and tabulate corals
Stromatop. similar to Frasnian
Some change in tabulates.
Rugose corals with pronounced changes.

name: Pillara Range, Canning Basin
remarks:
Type section of Pillara Fm.
Repeated cycles of 
3) cryptalgal limestone
2) stromatoporoid biostrome (up to 10 m thick): a) tabular-stromatoporoids, b) subspherical stromatoporoids, c) Stachyodes limestone

name: Elmis Reef, Aubenas, Ardeche
remarks:
The oldest known Jurassic coral reef is exposed in the Arde`che region of southern France. This reef site, consisting of at least three reefal bodies, is
of early Hettangian age and thus immediately postdates the end-Triassic mass extinction, which is well known for its catastrophic effect on reef

name: Badila
remarks:
Abstract ref. 1646:
Analysis of the Badila exotic limestone blocks (Upper Jurassic) showed different microfacies: reefal, coral, algal, reef-slope, lagoonal pelagic, oolitic and basin. Bioclasts and intraclasts can be found reworked in the younger rocks (Miocene). The large limestone blocks are the only evidence in the Outer Carpathian Zone of a reefal barrier in the Upper Jurassic.

name: Sortan-Manai, Betpak-Dala, Kazachstan
remarks:
Microbial mudmound reef tract with dasyclad green algae.
Island arc carbonate sequence.
Mound core lense-like bodies of massive micritic limestone with numerous remains of dasyclad algae. No stromatactis. Flank beds with nodular algal limestone and some tabulate corals

From Copper
a late Caradoc, possibly  also (?) Ashgill microbial mudmound reef tract from the Anderken Fm., with dasyclad green algae, is described (Nikitin, 1973; Nikitin et al., 1974; Nikitin et al, 1996). One reef is c.150m thick and about1500m across. Such reefs have physical similarities with those of the Boda Limestone of Sweden. The age of some of these mounds is not firmly established for some of the Caradoc mounds may be partly of Ashgill age. The Betpak-Dala locality  is the central part of the arcuate Ordovician reef tract, with a southern extension for 600km to southern Kazakhstan,  at the northern Tyan Shan range (Chon-Kemi River, N of Issuk-Kul Lake, near Alma-Ata). The other half reaches north to Stepnyak in northern Kazakhstan, W of the Irtysh River: total length of this island arc carbonate sequence is over 1500km (Zadoroshnaya & Nikitin, 1990)

name: Dongzhuang, Liquan, Shaanxi
remarks:
Late Caradoc early Ashgill algal reef mounds.

11 identified reef building genera

Also Webby, pers. comm.:
The 80-m thick reef-bearing interval at Dongzhuang comprises six superposed reefs, the lower, a  large, 30 m-high, wedge-shaped shelf-edge reef, bounded top and bottom by massively bedded, calcarenitic, bank-type deposits, and dominated by 'algal' constituents (Solenopora, Palaeoporella, Ajakmalajsoria), and cyanophytes (Hedstroemia, Girvanella) that contributed mainly a bafflestone facies. Basin-facing, outer flanks of this reef show wedge-shaped talus, up to 30 m thick, with clasts up to 80 mm across.  

The rest of the reefal series comprises back-stepping, partially stacked, patch reefs, dominantly of coral, stromatoporoid and stromatolitic contributors. They have an overall thickness of 40 m and a width of more than 100 m. Corals include rugosan Favistina, and tabulates Paleofavosites, Syringoporella and Halysites. The stromatoporoids are Ecclimadictyon and Clathrodictyon, characteristically sheet-like to more massive. The flanking bioclastic limestones include clasts with pelmatozoan debris, brachiopod fragments, gastropods, bryozoans and 'algae'. All these reefs, except the first which is small (2 m high) and stromatolitic, include corals and stromatoporoids, and they are 3 to 4 m high, with flanking (and enveloping) rudstones. The series appears to represent a shelf-edge complex with back-stepping, asymmetrical form, between a thick rudstone blanket on-shelf, and a narrow rudstone halo to the deeper transgressing shales of slope and basin.

name: Gor Uein Terguet, Tindouf Basin, Western Sahara
remarks:

Top
coral-stromatopora biostrome	
Stromatoporoid bindstone
Tabulate (platy and stick) and rugose coral framestone
Stromatoporoid bindstone
Base

From Copper:
A spectacular Middle and late Givetian coral- stromatoporoid patch reef belt, paralleling the Precambrian basement some 50-100km to the south, is known to extend for c. 300km in the Tindouf basin of northern Saharawi Arab Democratic Republic (='Spanish Sahara': Hazzard,1961; Dumestre & Illing,1967), These tabular to mounded reefs were up to c. 2km across, and tens of meters thick, capped by a rich shallow water coral and stromatoporoid fauna, in the region from Uein Terguet to Gor Loutad. 
Stromatactis mudmounds with auloporids and thamnoporids, like those of the Kess-Kess of the Tafilalt, are also known at Uein Terguet, where they appear to initiate reef growth in the 'first cycle' (Dumestre & Illing, 1967).

name: Dongling, Qingshuiyan, Xiushui, Jiangxi
remarks:
sphinctozoans most significant (60 % of framework).
Amblysiphonella, Intrasporecoelia, Tebagathalamia, Rhabdactinia and smaller Sollasia, Guadalupia, Cystothalamia, Colospongia, Sinocoelia.
Inozoans 10 % of framework. Peronidella, Intratubospongia, Radicanalospongia, Stellispongia, Corynella, Grossotubenella, Cavusonella.
Two types of chaetetids.
Palaeoaplysina (!) abundant.
Archaeolithoporella
Tubiphytes.
Baffle- and Framestones.

Comments from Tian & Wang, 2021:
Reef builders: Frame-building and baffling organisms: hypercalcified sphinctozoan and inozoan sponges, sclerosponges, bryozoans, hydrozoans, and Waagenophyllum
Binding organisms: Archaeolithoporella, Tubiphytes, and cyanobacteria.

Reef dwellers:Echinoderms, gastropods, bivalves, brachiopods, gastropods, benthic foraminifera, calcareous algae, and single rugose corals.

Rock type and reef-related depositional characteristic:Reef core: sponge framestone and bafflestone, Archaeolithoporella and cyanobacteria bindstone, and sponge framestone with the encrusting Archaeolithoporella
Reef flat (reef crest): packstone with reef breccia
Reef base: crinoidal packstone to grainstone
Back-reef: bioclastic packstone with calcareous algae, gastropods, and foraminifers.

Reef type: Metazoan reef at the shallow carbonate platform margin.

Coorinates stated in text.

name: Putilovo quarry, St. Petersburg
remarks: Mud mounds, described from the Volkhovian (earliest Middle Ordovician), east of St Petersburg (Dronov and Federov 1994), are 4 to 5 m high, 30 to 50 m across, dome-shaped, and with a mud core and micritic crust facies; no reported calcimicrobes. A Trypanites-bored discontinuity surface separates the micritic crust from flanking pelmatozoan bioclastic limestones. Pelmatozoans are thought by Dronov and Federov to have grown on the atoll-like micritic rim, as baffles to the inner lagoonal mud core. Palaeomagnetic drift paths (Torsvik et al 1992) suggest the mud mounds grew in cooler temperate shallow seas.

name: Malyi Karatau, Kazachstan
remarks:
Latest Cambrian-earliest Ordovician Epiphyton-bearing buildups, up to 20 m high, occur on ocean-facing margins of a seamount in Maly Karatau, Kazakhstan, with smaller mounds scattered in the seamount interior (Cook et al 1991).
Thin section with Girvanella, clotted micrite and Epiphyton shown by ref. 1960

name: Ullerntangen, Ringerike
remarks:
Middle Hirnantian
At Ullerntangen the bioclastic limestone sequence with its small mud  mounds is overlain by a very much larger, lens-shaped buildup, at least 350 m in length, 100 m in width, and up to 12 m in thickness.  It was originally interpreted as a reef by Kiaer (1897) but Hanken (1974) has argued that it lacks an organic framework, being largely composed of reworked material.
Nevertheless a remarkably diverse biota is recorded from this structure, including the stromatoporoid Pachystylostroma, rugoans Palaeophyllum,
Cyathophylloides, Tryplasma, tabulatans Saffordophyllum,  Rhabdotetradium, Lyopora, Reuschia, Catenipora, Proheliolites and Plasmpora as well as exhibiting pockets with clusters of cystoids and trimerellid brachiopod specimens.  The comparatively random directions of orientation of many of the coral and stromatoporoid specimens on the present exposed, slightly inclined, surface are not by themselves a certain basis for claiming that these organisms, or a substantial number of them, were not part of an in situ framework. Almost half the muddy matrix is composed of skeletal bioclasts - predominantly representatives of pelmatozoans, brachiopods, bryozoans, algae (Vermiporella, Hedstroemia) and the cyanobacterieum Girvanella.  The upper surface of the mound is cut by deep fissures up to 6 m deep, that imply a period of significant erosion possibly under subaerial conditions, and then they were infilled by sandy pelmatozoan-dominated bioclastic limestone in a subsequent depositional phase.  Finally a further sandstone unit overlaps the mound on its northern margin, and exhibits a very rich brachiopod, bryozoan and gastropod fauna near the mound.  This unit represents the uppermost part of the unnamed formation, and appears to be bounded at its top by a significant unconformity (hiatus) to the overlying Silurian Saelabonn Formation.

name: Tremp-Pobla de Segur
remarks:
Coral assemblage in olistostrome member of Vallcarga Fm.
36 genera belonging to 2 orders and 9 suborders. Few reef building genera:
E.g.
Actinastraea
Astraraea
Holocoenia
Fungiastaea

Colonial forms predominate but mostly of small size (less than 10 cm).
Large borings evident on plates

name: Libyan Desert
remarks:
Reef building and solitary corals.
Position changed!

name: Hummingbird Creek, Alberta
remarks:
35 m thick and several km long reef complex.
Stromatoporoid reef with interbedded peloidal and skeletal wackestones, and mudstones.
Laminar Labechia palliseri and Clathrostroma cf. jukkense prevail. 
Solenporacean algae rare.

name: Aubenas, Ardèche
remarks:
Cordon grumeleux
Submerged plateau, transitional between Jura shelf and Tethyan basin.
Cryptalgal carbonate bodies. Lime mudstones and wackestones bound by stromatolitic crusts. 
Lenticular bodies 0.5 m thick, 1-3 m wide.

name: Naves, Ardèche
remarks:
See reef 2629.
Small isolated stromatolitic knobs also in lower Kimmeridgian and lower Tithonian. Cryptalgal bodies enriched in radiolarians relative to surrounding deposits.

name: Civetta, Dolomites
remarks:
Sciliar Dolomite and Cassian Dolomite.
17 reef building taxa discussed.
Sphinctozoans, microbial crusts, Tubiphytes, microbroblematica. Few Solenoporaceans.
Corals rare but sometime forming patch reefs.
Primary pores preserved and sometimes widened, mostly destroyed by abundant fibrous marine cement.
Observations from non-dolomitzed slope.

name: Fincastle, Virginia
remarks:
Middle Member of Chepultepec/Stonehenge Fms.
Thrombolitic mounds interbedded with skeletal muds and sands.
Maximum 10 m thick and 50 m wide mounds composed of stacked bioherms. 
Type grainy thrombolites and Girvanella mounds.

name: Hebron, Virginia
remarks:
Middle Member of Chepultepec/Stonehenge Fms.
Thrombolitic mounds. Type muddy bioherms.
Vermiform fabrics by trapping and binding of lime mud by sponges and algal mats. Microspar cavity-fills interpreted as bioeroded sponge-silt. 
Cavities probably formed by bioerosion.

name: Avens Bridge, Virginia
remarks:
Middle Member of Chepultepec/Stonehenge Fms
Small thrombolitic bioherms.
See reef 2632 for further remarks.

name: Goose Arm, Newfoundland
remarks:
Carbonate belt behind platform edge.
Stromatolite and thrombolite mounds occur throughout the section, but do not occupy a specific position in the assemblage.
Epiphyton-cementstone evident from fig. 85 in James (1983).

name: Voskhod and Rodnoye, Chornaya River Basin, Crimea
remarks:
Lower part of boissieri zone of the Berriasian.
Small bioherms (3-5 m thick, 4 m wide) of hermatypic corals and algae. Maximum 6 m thick.
Intermound areas filled with bioclastic grainstones and packstones with fragments of corals and others. 
Framework of massive colonial (massive platy and pacheloid/ramose) corals and Lithocodium. 

Abstract ref. 1764:
A section of Berriasian deposits from the River Belbek area (Southwestern Crimea) containing coral-algal bioherms is described. A detailed lithological and palaeontological description of one of these bioherms is given. Lithological features of Berriasian carbonate rocks are discussed, microfacies analysis of these rocks with there palaeontological remains are carried out. The history of the Berriasian development of the territory will be reconstructed.

name: Ayton Farm, North Yorkshire, England
remarks:
Solenopora-gastropod facies as pre- and inter-reef sediments. 
Reefs as a series of 2m thick isolated structures. 
Coral skeletal volume very high (90%).
Highly micritized carbonate grains, and high bioerosion through bivalves. 
Effectively monospecific buildup dominated by Thamnasteria concinna. 30-40 cm sized colonies.

name: Pandora, Gulf of Papua
remarks: Probably algal mound.

name: Lauron, La Nerthe
remarks:
Calcaire Blanc Supérior
Monopleura clusters

name: Periquillos, Colima
remarks: Recumbent rudist lithosome (Immanitas bed)

name: Portopalo, Pachino, Sicily
remarks:
Massive rudist lithosome with prominent domal shape (4 m high, 5 m wide).
Highly dispersed cylindrical elevator rudists (Hippurites) in an micritic sandy matrix.
Vocanoclastic setting.

Abstract ref. 1770:
Maastrichtian strata from the Pachino area (SE Sicily) provide a model of association between rudist-coral frameworks and submarine volcanic activity. Two successive carbonate units are distinguished: (a) Coral- rudist bioherms and biostromes developed in a high-energy environment. (b) Hippuritid build-ups and banks overlain by rudist-coral clusters which grew under harsher ecological conditions, in a weaker current regime. At the top of the Maastrichtian sequence, the growth of rudist-coral frameworks ceased as ecological conditions shifted toward restricted environments. The inferred succession reflects a gradual decrease in current strengths and water depths, related to the Maastrichtian regression phase. The frameworks display consistent evolutionary sequences reflecting progressive changes in their biota, structure, and size and shape. Occurrences of rudist-coral frameworks are clearly linked with submarine volcanoes which provided opportunities for their development; they sometimes grew in the vicinity of active-vent centers, a feature reported for the first time in the Upper Cretaceous.

name: Koronia, Helicon Mountains
remarks:
Autochthonous reef limestones in ophiolitic conglomerates, sandstones and marls.
Corals, encrusting algae, sponges. Rudists in the back reef.

name: Marmeko, Boeotia
remarks:
Clusters and biostromes of Radiolites souvagesi and Vaccinites inferus above coquina horizon.
Chaetetids associated.

name: Kiriaki
remarks: Vaccinites chaperi and thick-shelled radiolitids.

name: Antikyra
remarks: Clusters of Hippuritella lapeirousei overlain by biomicritic limestones.

name: Moukharemi, Edessa
remarks:
Massive limestone with coral-rudist float- to rudstones.
Strongly bored and enrusted by corallinaceans.
Lapeirouseia identified.

name: Vrbovac, Bacevica, Serbia
remarks: New rudist genus and several new species described.

name: Castelcucco, Veneto
remarks:
Massive or coarsely bedded rhodolithic biostromes overlain by coarse-grained glauconitic biocalcarenites.
Tide- and wave-dominated delta setting. Biostromes developed on offshore bars.
Some bryozoans, serpulids and bivalves associated.
Phosphate indicates plenty of nutrients.

name: Maré, Loyalty Islands, Melanesia
remarks: Dolomitic rhodolite facies (Middle Miocene) with karstic surface.

name: Lifou, Loyalty Islands, Melanesia
remarks: See reef 2650.

name: Rurutu, Polynesia
remarks:
Belongs to France
60 m high cliffs on northwestern side of the island composed of packstone with big fragments of coral grading into wackestone. Doublet repeated every 30-50 cm. 
branched corals replaced by massive coral heads in successive layers.

name: Nauru, Pacific
remarks: Coral facies covered by incresing amounts of coralline algae.

name: Central Ranges, Trinidad
remarks:
12 genera and 14 species of coral described. 
All from 'zoogenic' limestone blocks with worn coral fragments.
Corals, sponges, echinoderms, pelecypods and nerineid gastropods indicated.

name: Tehucacan, Pueblo
remarks: Reef coral fauna

name: El Tigre, Sonora
remarks:
Impoverished continuation of the Glen rose reef trend.
Strong bioerosion evident on plates.

name: Lamy, New Mexico
remarks:
1.5 m thick coral thicket of ahermatypic coral Archohelia dartoni Wells. 
Blue Hill Shale Member
Zonation by different sedimentation rates and accompanied variations in debris production.

Moderately deep cool water coral accumulation.

name: Vanderbeek, Leon Co., Texas
remarks:
Amoco well
Outboard reef trend on distally steepened ramp. 

Two major types of reefs may occur both in an outboard an inboard position during latest Kimmeridgian and earliest Tithonian, resp.
Vanderbeck is an outboard reef, Reef is coral dominated at base but  rich in siliceous sponges and microbial crust at top.

Data refer to cement-rich coral-sponge-microbial boundstones and skeletal pack-/grainstones.
Best reservoir quality in shoal grainstone with reefal debris.

Ideal sequence in area
Top
marine shlae
marl
shallow lagoon
debris flow
coral-calcareous sponge microbiolite reef
reefal debris
debris fan
shallow outer ramp
sponge-thrombolite reef
upper deep marine ramp
coral-calcareous algal reef with washover fan
lagoon.

name: Tazewell, Tennessee
remarks:
Several small thrombolitic bioherms in subtidal package, with flat pebble conglomerates and bioturbation. 
Minor development in overlying intertidal package.

name: Flat Gap, Tennessee
remarks: Digitate stromatolite (dendrolite) bioherm interbedded with thrombolites in intertidal Copper Ridge Dolomite.

name: NE Amadeus Basin, N.W.T.
remarks:
Thrombolitic and stromatolitic bioherms.
Several horizons.

name: South Australia
remarks: Position doubtful

name: Mohawk Valley, New York
remarks:
Abstract ref. 1800:
Tribes Hill domal thrombolites, termed here microbial reef mounds, occupied the basal part of meter-scale shallowing-upward cycles. They are part of a high-energy facies that a sharp, transgressive surface separates from an underlying low-energy peritidal setting. This erosional surface served as the surface on which one of the reef mounds established itself during initial transgression before further deepening. The others overlie a floor of skeletal grainstone reflecting a high-stand sea-level facies tract. Skeletal grainstone composes the fill between the mounds. One channel and several aggrading hummocks occupy inter-reef mound areas resulting from storm events in a subtidal setting.

name: Mt. Medvednica
remarks:
Abstract of ref. 1802:
The biolithitic complex with a barrier reef in NE Mt. Medvednica shows the continuity of sedimentation of the Maestrichtian-Palaeocene. The lower part of the reef, which is built up mainly of rudistids, is of Maestrichtian age. The Palaeocene part of the reef is built up mainly of hermatypic corals and solenoporacean algae. The described biolithitic complex belongs to the sedimentation model characteristic for the subduction zone with an island arc system. The boundary Cretaceous-Tertiary is found everywhere in the Dinarides marked by a significant biostratigraphic discontinuity, and in terms of lithostratigraphy, by a continuity or discontinuity depending on geotectonical events. The facies migration occurred in transgressive succession in direction opposite to the subduction.

name: Vapenkova skala, Rozbehy
remarks:
Abstract of ref. 1803:
The 1st paleontologically confirmed occurrence of Upper Cretaceous sediments in the Little Carpathians was described. A series of strata of carbonate-sandstones through fine grained conglomerates of the Campanian with large Foraminifera of the genera Orbitoides, Pseudosidlerites and Lepidorbitoides was exposed on the southern slope of Vapenkova skala near Rozbehy. Bodies of biohermal reef limestone with corals and Dasycladaceae, probably of the Maastrichtian, were found on the walls of the Campanian strata. The find represents an important connecting link between the Brezova development of the Upper Cretaceous and Senonian sediments found to exist on the floor of the Vienna basin in drillings in the area of Zavod and Studienka. O. tissoti, O. media, P. vidali and L. minima are discussed in detail.

name: Tsagan-Del, Wester
remarks:
Lenses of reef-like limestones with tabulate corals: Cateniopora and diverse heliolitines.
Mongoliolites paradoxides
'Proheliolites' ex gr. koskolensis
Propora ex gr. magna
Halysites proecedens
Diverse brachiopod fauna associated with corals.

name: Kalpin, Tarim Platform, Xinjiang
remarks:
Basal Middle Cambrian 50 km NE of Kalpin
Lower part of Shaylik Fm. consists of biolithite, leopard limestone, wormkalk and breccioid limestone.
Overlain by thin-bedded chert-stripped limestone.
Outer neritic platform setting in high energy environment.

name: Missouri
remarks:
Domal stromatolites associated with grainstones.
Collections of Patzkowsky refer to interreef fauna.

name: Aqra
remarks:
Rudists, forams and algae as main reef builders.
Some corals.

name: Mesaoria Plain
remarks:
40 m water depth inferred. 
Dominated by ramose Cladocora, but diverse molluscan fauna 38 species in total. Reef builders Cladocora, Ostrea and serpulids
9 m thick, 50 m wide.
Base with Ostrea domination.

Reef resting on calcareous silts, sandstones and conglomerates.

Similar structure as Tortonian reefs.

Abstract of Ref. 1821:
Paleocological analysis of the reef community shows that, apart from corals, it was dominated by epifaunal molluscs. It represents one of the most diverse fossil communities found on Cyprus following the Messinian Salinity Crisis (MSC), with 38 identified species of macrofossils and 8 species of foraminifera. When compared to patch reefs on Cyprus formed just prior to the MSG, this Pliocene reef shows both the biological devastation of the event and the quick and complete recovery of the reefal biodiversity.

name: Osmundsberget, Dalarne
remarks:
Up to 30 m thick bioherms of Palaeoporella variabilis (Codiacean, Chlorophyta) and abundant sparite. 
Micritization noted. Open porosity.
Growth ceased before end of Hirnantian.

name: Rosseveltveg, Curacao, Netherland Antilles
remarks:
Two units:
Top: Acropora palmata dominant
Base: Stylophora affinis dominant
Maximum 11 coral species at one locality.

name: Salina, Curacao, Netherland Antilles
remarks:
10 coral species listed:
Montastrea limbata most abundant

name: Gurabo Adentro
remarks:
Up to 14 species indicated from one reef body.
Porites, Monastrea and Stylophora prevailing.
38 coral genera (71 species) in total according to ref. 1902.
19 m thick fringing reefs near edge of gently sloping shelf.

name: Brazo Seco
remarks:
8 dominant coral species indicated. 
Placocyathus prevailing.

name: Bowden
remarks:
Deep reef (> 20 m) environment.
9 coral species indicated
Placocyathus alveolus strongly predominant.

name: Cerro de Oro, Sonora
remarks:
late Barremian-early Aptian
Uppermost Cerro de Oro Fm.
Described as reef-like biohermal structures up to 10 m thick and up to 100 m long.
Coral boundstones with bivalves and forams.
21 Coral species described.

name: Cerro de Oro, Sonora
remarks:
Late Aptian to middle Albian.
Biohermal structures of colonial corals, stromatoporoids, rudists and other bivalves and abundant formas. 
Up to 10 m high and 700 m long.
Corals and stromatoporoids in growth position.
20 corals described. 1 added for stromatoporoids

name: Lampazos, Sonora
remarks:
Bisbee Group
Thick massive biohermal limestones mentioned at base and top of Espinazo del Diablo Fm.
12 Coral species described.
Age assignment corrected by ref. 2005, abstract:
The stratigraphy and structure of the Lower Cretaceous (Aptian-Albian) rocks exposed in the area of Lampazos, Sonora, are redefined and correlated to well-known stratigraphic successions of Chihuahua and northeast Mexico (Coahuila and Nuevo Leon). Originally, seven stratigraphic units were proposed for the Cretaceous rocks exposed in the Lampazos area, but in this article only five units (El Aliso, Agua Salada, Lampazos, Espinazo del Diablo, and Los Picachos formations) have been used, and we propose herein to discontinue usage of the other two (Nogal and La Mesa formations). This Aptian-Albian succession of east-central Sonora yields facies and fossil content remarkably similar to coeval sequences in the Gulf of Mexico realm (Chihuahua, Coahuila, and Nuevo Leon). These sections contain abundant microfossils (benthic and planktonic foraminifera, colomiellids, nannoconids, and radiolarians) that permit detailed biostratigraphic determinations. A complete Aptian-lower Albian section (base of K-6 through top of K-15 of the biochronologic scheme of Longoria, 1984) was identified. Abrupt lithic changes through the Aptian-Albian section of Lampazos revealed three major paleoceanographic events having an overall regional marine transgression, including an early Aptian (K-6 to K-7) event, a late Aptian (K-10 to K-11) event, and an early Albian (K-13 to K-14) maximum flooding phase. We used physical and biochronologic data to tie the aforementioned events to geochemically constrained Aptian-Albian oceanic anoxic events (OAEs) in Santa Rosa Canyon of Nuevo Leon.

The close correlation between the oceanic events in east Sonora (northwest Mexico) and central Nuevo Leon (northeast Mexico) invokes the closer paleogeographic development of the two regions (Begin page 1812) and undoubtedly links the area of Lampazos to a rapid encroachment of the paleo-Gulf of Mexico through north-central Mexico (the Mexican Sea) into northwestern Mexico (Chihuahua trough and Sonoran basin). The early Aptian (biozones K-6 to K-7) transgression has its maximum extension during the early Albian (biozones K-13 to K-14), culminating with the drowning of the carbonate platforms.

The Lower Cretaceous rocks exposed in the Lampazos area are complexly folded and faulted. The more conspicuous structures are isoclinal and box-shaped folds and thrust faults, mostly oriented north-south and northwest-southeast, having vergences to both the northeast and southwest. A very conspicuous feature is the opposite vergence of thrust faults, either converging or diverging. Two dextral strike-slip faults (northeast-southwest and east-west) separate the area into three large blocks that have different patterns of folds and thrust faults. Also, it is evident that the area was affected by at least two episodes of normal faulting. Furthermore, the structural style of deformation present in the Lampazos succession is remarkably similar to the style of deformation of coeval rocks in northeastern Mexico, especially to the structure of the Chihuahua tectonic belt. The Lampazos succession is paleogeographically and tectonically related to the Chihuahua tectonic belt, and it is considered to be the westernmost extension of the ancestral Gulf of Mexico.

The fact that the Lampazos succession can be lithocorrelated to known sequences in northeastern Chihuahua (Lucero, Ahumada, and Loma Plata formations) and northeast Mexico (Cupido, San Angel, La Pe±a, and Tamaulipas formations), which are know to be source rocks in exploration wells in Nuevo Leon and Coahuila, makes the Lampazos area of Sonora potentially attractive as an exploration target.

name: Andara + Fuente De, Asturia
remarks:
Beresella (paleosiphono-cladal alga) in sparitic matrix dominant.
Buildups several 10s of m thick together with phylloid algae, chaetetids, sphinctozoans and small rugose corals.

name: NE Cantabrian Mts., Castilla y Leon
remarks:
Anthracoporella (dasycladacean alga) dominant. 
Spiculae as evidence for presence of sponges.
Sphintozoans are also present in Lores Limestone

name: Tende Hantu Mts., Mangkalihat, Borneo
remarks: Atoll structure with low energy, slightly restricted platform interior structure, steep southern and eastern coral reef margins and a northwestern margin with a 'step-wise' appearance.

name: Muarawahau, Borneo
remarks: Coral and coralline algae bioclastic pack/rudstone to floatstone with abundant fragmented shallow marine bioclasts including recrystallized corals, coralline algae and Nummulites.

name: Muarawahau, Borneo
remarks:
Coral pack/floatstones in a marly matrix. Ta 3.
Branching corals, oysters, some larger benthic forams and miliolids.
Low energy inner shelf setting.

name: Gurung Pengabun, Borneo
remarks: Abundant reworked branching nd rounded massive corals inferred to have been derived from a nearby patch reef environment.

name: Batuputih, Mangkalihat, Borneo
remarks:
Coral bafflestones, rudstones and framestones.
Patch reefs on seaward side of platform.
Reservoir potential most prominent in platoform interior (re.f 2819).

name: Off Tarakan, Borneo
remarks:
Linear delta-front reefs.
Framestones, floatstones, 
Corals prevailing, larger forams, coralline algae and Halimeda.

name: Miller Creek, Blanco Co., Texas
remarks:
Nearshore oyster biostrome traced over 35 km2. Around 1 m thick. Clusters up to 1 m in diameter. 
Thick-bodied gastropods, mud-burrowing clams and serpulid worm tubes present.

name: Lake Austin, Travis Co., Texas
remarks:
Monopleurid biostromes in several horizons within the lowe Glen Rose.
Tabular and conical colonies.
Three species of monopleurids.
Few Ostrea are associated.

name: Cibolo Creek, Kendall Co., Texas
remarks:
Main Caprinid reef trend at shelf edge.
Coalcomana texana Whitney strongly prevailing. 
Some coralline and dasycladacean algae present. 
Common living position

name: The Narrows, Blanco River, Hays Co., Texas
remarks:
Coral reef with rich fauna, older than Glen Rose trend (basal Glen Rose Fm.).
Includes Spring Branch-Cranes Mill region, Comal County

name: Kirkfield, Brich Island, Ontario
remarks: Small Tetradium microatoll

name: North-central Kentucky
remarks: Late Maysvillian-Gamachian bryozoan reef mounds

name: Madison, Indiana
remarks: Biostromes dominated by corals Favistina and Tetradium

name: SE Indiana
remarks: Biostromes dominated by Labechia and locally Tetradium.

name: New Wells, SE Missouri
remarks: Small biohermal mounds with solitary corals, green alga Dimorphosiphon and encrusting bryozoans. Borings!

name: Tripolitania
remarks:
10-100 m thick bryozoan dominated biostromes (figures suggest reef mounds
Wackestones with bryozoans, some biomicritc seems, intense dolomitization.
Bryozoans mostly vertically oriented with little evidence of dismantling.

name: Khabt-el Hajar, Anti-Atlas
remarks: Bryozoan biostromes and or 'reef-like' lenses, also associated with cystoids.

name: Balbanyu River, Prepolar Urals
remarks: Dolostones show abundant relict corals and 'algae' in massive unbedded strata  of the Yaptikshor Fm., which are identified as 50m thick reefs (ibid., p.102, 116): these have a Holorhynchus, Mesofavosites, Paleophyllum  fauna of Hirnantian age, suggesting that  these reefs were like those of the Baltic area.

name: Abadeh
remarks:
5-6 m thick patch reefs, lateral extension up to 30 m in shallowing upward sequence of first cycle.
Porites-Faviidae assemblage.

10 m thick and 200 m long reefs in next cycle.
Porites-Faviidae assemblage but Porites less abundant than in lower reef. Heavily encrusted by coralline algae. 80-90 % coral coverage. 

20 species indicated (Genera: Acanthastrea, Acropora, Agathiphyllia, Antiguastrea, Astreopora, Astrocoenia, Caulastrea, Diploastrea, Favites, Goniopora, Hydnophora, Leptoria, Montastrea, Porites, Stylocoenia, Stylophora). Algae not described.

name: Qom
remarks:
Back-arc basin.
Small patch reefs at very top of Qom section. 
2-3 m thick some tens of m lateral extension.
Formed by dome-shaped colonies (mostly faviids) and large Caulastrea thickets.

name: Haletown, Tennessee
remarks:
Microbial mound growing on grainstones and buried by grainstones.

Abstract 1835:
Carbonate mounds within the Chesterian (Mississippian) Bangor Limestone in north Alabama and east Tennessee are few in number, but diverse in character. Fourteen known mounds in this area can be assigned to five categories: 1) stromatolitic, 2) mud, 3) bryozoan-crinoid-coral, 4) bryozoan-crinoid, and 5) coral. Stromatolitic and mud mounds are microbial, bryozoan-crinoid-coral mounds are biodetrital, and coral mounds and some bryozoan-crinoid mounds are biohermal (reefal). Three lensoid stromatolites within crinkly-laminated dolomudstone comprise a single mound horizon about 0.5 m thick east of Monteagle, Tennessee. Near Haletown, Tennessee, the Bangor Limestone contains two mud mounds. The largest measures 8.2 m across and contains articulated bivalves and brachiopods, and intact fenestrate bryozoans. The mound's upper surface is bored. The mud matrix appears to contain tubular microfossils resembling Renalcis. A single bryozoan-crinoid-coral mound has been identified in Lawrence County, Alabama. It is approximately 25 m wide, up to 1.6 m thick, and had a maximum of 45 cm of synoptic relief. This mound is dominated by in situ colonies of the large rugosan Caninia sp. in a matrix of fenestrate bryozoan and echinoderm debris. A bryozoan-crinoid mound about 0.7 m thick and 1.5 m wide near Blount Springs, Alabama, contains a framework of fenestrate bryozoans and serpulids, spar-filled voids, and skeletal debris dominated by echinoderm ossicles. Bryozoan-crinoid mounds about 2 m thick have been reported from the Bangor-Pennington transition zone east of Monteagle. Five mounds up to 15 m wide and up to 1.5 m thick that are constructed entirely by Caninia sp. are known near Blount Springs and Lacon, Alabama.   Bangor mounds are relatively rare and small, suggesting environmental stress. The mounds we examined are mostly underlain by packstone/grainstone, which suggests that the principal stressor might have been a mobile substrate coupled with periodic smothering. However, the Lawrence County mound is underlain by oolitic grainstone that had first been indurated during a period of early subaerial exposure. Early diagenesis or other stabilization mechanisms probably occurred at the other mound sites as well.

name: Lacon, Alabama
remarks:
Stromatolitic biostrome.

name: Peace Reach, Williston Lake, B.C.
remarks:
Terebratulid-echinoderm biostromes.

Abstract ref. 1836:
Abstract: Mesozoic carbonate accumulations are rare in northwestern Pangea. This is due, initially to the demise of many carbonate secreting organisms during the terminal Permian biotic crisis and subsequently, to increased clastic sedimentation resulting from the tectonic development of western North America. Ecological voids resulting from the extinction however resulted in new opportunities for surviving taxa. Terebratulid brachiopod-echinoderm dominated biostromes within the primarily siliciclastic Liard Formation ( Middle Triassic, Ladinian) of northeastern British Columbia provide an example of this.  The Liard biostromes are composed primarily of whole and unabraded terebratulid brachiopods, articulate crinoid elements and cidaroid echinoid spines and interambulacral plates. Many of the terebratulid brachiopods are characterized by the pedicle attachment trace fossil Podichnus. Other organisms which occupied the biostromes include acrotretid and spiriferid brachiopods, bivalves, and gastropods, as well as rare bryozoans, oysters and possibly scleractinian corals.  Sedimentary units deposited on the margins of the biostromes are characterized by an abundance of body fossils (decapod crustaceans, bivalves and ophiuroids) and trace fossils (i.e. Asterosoma, Cylindrichnus, Palaeophycus, Rosselia, Teichichnus and Thalassinoides). This trace fossil assemblage contains a mix of horizontal and vertical deposit feeding organisms, consistent with deposition in a lower shoreface setting. Hiatal surfaces and laterally restricted bioclastic sandstone layers and lenses within these features suggests that frequent turnover of infaunal and epifaunal communities occurred at the edges of the Liard brachiopod-echinoderm biostromes.  Environmental/ecological criteria essential for the development of the Liard biostromes include: a) initial storm-induced concentration of shell material to create islands or zones of comparably stable substrate, thus promoting colonization by crinoids, terebratulid brachiopods, and cidaroid echinoids; b) a temporary decrease in siliciclastic input to the shoreface, allowing biostrome building organisms the chance to colonize these patches of stable substrate, and dominate deposition within the lower shoreface, and c) aerobic conditions in the lower shoreface allowing for a healthy and robust biostrome fauna.

name: New York Route 67, Amsterdam, New York
remarks:
Wolf Hollow Member
Pillow- to dome shaped and biostromal thrombolites in intraclast-echinoderm pack- to grainstone matrix.
Scour-and fill structures.

Tribes Hill microbial reef mounds, occupied 
the basal part of meter-scale shallowing-upward 
cycles.  They are part of a high-energy facies that a 
sharp, transgressive surface separates from an 
underlying low-energy peritidal setting.  This 
erosional surface served as the surface on which one 
of the reef mounds established itself during initial 
transgression before further deepening.  The others 
overlie a floor of skeletal grainstone reflecting a 
high-stand sea-level facies tract.  Skeletal grainstone 
composes the fill between the mounds.  One channel 
and several aggrading hummocks occupy inter-reef 
mound areas resulting from storm events in a subtidal 
setting.  This study is part of a continuing program of 
Tribes Hill sedimentology.

name: Reed North Quarry, Fairborn, Green Co., Ohio
remarks:
Stromatoporpoids more common on leeward side

Ref. 1843:
The Early Silurian is a critical time for understanding the evolution of corals and their role as reef-builders. By the middle Early Silurian, corals and stromatoporoids were the primary reef-building organisms. The Brassfield Formation (Llandoverian) in southwestern Ohio consists principally of nearshore bioclastic grainstones and packstones with occasional boundstones and minor shale intervals. Numerous coral-stromatoporoid patch reefs reported from the Brassfield are among the oldest known in the United States. Unlike other Silurian reefs in the U.S., Brassfield reefs are undolomitized and well-preserved. These conditions allow observation of fine-scale morphological details and permit a detailed taxonomic and paleoecologic comparison with other Silurian reef communities.  Fossil material (in situ and from float) was collected from a Brassfield patch reef exposed in the Reed North Quarry, Fairborn, Greene County, Ohio. Approximately 350 fossil specimens were identified during preliminary mapping of at least 72 square meters of the patch reef. In order of abundance, the reef-building organisms include favositids (176 colonies), stromatoporoids (109 specimens), colonial rugosans (37 specimens), halysitids (16 colonies), and solitary rugosans (9 specimens). A few specimens have encrusting crinoid or bryozoan holdfasts. Initial observations indicate that this Brassfield patch reef is consistent with the model of a typical Early Silurian reef.

name: Guerrero
remarks:
Ref. 1844:
The Upper Permian in South Mexico includes the Olinala Formation in the state of Guerrero. This formation is the youngest Paleozoic sedimentary cover of the Mixteco Terrane. This formation contains the youngest Permian beds reported in Mexico (Woardian, Capitanian). The lower and middle part, containg fosilss of goniatits, of Woardian age, consists of silisiclastic rocks, while the upper part is a carbonate sequence of Late Guadalupean age. The carbonate sequence overlies the siliciclastic sequence by erosional contact. This carbonate sequence is a ramp deposit, the inner shallow ramp deposits are mainly composed of echinoderm debris grainstone-packstones, in which are found, crinoids, pelecypods, gastropods, as well as microfossils such as Parachaetes sp, seaweed (Tubhyfites sp; Tubhyfites obscurus Maslov 1956), boundstones type LLH(C), and organic bank crinoids boundstones and shoal bioclastic grainstones.  The middle ramp is characterized by interbeded finegrained limestones and sandstones. The limestones are bioclastic packstone-wackestones with echinoid fragments (crinoids mainly), bryozoa, pelecypod shells of, brachiopod spines, small Foraminifera (Abadehella ex gr.coniformis) and fusulinids (Codonofusiela extensa Skinner& Wilde, 1955; Rauserella errática, Dumbar 1944, Condofusiella extensa Skinner & Wilde 1955) of Woardian-Capitanian age. The sanstones are litarenites and sub litarenites.  The deep ramp deposits consist of carbonate mud mount of cyanobacterium (Tubiphytes, Aelisaccus), calcareous sponges, Prorichtofenids, and bryozoa, that trap the calcareous mudstone, forming typical stromatactitis.

Abstract of ref. 1849:
The palaeoecology of calcimicrobial communities from the only Gondwana-related Lower Cambrian in Central Europe (eastern Germany, carbonates and siliciclastics) has been studied. Six morphological groups of calcimicrobes are described. Some of them show a significant ability for sediment stabilization and construction of biohermal reef mounds. Other types of calcimicrobes were more common in biostromal thickets. Some of them were capable of populating different environments, growing in different modes and on different substrates. An Epiphyton-archaeocyathan reef mound is described, illustrating the importance of calcimicrobes for mound formation. The fossil communities together with a complex of sedimentary features allow a reconstruction of the depositional history of the environment. Based on comparison with similar Gondwanan Lower Cambrian successions (Sardinia/Italy, Spain) and facies development a model is proposed describing the sedimentary history. Three depositional stages are distinguished: (1) deep subtidal ramp, (2) shallow subtidal ramp, (3) shallow subtidal to intertidal mixed siliciclastic-carbonate ramp with migrating oolitic shoals. In spite of similarities with the deposits in southern Europe, some distinct differences exist with respect to the succession of facies, the completeness of the sections, the fossil spectrum, and the nature of the siliciclastic sediments. For the German Lower Cambrian, a facies development from a low energy deep environment to a high energy shallow environment (partly restricted and with some evaporites) can be reconstructed. As compared with Sardinia and Spain, the depositional environment of the eastern German Lower Cambrian successions was predominantly characterized by low-energy conditions.

name: Eastern Ellesmere Island
remarks:
Coral-microbial shelf margin reef tract
500 m thickness exposed (base covered by glacier).
New genus of branching rugose corals prevails (up to 1 m in diameter).
Additionally cf. Halysites (up to 50 cm in diameter)
Corals encrusted by microbialites and lesser radiacial calcite.
Up to 50 % marine cement locally.
Microbialites: clotted or vaguelly laminated micrites, 3-5% calcimicrobes (Renalcis, Epiphyton', cf. Gammia).
Stromatoporoids, brachiopods, megalodont bivalves and lithistid sponges are accessorial.

Abstract or ref. 1861:
A recently discovered Silurian reef tract in the high Canadian Arctic has an exposed length of more than 150 km and is locally more than 500 m thick. The reefs occur within a Silurian ramp and rimmed shelf-margin sequence about 2 km thick. Conodont biostratigraphic data indicate that the reefal strata are late Llandovery to Ludlow in age, and reefs are composed largely of coral-microbial boundstone, The corals are mainly digitate rugosans and large halysitids, associated with fewer stromatoporoids and lithistid sponges. However, most of the reefal strata consist of microbialite, which encrusts skeletal metazoans or is massive or thromboidal. Microbialite microstructure consists mainly of clotted micrite or laminated micrite associated with common Renalcis, other calcimicrobes, and locally abundant early marine cements. Other reef rock types include stromatactis-rich lime mudstone, cementstone, zebroid stromatactis-bearing lime mud-stone, crinoidal grainstone, and, rarely, stromatoporoid boundstone. The reefs formed on the shelf margin and prograded basinward in three distinct phases during Wenlock and Ludlow time. Underlying Llandovery, shelf-margin facies are highly dolomitized and may represent an original stromatoporoid boundstone. Overlying late Ludlow to Pridoli carbonates were deposited on a prograding carbonate ramp, dotted with small coral-stromatoporoid and other biostromes, Three periods of Silurian reef growth can be recognized in the Arctic: Llandovery, latest Llandovery-late Ludlow, and late Ludlow-Pridoli. The Llandovery phase was widespread, and large stromatoporoid-coral reefs occupied a variety of depositional settings, including shelf-edge, intrashelf, drowned shelf, and slope. Late Llandovery to late Ludlow reefs were also regionally extensive, but were predominantly coral-microbial boundstone and locally grainstone-rich structures containing accessory metazoan (stromatoporoid-coral) framestone and boundstone. These formed high-relief structures with coarse allochthonous debris aprons. Large stromatoporoid-coral reefs were also present, but these were confined to areas characterized by high rates of siliciclastic sedimentation or to intrashelf areas. Another regional change in reef composition occurred in the latest Ludlow. Initially, reefs were rare and dominated by lithistid sponges and microbialites, but in Pridoli time, they became widespread and were constructed by corals and stromatoporoids, as were their Llandovery ancestors. In addition, the Pridoli reefs did not attain the large sizes of reefs in the two older sequences. The three phases of reef development can be related to important, basinwide sequence boundaries. Microbialite-rich reefs have also been described from northwestern Russia, Alaska, and eastern Canada and are some of the largest reef structures known. Their large size reveals a need to reconsider popular reef evolutionary models, in which skeletal metazoans are regarded as the predominant constructors. Large reef size is implied in these evolutionary models, but, based on this and other reef studies, microbialite-rich reefs equal, and commonly surpass, the dimensions exhibited by coral-stromatoporoid reefs. Considering the microbialite-rich reefs, now known from both the Ordovician acid Silurian, it is clear that benthic microbial communities played a very important role in reef construction through the lower Paleozoic.

name: Tiewadian, Xian, Shaanxi
remarks: Webby pers. comm.

name: Tiewadian, Xian, Shaanxi
remarks:
Webby, 2002:
A series of reef complexes, reefs, and biostromes have been
reported through a carbonate succession 600 m thick at Tiewadian
(Fig. 5) and equivalent sequences of adjoining areas, north of the
Wei River, Shaanxi Province (Ye et al., 1995, Ye et al., 1996). They
occur on topographic highs of the rifted, southwestern margin of
the Ordos Platform (North China Block). At Tiewadian the sequence
includes a composite, 150-m-thick reef complex composed
of superposed biostromes and reef mounds, a 30-m-thick
biostrome, and discrete, large to small, lens-shaped reefs, from 5
to 35 m thick. A wide range of frame-builders and binders are
recorded, though seldom all groups in a single reef or biostrome.
Stromatoporoid Forolinia (probably Labechia), and microbes
Phacelophyton, Renalcis, Epiphyton, Trichophyton, and Girvanella,
are the main contributors. Less important are algae Solenopora,
Vermiporella, and the corals Lichenaria, Cryptolichenaria, Amsassia,
and Eofletcheria. Some larger reefs exhibit a generalized framework
succession: substrate stablization of bioclasts by microbial
(stromatolitic) growth, in places associated with corals or succeeded
by them, and then dominant Forolinia, and/or less common
Phacelophyton, towards the top. Smaller reefs are mainly
stromatolitic. Vermiporella, though recorded by Ye et al. (1996) as
a major reef builder, may have had a more limited role in
sediment production.

name: Bidu River, Kerman
remarks:
Well developed coral-stromatoporoid biostromes (probably reefs). 25 m thick.

Rugose corals: Hexagonaria, Peneckialla, Disphyllum, Temnophyllum

Position?

name: Tuosuo Lake - Huashixia, Kunlun Mts., Qinghai
remarks:
Stratigraphy according to ref. 2220
Reef growth starting in Longlinian with Tubiphytes-Archaeolithoporella frame and crinoid bryozoan baffle frame.
Abstract of ref. 1915:
The early Permian reef belt is distributed in the southern side of eastern Kunlun, north area of Qinghai-Tiber Plateau. The core-reef facies of the reef extends from Tuosuo Lake to Huashixia. Lots of reef breccia was found at the southern slope of the core-reef belt, and to the north of the reef belt there is back-reef limestone. Calcisponges, hydrozoa, bryozoa, Tabulozoa, Tubiphytes and red algae are the main frame-building organisms. Archaeolithoporella, laminated blue-green algaes, Tabulozoa and Tubiphytes played a role of binding or encrustating. There are many kinds of epibiont in the reef, including brachiopod, gasteropod, foraminifera, echinoderm and simple coral. The type and the characteristics of the reef- building organisms in eastern Kunlun and Animaqing are basically the same as those in the south of China.

name: Asher Atlit 1 Borehole,
remarks:

Reef builders include coralline sponges, microbial crusts and sessile foraminifera, various microproblematica (Microtubus, Bacinella) and corals. Back-reef environments are characterized by algal-foraminiferal facies with coated grains, oncoids and foraminifera, and a grapestone facies.

name: NMA-1 well, Male
remarks:
Abstract of ref. 1928:
As documented by industrial seismic reflection profiles and well data, the Cenozoic stratigraphic evolution of the Maldive carbonate system shows three distinct intervals characterised by their own specific depositional signatures. Late Palaeocene volcanics generated by the Reunion hotspot filled deeper pull-apart structures and created a flat topography that promoted the onset of the Maldive carbonate system in the early Eocene. Some of the initial structural depressions remained as deep internal seaways surrounded by reefal margins until the late Oligocene. The Eocene-Early Oligocene stratigraphic signature is essentially aggradational and corresponds to a transgressive cycle associated with a second-order sea-level rise. In the mid-Oligocene, a major sea-level fall exposed the neritic carbonate system and restricted sedimentation to the former deep internal basins. During the next transgression, a neritic carbonate system re-established itself on the newly flooded platform and was finally drowned near the Oligocene- Miocene boundary. The main effect of this second-order transgressive cycle was the transformation of the central troughs into one single deep basin in the Neogene, the palaeo- Maldive Inner Sea. When a reef framework was established in the early Miocene near the present location of the platform edge, systematic bank margin progradation toward the central Inner Sea basin became enhanced. This Neogene progradational phase is explained as the response to a long-term sealevel fall associated with a second- order regressive cycle. Finally, the late Pliocene-Pleistocene depositional signature is mainly aggradational and corresponds to the regional modification from flat-topped carbonate banks to atoll physiographies. The 'antecedent karst theory' suggests that increased karstification was triggered by high-frequency eustatic and climatic changes in the last 3.0 Ma.

name: Bandung, Java
remarks:
Abstract ref. 1943:
Outcrops of the Rajamandala Formation limestone near Bandung offer an excellent opportunity to study the facies -relationships of an Early Tertiary reef, which may serve as a model for Tertiary reef exploration in Indonesia. The limestones are exposed along quarries and natural Outcrops along the road from Bandung to Jakarta. These limestones with thicknesses of approximately 600 meters are dipping 40 to 60 degrees toward the south and are involved in asymmetric folding and thrusting towards the north. 
Along its ENE-WSW trending strike the limestone exhibits a graded granular limestone facies representing turbidites at the toe of the basin-slope facies, a foraminiferal algal facies with rudstone facies representing a fore-reef facies, a coral-algal baffiestone to boundstone facies (locally quarried and slabbe as commercial marble), representing, reef ramparts, and a possible milliolid limestone facies with isolated patch reefs, representing the lagoonal back reef facies. 


CORAL DEBRIS RUDSTONE FACIES: 
This facies consists of angular fragments of corals and other limestones, mostly dark grey, embedded in a limemud matrix, which is generally lighter in color. Fragments, poorly sorted, vary in size up to 30 cm. Matrix contains considerable amounts of large foraminifera mainly Lepidocyclina. This facies represents talus-slope debris of coral fragments from the main reef

CORAL BOUNDSTONE FACIES: 


In general this consists of corals in growth position in which the spaces among the coral framework are filled up with muds containing coral debris, large foraminifera, etc. often bound with encrusting red algae. The rocks are light colored and are usually dense, massive, nonbedded to poorly bedded, with no primary porosity. The following sub-facies can be recognized based on the type of corals: 


Massive Head Corals Boundstone: This facies consists mainly of colonies of massive head corals, such as brain-corals, Meandrina etc. with encrusting red algae. A pack-stone facies, rich in foraminifera, is common in between the coral colonies. Worm tubes are very common in this facies, as well as large shells of gastropods and lamelli-branchia. These rocks are very massive, dense and usually white in color. The carbonates are very pure, containing over 95% calcium carbonate. Recrystallization is fairly. This rock is polished into commercial marble, common. This facies presumably represents the reef crest or reef flat. 


Platy Coral Boundstone: This facies consists of platy corals, which are aligned parallel to bedding. Within the framework of these boundstone are pockets of foraminiferal packstone to wackestone. These rocks are mostly massive and poorly bedded, but occasionally show wavy bedding. This facies presumably represents the deeper environment of the reef front. 

Branching Coral Bafflestone: This facies consists primarily of branching corals, mostly in growth position, some as broken fragments ' , embedded in a limemud matrix. Typical corals are Porites, Acropora, -RhabdophyIlia etc. (Gerth, 1933). Branching coral facies presumably represent sub-wayebase environments of the reef front. 


These three sub-facies are usually intermixed together and cannot be differentiated, but often the platy coral boundstone and especially branching corals bafflestone form' definite facies development, such as G. Pawon and G. Manik. 


REEF DEPOSITIONAL ENVIRONMENTS 


Measured sections at several localities and their lateral correlations indicates that depositional environments of the reef related sediments can be identified, based on the lateral facies developments, as well as each individual facies. The following depositional environments can be recognized:

name: Maestrazgo and Aliaga-Penyagolosa Basins
remarks:

In places they are replaced by microsolenid-dominated patch reefs of biohermal character (up to 7 m in diameter) built by crustose and ramose coral morphotypes.
The coral bioherms are overlain by requieniid rudist beds in micritic matrix.

Lowermost reefal interval in Kugitang.
