Coordinates updated May 2010

name: Daluokeng, Gaofeng, Cili Co., Hunan
remarks:
lower Daluokeng Fm.:
Greyish white massive sponge-algal-microbial framestone, intercalated lenticular beds of wackestones, shell beds containing corals, sponges, forams, calcareous algae and the brachiopods Uncinunellina multicostioidea, Spirigerell ovalioides, S. shuizhtangensis, Ladoliplica zigzagiformis, L. platformia.
Brachiopds much rarer in underlying coral limestones of the Xiamidong Fm.

Reef overlain by thick-bedded wackestones with intraclasts (Member 2) and oolitic limestone (Member 3).

Abstract ref. 2128:
Bafflestones, framestones as well as bindstones are described. According to the function of reef-building, the organisms are classified to frame-builder, bind organisms and clastic-builder, in which main frame-builders are Sphictozoa, Inozoa, Tabulozoa and Hydrozoan, the bind organisms are Archaeolithiporella, Tubiphytes, Tabulozoa and blue-green algae. Four developing stages of the reefs have been distinguished.

name: Blue Pool Bay, Wales
remarks:
Abstract of ref. 1976:
Buildups with a rigid coral framework are generally rare in Lower Carboniferous time. An exception was found in the Hunts Bay
Oolite-Formation at Blue Pool Bay (Gower Peninsula). This bioherm is intercalated in well-bedded oolitic limestones. It is about 25 meters in
width and rises up to 10 meters in thickness. The coral association indicates an Asbian age of the bioherm. The core of the structure consists of
large massive colonies of Lithostrotion and a small number of dendroid colonies (Siphonodendron and Syringopora). Most of the corals are
preserved in living position. The density of the colonies is high, in many cases they grow upon eachother. Dendroid corals become more
common in the outer core. An increase of colonies, which are upside-down orientated, together with broken colonies and coarse debris
describe the facies of the flanks. The general decrease of the amount of corals and the gradual increase of fragments of colonies in bioclastic
rudstones to wackestones at the top of the structure characterize the end of the biohermal development. 

Due to the appearance of a coral framework and its thickness, the bioherm is wave resistant. It is described as the first ecological coral-reef of
the Lower Carboniferous of South Wales.

name: Cap Guir, Agadir, Maghreb
remarks:
Peninsula north of Agadir

Coral reef with 70% massive and rare branching corals. Other reef builders are stromatoporoids, bryozoans, mollusks and microbialites (laminated stromatolites and peloidal thrombolites) and microencrusters (Bacinella, Tubiphytes, Lithocodium, encrusting forams), rare solenoporeaceans.
Microbialites approaching 25% or reef volume.

name: Cap Guir, Agadir, Maghreb
remarks:
reef mostly built by stromatoporoids (30%), corals (20%) (Stylina tubilifera, Thecosmilia) and chaetetids, rare mollusks and bryozoans. 
Abundant internal reef debris (50%).

Microbialites especially abundant in colonisation stage approaching 40%. Stromatolites associated with abundant microencrusters: Tubiphytes, Bacinella and Lithocodium. 
Very pronounced succession with stabilisation, colonisation, diversification and domination indicated.

name: Jinan, Shandong
remarks:
Thrombolite microframes

Abstract ref. 1979:
Mid Cambrian reefs with microframe structure built by calcified microbes, probably cyanobacteria, are well-exposed in the Zhangxia Formation near Jinan in
Shandong Province. Members of the Epiphyton, Renalcis and Girvanella groups are almost solely responsible for a series of extensive biostromes, individually up to 15 m thick, in which metazoans are scarce. These reefs are surrounded by coarse cross-bedded oolite-pisolite, reflecting rapid growth in a high-energy environment.
The two main reef lithotypes present are: (1) matrix-rich Tarthinia-Tubomorphophyton thrombolite-dendrolite microclusters, and (2) Gordonophyton-Razumovskia thrombolite microframes. The latter were created by rectilinear arrangement of prostrate and vertical microbial filaments, and the small (millimetric) size of the cavities contributed to framework strength.
Similar, but usually less well-preserved, mid-late Cambrian reefs appear to be widespread in Asia and North America. These North China examples establish
microbial microframes as a distinctive reef-structure, and show that frame-building continued during the Cambrian despite archaeocyath demise.

name: Novonikolayev Oil Field, Dnjeper
remarks:
Several oil-gas bearing reefs in Dniepr-Donets depression mentioned in text, but exact localities not provided:
Bogatoy, Kampan, Machekh, Novonikoleyev, Selyukhov, Belichev.

name: Inangahua Outlier, Reefton
remarks:
Buller Terrane.

Horizons of bio-rudite in places exceptionally rich in largely transported coral and stromatoporoid colonies. 
Near coastal environment.

Abstract of ref. 2236:
Study of 35 systematically collected and 10 semi-random samples (about 100 cm(2) each) from one outcrop of the Lankey Limestone (Emsian) near Reefton, New Zealand indicates that it is a reef framestone built by tabulate (4? spp.) and clonal rugose (one sp.) corals, two species of stromatoporoids, a few bryozoans (2? spp.) and crinoids. The guild structure of the reef community and data on skeleton orientation and growth direction further indicate that there was relatively minor biostratonomic alteration of the original community. Skeletons are either in growth position or tipped, toppled or even overturned, but they have remained in situ. Other clone-rich Lankey Limestone outcrops in the Reefton area support the notion of an upper shelf reef system and stratigraphic and sedimentologic data suggest that it was located near the Gondwana margin at a paleolatitude of about 35 degreesS.

name: Maloichskaya, West Siberia
remarks:
Brecciaform limestones with fragments of 'algae' and stromatoporoids.
Many reef builders in common with Nyurolka basin:

Rugose corals:

and many stromatoporoids

name: Manchester Plateau, central Jamaica
remarks:
About 20 genera and >30 coral species
5-8 M thick.

Age was Lower Miocene. Revised to latest Oligocene in ref. 2574

Abstract of ref. 1993:
During the middle Tertiary, the island of Jamaica was part of a large system of shallow carbonate platforms extending northeast along the Nicaraguan Rise.
Although these platforms undoubtedly supported a rich fauna of marine benthos, the coral communities of this region are poorly known. New exposures in Jamaica,
however, provide a clearer picture of the development of these Tertiary reefs, especially those spanning the Oligocene/Miocene transition, a time of significant
taxonomic turnover in Caribbean corals. 

Recent bauxite mining on the Manchester Plateau of central Jamaica exposed well-developed (5 - 8 m thick) patch reefs in the Lower Miocene of the Newport
Formation. Sections through these coral build-ups have been logged and extensively sampled. This material was compared with new data from similarly exposed
reefs in the Upper Oligocene Brown's Town Formation of north central Jamaica. Cluster analysis and ordination of coral occurrences has revealed similarities as well
as distinct differences between Oligocene and Miocene assemblages.

Both units contain coral assemblages dominated by massive, branching, or plate-shaped colonies. Coral diversity is also roughly the same in each formation
(approximately 20 genera and >30 species). There is some turnover of species between the late Oligocene and early Miocene, but perhaps the most significant
difference between the sampled assemblages is a change in the relative abundance of certain key taxa. Antiguastrea cellulosa, for instance, is the dominant massive coral in the Upper Oligocene assemblages but is much less common in Lower Miocene faunas.

Ecologically and sedimentologically, there appears to be little difference between the coral build-ups in the Brown's Town and Newport Formations. This suggests
that, in contrast to some other regions in the Caribbean, patch reef communities in Jamaica thrived throughout the Oligocene/Miocene transition. Changes in dominant
coral taxa, however, could suggest a complex shift in community structure during this turnover interval.

name: North central Jamaica
remarks: No evidence for the Oligocene/Miocene reef crisis in Jamaica.

name: South central Pennsylvania
remarks:
Abstract ref. 1994:
Laurentian shelf margin deposits typically are dolomitized or metamorphosed, but the Ledger Fm. contains an exceptionally well preserved microbialite reef complex, riddled with large submarine cavities. The microbialite consists of Renalcis-like shrubs, centimeter-scale domal stromatolites, dense fronds and laminated
fabrics. Petrographically, the microbialite is expressed as clots of spherulites, stringers, arborescent garlands, and dendritic shrubs. Microbial processes dominated all
ecological niches; forming the substrate, colonizing cryptic spaces, coating and encrusting other algae. Cavities within the microbialite formed through a number of previously undescribed processes, at least on the large scale reported here. Organic decay led to the development of stromatactis-like voids on a meter-scale, while syn-depositional slumping and channel formation led to microbial props and folds which resulted in further void generation.  
These large cavities were stabilized with multiple generations of radiaxial fibrous and herringbone calcite cements, intercalated with internal sediment. The herringbone calcite cement has depleted carbon isotopic values relative to the radiaxial fibrous cement, even those within the same cavity. This suggests that the herringbone morphology is related to unusual porewater conditions. In this instance I interpret that the herringbone calcite reflects near anoxic porewaters due to large quantities of decaying microbial material nearby. 

Marine cement stratigraphy, based on petrography, CL, stable isotopes, and trace element geochemistry, demonstrate that the cavities did not fill simultaneously.
Rather, even adjacent cavities exhibit complex patterns of cementation, encrustation, and cement breakage, indicating that the reef's location was in a high energy,
shelf margin setting where storms and local events impacted each cavity differently.

name: Bappagai Well, Tankhai-Ust-Mil, Siberia
remarks: Large 'algal' reef complex underlain by Domanik facies type limestones of Lena-Amgan age.

name: Pueblo Nuevo, Chiapas

36 + 6 m thick structures superimposed in Oligocene barrier reef tract, separated by peat bed.
Camino Carretero Member of La Quinta Fm. 27 coral species are described; algae are not described. Dominant genera are: Diploastrea, Atiguastrea, Alveopora, Agathiphyllia, Colpopyllia, Favites, Porites. Strongly zoned: algal-Eulepidina shoal at base, branching coral bed, Porites bank, zone with massive corals.

name: Gor Loutat, Tindouf Basin, West Sahara
T-Reef, Gor Uein Terguet, Tindouf Bas., West Sahara
remarks:
Chain of stromatactis mud mounds with steep flanks. 
Some mounds with common rugose corals.
Crinoids common.

name: Gor Uein Terguet, Tindouf Basin, Western Sahara
remarks: Thin biostromal developments of thamnoporoid coral beds

name: Limonovka, central Urals
remarks: Steeply flanked mound composed of massive 'algae' and stromatoporoids (Actinostroma).

name: Monte San Angelo, Gargano
remarks:
From ref. 2006:
Formed by rudist framestones and bafflestones, the shelf edge-related rudist complexes, unlike the rudist banks, are commonly not well preserved in situ as the main source of the bioclastic sediments (Figure 10). In the Murge region they are clearly associated with (Begin page 1569) the fault systems that form the eastern shelf edge (Borgomano and Philip, 1987), and in the Gargano they occur as megablocks (>103 m3) in base-slope deposits (Figure 11). A detail study of the biogenic components of those bioclastic sands and blocks has shown that they were mainly sourced from rudist associations not found in the inner platform. Combined analyses of a few preserved shelf edge-related rudist complexes and the associated deeper marine sediments have allowed some of their characteristics to be established. They were dominated by recumbents rudists, including caprinids and Sabinia. The diversity, size, and shape of those rudists, commonly associated with rounded and well-sorted bioclastic gravels, suggest that they lived in a high-energy subtidal setting (Figure 10). These shelf edge-related rudist complexes could be considered as reefs (Longman, 1981), defined as carbonate buildups, influenced by organisms, that controlled depositional processes in adjacent zones and were situated on a topographic high.

name: Murge Area
remarks:
From ref. 2006:
Tidal channel-related rudist <bioherms> consist of meter-thick lenses or <bioherms> (Cummings, 1932) dominated by rudists, overlying algal-mud banks having an erosive contact (Figures 7a, 8). The horizontal dimensions of the rudist <bioherms> are less than 10 m. They are stacked in a progradational system and are overlain by algal-mud banks. The rudist communities are monospecific and have bafflestone-framestone structures (Embry and Klovan, 1971). The <bioherms> have filled preexisting depressions cut through the algal-mud banks. It is plausible that they have affinities with tidal channels because (1) they occur in a zone dominated by cryptalgal laminites inferred to have formed in intertidal environments, (2) they have the character of submarine deposits, and (3) they have prograded in depressions over a lag breccia rich in mud and stromatolitic clasts.

name: Ouachita Thrust Belt, Oklahoma
remarks:
The calcareous alga Donezella is composed of thin (typically 70-160 micrometer in diameter) branching segmented tubes, which bifurcate at an angle of 45-90
degrees. This calcareous alga is known to baffle sediment and build small (~6 m thick) to large (30-100 m thick) bioherms. Examples of Donezella-dominated
bioherms are reported from Middle Carboniferous strata of Algeria, the Canadian Arctic Archipelago, Spain, and West Texas. 
     A 5 m thick Donezella - siliceous sponge bioherm from the Wapanucka Formation was studied in detail by microfacies analysis. Due to high dip of the beds, the lateral dimension of the bioherm is not known. 
The bioherm overlies thin (20 cm), cross-bedded crinoidal-bioclastic packstone to grainstone, and is capped by peloidal packstone to grainstone The bioherm is primarily composed of Donezella boundstone-bafflestone and peloidal wackestone. In situ siliceous sponge bodies are locally preserved in the lower part of the buildup, by encrustation of micritic crusts and the red alga Archaeolithophyllum. Siliceous sponge spicules are common in the lower half of the bioherm and are rare to present throughout the upper half of the bioherm. The presence of siliceous sponge bodies in the lowest part of the buildup strongly suggests that they played a significant role in initial mound accretion. 
     The green calcareous alga Donezella is common to abundant throughout the bioherm. Donezella builds a delicate framework or colony of thalli enclosing constructional pores. These pores are filled with internal sediments, burial calcite cements, dark micritic crusts and peloids with fuzzy outlines. Toward the top of the bioherm Donezella is increasingly surrounded by carbonate mud. Worm tubes with dark, micritic, encrustations are common in Donezella colonies. 
     The calcareous alga Berestovia (or Claracrusta) is present mainly in the lower half of the bioherm, acting as the primary and secondary encruster of siliceous sponges. Berestovia is also the primary encruster of Donezella colonies. The red alga Archaeolithophyllum is locally present as the secondary and tertiary encruster of siliceous sponges in lower part of the bioherm. Broken segments of Archaeolithophyllum and other phylloid algae are increasingly present toward the top of the bioherm, often encrusted by encrusting foraminifera. 
      Ostracod, benthonic, and encrusting foraminifera are rare to present, but are increasingly present toward the top of the bioherm. Brachiopods, ramose bryozoans, crinoids and corals are rare to present, and are scattered irregularly throughout the bioherm. 
     The bioherm shows a subtle vertical community succession from Donezella boundstone to peloidal wackestone in the lower 5/6 of the bioherm to wackestone
with scattered Donezella, fragments of phylloid algae, ostracodes and foraminifera toward the top. This succession is interpreted as being due to shallowing. The presence of siliceous sponge bodies, the abundance of siliceous sponge spicules, and the lack of high-energy microfacies in this bioherm indicates initiation and growth in a quiet-water environment below storm-wave base in the open-marine / slope environment seaward of the platform-margin grainstone belt.

name: La Serre, Montagne Noire
remarks:
Abstract ref. 2009:
 During the Early and Middle Viséan rugose corals again occurred widespread within shallow water marine environments. To some extent they accumulated to form reefal structures. The significance and function of related rugose corals were highly variable. In order to achieve a systematic approach Lower Carboniferous biostromes and biohermes were examined in different geotectonic settings north (Belgium) and south (France: Montagne Noire) of the European Variscian orogenic belt. 
     In the Montagne Noire the Viséan to Namurian sequence is part of large olistoliths originating from an active continental margin. Limestone olistoliths yield different shallow-water communities. Bioherms show a community consisting of calcareous algae, cyanobacteria (e.g. Orthonella), and bryozoans. Accessory brachiopods, corals, molluscs, siliceous sponges, and foraminifers occur. Sporadically there are intercalations of dark, well-bedded pack- and grainstones (part of peri-biohermal facies). Some of the olistoliths yield a rich coral fauna. Most abundant are solitary corals (e.g. Axophyllum), but in some cases colonial forms contributed to the formation of biostromes and small bioherms. They were dominated in changing compositions by Lithostrotionidae, Lonsdaleia and Axophyllum.
These small structures seem to be bound to lagoonal or inter-biohermal settings. 
     In Belgium coral biostromes occur throughout the Viséan. Siphonodendron martini occurs in the capping-beds of the cryptalgal-bryozoan Buildup of Bomal
(Middle Viséan). During the Late Viséan a diverse coral fauna inhabited the microbial mounds of the Campine Basin. From the same interval two biostromes are known form Royseux (northern limb of the Dinant Syncline). These biostromes show important contributions by Lithostrotionidae. 
     In general Late Viséan and Early Namurian coral biostromes and bioherms appear to represent local niches. The reef-building potential seems to be relatively high if rugose corals and encrusting organisms co-occur.

name: Sierra de la Estrella, Guadiato
remarks:
Microbial mud mounds between inner and outer ramp setting.
Asbian-Brigantian

Abstract ref. 2010:
     In the Guadiato Area sedimentation occurred during the upper Viséan to form the Sierra de la Estrella outcrops which belong to the Sierra del Castillo Unit The
Guadiato Area is located on the boundary between the Ossa-Morena and Central-Iberian zones, in the south-western Iberian Peninsula, where Lower
Carboniferous outcrops are numerous. Buildups development has been recognised in most outcrops of the Sierra del Castillo Unit, and they are located at La Casa
de la Calera, Peñarroya, Sierra Boyera and Sierra de la Estrella. Although the stratigraphical setting of the first three sections has been previously described, their
buildup development and morphologies are different to those of Sierra de la Estrella, whose buildups are thicker and more abundant. 
     The stratigraphic succession from Sierra de la Estrella is dated precisely as upper Viséan by means of foraminifers (Zone 15 of Mamet). The main guide taxa are:
Palaeotextularia (bilaminar), Cribrostomum, Vissariotaxis compressa, Howchinia, 'Monotaxinoides' sp., Endothyranopsis crassa, and the Microproblematicum
Saccamminopsis fusulinaeformis. Sediments at Sierra de la Estrella show characteristics of a storm-dominated transitional zone between outer and inner ramp. The
outstanding feature of this ramp is the development of microbial buildups. They may be called mud-dominated buildups or mud-mounds because they are
mud-dominated (they show more than 50% of mud). They are regarded as microbial mounds because they are mainly composed of organomicrite and show
common stromatactoid cavities. 
     Two main morphologies have been identified: 

     1. Tabular mud-banks; they extend laterally for 1000 m to 1300 m, and are 35-60 m in thickness. 
     2. Domal mud-mounds; they have variable size; they are 2-25 m in thickness and 4- 40 m in diameter.

Buildup types were related to sedimentological conditions; domical mud-mounds were developed in transitional facies between the inner and outer ramp, with
variations in the environmental conditions, while tabular mud-banks were developed in more stable conditions in an outer ramp setting. 
     Microbial buildups are interbedded with tempestites and marls. Some siliciclastic beds showing erosion surfaces and hummocky cross-bedding also occur 
     The sedimentological and paleontological characteristics of the Sierra de la Estrella section allow us to recognise two deepening-upward sequences (probably of
4th order), which are integrated into a major transgressive sequence (belonging to a 3rd order cycle). This glacio-eustatic cycle is recognised in upper Viséan
throughout the Guadiato Area, so it could be envisaged that it will influence all outcrops from this epoch within the Ossa-Morena and Central Iberian zones.

name: Koscian reef, Bronsko reef, Rensko reef
remarks:
Gas reservoirs

Abstract ref. 2011:
     The gas saturated Zechstain Limestone Reefs within western and south western direction from Poznan have been recently discovered. These are Papro W reef
nearby Nowy Tomy l Town and Koscian - Bonikowo Kokorzyn reefs located nearby Koscian Town.  Koscian and Papro reefs and Bonikowo Kokorzyn reefs
were discovered with 2D and 3D seismic respectively.  The reefs were formed in the inner part of Zechstein See about 60-80 km north from the off shore carbonate
platform. The genesis of the reefs is strongly connected with a local Carboniferous paleo highs called Wolsztyn High (Fig 1). The paleo-highs are formed with
carboniferous sandstone (Koscian area) or Autunian volcanic rocks (Paproc_W area) and  they were covered by shallow see. In this shallows there were mainly
bryozoan reefs and oolitic-oncoidic carbonates deposited. Additionally, mostly at the top of the reef the stromatolite occurs. Porous reef body, characterised by
thickness of up to  90 m is surrounded by deep basin limestone facie which is deposited as thin (up to 5m thickness) tight mudstone. 
     Below this the most important parameters of the reefs are presented: 

     Porosity very good up to 35 % 
     Permeability variable 0.1 3000 mD

Paproc-W Reef, area 4 sqkm, top depth 2450m TVDSS, thickness 50-80 m -The first discovered by 2D seismic Zechstein Limestone Reef in Poland.  All its
thickness is gas saturated. The accumulated gas contains 40 % of hydrocarbons. 

          Koscian Reef ,  area 20 sqkm, top depth 2100m TVDSS, thickness 60 m. Koscian Reef is the largest of all discovered reefs body (Fig.3). 
          There is gas-water contact at the depth of 2208m.The resent discoveries allowed to located new Wielichowo and Ruchocice Reefs at NE from
          Koscian Reef. 
          Bonikowo Reef, area 9 sqkm, top depth 2260m TVDSS, thickness 90 m. 

     In 1999 several new reefs was discovered i.e. Rensko-Kokorzyn-Bronsko and it seems to be the largest discovered reef, however  shape of the reef was
interpreted from 3D seismic and wait for the wells drilling.  The reefs saturated  gas contains 81 % of hydrocarbons (80.5 % of methane) and 18 % of nitrogen. 
     It is very important to notice that the efficient reef prospecting is possible thanks to 3D seismic survey.  Both 2D and 3D seismic was shot by GEOFIZYKA
Toru.  Especially it is worth emphasising that final success is a result of a co-work of many people; geophysicists, geologists  and engineers. Presently, thanks to
excellent co-operation between POGC - Oil and Gas Zielona Góra and GEOFIZYKA Toru S.A. the exploration of the Zechstein Limestone reefs has become the
priority task for the companies operating in the western Poland

name: Black Nose, ODP 171B, West Atlantic
remarks:
Abstract ref. 

By Barremian-Aptian time, the reef stepped back 40-50 km from the lower Cretaceous margin and formed a long tract of coral-rudist reefs such as the one evident in seismic profiles in the shallow subsurface at the head of Blake Nose (Fig. 3). 

The Aptian reef tract ceased growth during the late Aptian, at which time periplatform debris was no longer delivered to the outer edge of Blake Nose, and the deposition of green and red variegated clays began.

name: Bihor Mountains
remarks: Allochthonous reefal blocks

name: Argentara Massif, Maritime Alps, France-Italian bor
remarks:
Abstract ref. 2024:
A finding of a Nerineae fauna in the southeast part of the Argentera massif and in the Tenda pass (Franco-Italian Alps) is reported. The formation is a reef facies of Kimmeridgian-Tithonian age (upper Jurassic). The following forms are represented in the fauna: an unidentified species of Nerinea, Ptygmatis cf. pseudobruntrutana, Phaneroptyxis moreana, and Cryptoplochus cf. subpyramidalis.

name: Malleval, Vercors
remarks:
Abstract ref. 2025 (not seen):
Sedimentary rocks exposed in the vicinity of Malleval (southeast France) include Tithonian (Jurassic), Berriasian, Valanginian, Hauterivian, and Urgonian (all lower Cretaceous) formations. A new outcrop of the upper Valanginian reef facies is reported. The Nant and Gerlette anticlines and the Picotiere syncline, all oriented north-south, are cut by three previously undescribed fracture systems: north-south, north-northwest-south-southeast, and  west-southwest-east-northeast. The late phase of tangential movements in the Subalpine region is probably responsible for westward thrusting along the fractures.

name: Siniscola-Posada, Sardegna
remarks:
Abstract ref. 2026:
On the eastern coast of Sardinia, in the Siniscola-Posada area, Jurassic rocks are transgressive on the Hercynic basement. The sequence begins with 15 to 50 metres of dolomitic limestones and dolostones, yielding Bathonian and Callovian ammonites. Oxfordian is probably missing. The middle Jurassic dolostones are directly overlaid by Kimmeridgian limestones, 100 m thick. The Beckeri zone is well represented in their upper half, with the index form and several other ammonites and aptichi. The Jurassic sequence ends with Tithonian limestones in reef facies.

name: Eastern Betic Cordillera
remarks:
Abstract ref. 2028:
Specimens of small diceratids from Tithonian (Jurassic) reef deposits of the eastern Betic cordilleras belong to Monnieria or a closely related genus. Their presence suggests analogous reef environments during the Portlandian and Tithonian in southern Spain and the Languedoc region, southern France.

name: Suva Planina, Serbia
remarks:
Abstract ref. 2029:
Reef limestones of the Suva Planina region and similar organic limestones of eastern Serbia, Yugoslavia, represent continuous sedimentation from Tithonian (Jurassic) to Valanginian (Cretaceous) time. Two types can be distinguished--reef deposits and lateral equivalents formed in deeper waters. Transgression was widespread, and deposition of thick sequences of limestone was due to gradual subsidence of the depositional basin during epeirogenic crustal movements.

name: Suva Planina, Serbia
remarks: See reef 2918

name: Crimea Mountains
remarks:
algal-coral bioherms, 2.5-8 m thick, 2.5-6 m across, 3-10 m distance between bioherms

Abstract ref. 2031:
Biostromal structures have been identified in the upper Valanginian and lower Hauterivian (lower Cretaceous) deposits along the Crimean mountains (USSR). The structures have been formed by scleractinians, algae, and rarely by hydrozoans. Reef facies first appeared during the upper Oxfordian (upper Jurassic) and northward migration of some 25-30 km continued until the Hauterivian. The migration was influenced by tectonic movements and uplift of Kimmerian massifs.

name: Sabana Grande, SW Puerto Rico
remarks:
Part of abstract of ref. 2032:
The structurally low Yauco basin began to receive volcanic rocks, clastic rocks, olistostromes, and olistoliths in Maastrichtian time. Campanian reefs which had grown on the uplifted Jurassic crust slid northward into the basin. Emplacement of reefal debris and olistoliths was synchronous with volcanism and uplift. These processes suggest proximity to submarine volcanoes, possibly in a deforming forearc basin. Surficial exposures of mantle rocks are probably the result of structural inversion of the basin in response to contraction in the currently active east-trending left-lateral fault system.

name: Porcupine Basin, offshore Ireland, Atlantic
remarks:
Reefs buried under 30 m of sediment. No age control. 

Abstract ref. 2033:
During a recent cruise in the Porcupine Basin, off southwest Ireland, we discovered two extensive and hitherto largely unsuspected deep-water reef provinces, including a giant cluster of hundreds of buried mounds. The ring shapes of many reefs suggest that they are caused by an axial fluid expulsion at the sea bed, a transient flow well confined in space and time. We are exploring various hypotheses, but a stimulating avenue for research is opened by a glacially controlled growth pulse and subsequent decay of a shallow layer of gas hydrates as a methane buffer and probably indirectly as a ground for overlying biological communities.

name: Sendurai, Tamil Nadu
remarks:
Maastrichtian or most likely Danian age based on Hercoglossa danicus. 
However, Orbitoides minor is also present suggesting Maastrichtian age.

Corals and bryozoans

Quotation from ref. 2034: The common fossils in this limestone are corals, polyzoans, lamellibranchs and gastropods. The corals are mostly compound and are often so massive and abundant that one is tempted to consider the rock a coral limestone.

name: Lindi
remarks:
Chain of reef knolls overlying sandy detrital limestone.
No description

name: Lindi
remarks:
Sandy reef limestone and marls.
Reef facies suggested by ostracodes. No description.

name: Lindi
remarks: See reef 2926

name: Kitunda Cliff, Lindi
remarks:
Massive, mostly sandy reef limestone surrounded by grey buff clay.
No description of reef facies.

name: Drake Island, Glacier Bay National Park, Alaska
remarks:
Platform margin reef


Abstract ref. 2036:
In Glacier Bay, Alaska, Silurian limestones record the development and demise of a stromatolite reef complex in the Alexander terrane. These microbial deposits are of regional and paleontological significance because they contain paleogeographically distinctive biotas and yield important insights into Phanerozoic stromatolites that inhabited normal-marine subtidal environments. Willoughby limestones exposed on Drake Island reveal that stromatolite growth at the platform margin influenced platform dynamics with the protection of peritidal and lagoonal habitats behind a reef-fringed rim, which experienced early lithification by the precipitation of synsedimentary marine cements. Relatively low-energy subtidal conditions in a restricted, shallow-marine lagoon are implied by the peloidal and mollusk-rich wackestones, packstones, and grainstones. At the platform margin, stromatolite boundstones and cementstones capped a reef-like mound by forming a thick microbial-cement crust on a core of outer lagoonal sediments. Well laminated, fenestral mudstones and peloidal wackestones-grainstones have an abrupt lateral contact with the microbial boundstones, indicating their formation in peritidal flats adjacent to the stromatolite reefs. Foreslope breccias consist of clasts derived from shallow subtidal environments on the shelf and at its rim. Cyclic repetition of these deposits indicate that sea level fluctuations and tectonic instability in the Alexander terrane contributed to periodic shedding of shallow-marine detritus to the upper slope, followed by the rebuilding of stromatolite reefs at the platform margin. Culminating stages in the Klakas orogeny induced large-scale, catastrophic collapse of the carbonate platform. Silurian stromatolites characterized by similar habitats and microbial-sponge biotas in southwestern Alaska and the Ural Mountains, Russia, together with paleomagnetic data, detrital zircon evidence, and the timing of late-stage Caledonide events, firmly establish genetic and temporal links of the Alexander terrane with other areas along the Uralian Seaway.

name: Loudon, Knoxville, Tennessee
remarks: Southwestermost extension of reef tract. See reef 2463 for remarks.

name: Lakeside Mountains, Utah
remarks:
Thrombolitic and stromatolitic mounds (pinch and swell structures).

Abstract ref. 2040:
Stromatolites have been recognized as opportunistic disaster forms following the end-Permian mass extinction. This occurrence was attributed to the partial relaxation of ecological constraints in the aftermath of the mass extinction. A similar pattern occurs in the Great Basin following the Late Ordovician mass extinction in association with a shift to low-diversity, generalized faunas.

Most Late Ordovician-Silurian faunal communities in the Great Basin are diverse and limited to relatively narrow environmental zones. Thin (10-20 cm thick) stromatolites occur throughout the section within inner-shelf tidal-flat facies. After the mass extinction, earliest Silurian (Rhuddanian) communities are broadly distributed with low diversity. Associated stromatolitic and thrombolitic mounds increase in abundance and reach a thickness of 2.5 meters. Bootstrapping analysis suggests the restriction of thick mounds to the post-extinction interval is non-random (probability <0.5%).

The widespread shelf stromatolites and thrombolites of the early Paleozoic declined, probably because their habitat was disrupted by the evolving Paleozoic Evolutionary Fauna. By mid-Ordovician, stromatolites and thrombolites were small and restricted to marginal, inner-shelf environments. They temporarily regained prominence in the aftermath of the Late Ordovician and end-Permian mass extinctions. In the earliest Silurian, shelf communities were undifferentiated in the long (3-4 MY) aftermath of the mass extinction. Thick stromatolites and thrombolites disappeared when diversity increased and differentiated communities were re-established. This patterns suggests animals that were suppressing stromatolites and thrombolites were reduced or absent after mass extinctions.

name: Lost Springs, Nevada
remarks:
Stromatolitic bioherms.
No bioherms in shallow water. 
Abstract of ref. 2041:
Most of what is known about the biotic recovery from the end-Permian mass extinction has been recovered from strata deposited in shallow-water environments. Yet, properties of the deep-ocean have been invoked as causes for the mass extinction as well as the unusually prolonged biotic recovery from this crisis. A nearshore to shelf transect of the Lower Triassic Virgin/Schnabkaib Limestones of the Moenkopi Formation (southern Nevada) was studied for changes in facies types and biofabrics as well as comparison with the coeval outer slope to deep basin Union Wash Formation (eastern California).

A number of biofabric trends were documented across this transect. Vertical burrows are common in nearshore strata, while horizontal burrows are prevalent in shelf strata. Intervals with relatively high ichnofabric indices (ii 4-5) are more common in shelf than nearshore strata. The most intriguing biofabric trend is the lack of microbial structures, such as stromatolites, in the most nearshore section, with their greatest occurrence found in shelf strata. This anachronistic onshore-offshore trend of stromatolitic development points to offshore and oceanic environments as a likely influence on their formation. Presence of seafloor carbonate cements in coeval slope and deep basin Union Wash strata, implying an offshore presence of water masses supersaturated in calcium carbonate, suggests that unusual ocean chemistry may have played a significant role in the development of Early Triassic shelfal stromatolites.

name: Mfamosing quarry 2
remarks:
Stromatolite 'bodies' in subtidal low energy environment.
Three horizons in succession.
Substantial borings by Lithophaga.

Fringing coral reefs.

name: Binanga, Karangmumus, Borneo

Limestone horizon III
Coral fringning reefs in 'Glanzkohlengruppe'.
Together with small Lepidocyclina and Miogysina polymorpha.

name: Binanga, Karangmumus, Borneo
remarks:
Limestone horizons IV and V. About 700 m under horizon III.
Locality W34.
Two coral beds separated by 40 m of sandstones. 
'Glanzkohlengruppe'

Goniopora, Cyathoseris, Leptoseris, Metastraea, Symphyllia.

Coral fringing reefs.

Sekoerau locality is probably identical and has 15 coral species according to ref. 2418.

name: Basleo, Timor
remarks:
Prolific coral faunas, mostly solitary rugosans but also severals favositid, auloporid and trachypsammid tabulates (Favosites, Pachypora).
Borings indicated on plates and mentioned in plate captions. Probable sponge borings in Trachypsammia.
Mostly reworked coral material in tuffaceous marls.
Corals obviously associated with abundant siliceous sponges and bryozoans.

name: Obi

Position!

name: Southern Novaya Zemlya

name: Admiral Bay Fault, Canning Basin
remarks:
Primary reef framework of domical and digitate stromatolites. Flanking deposits are bryozoan and palmatozoan grainstones and packstones.

From Webby:
Localized stratigraphically within the Goldwyer Formation, of probable early-mid Darriwilian age, and occupy restricted sites immediately adjacent to a major, intra-basinal fault zone (Admiral Bay Fault Zone). Four separate occurrences of these linear-shaped, microbial-dominated reefs are recorded along the main Admiral Bay fault line over a distance of 16 km. They vary from 500 m wide and 330 m thick to 200 m wide and 25 m thick, and at least one is more than 1 km in length. The reefs exhibit a primary reef framework of domical and digitate stromatolites. Flanking deposits are bryozoan and pelmatozoan grainstones, and packstones. The fault system which defines the northeastern margin of the Willara Sub-basin, was apparently active intermittently through Early-Middle Ordovician time. McCracken et al. (1996) suggested that uplift of the footwall side of the main fault produced a narrow, raised, linear belt along the line of the fault, providing suitable shallower depositional conditions for localized reefal growth. The timing of uplift is possibly early Darriwilian. These reefal masses were subsequently fractured by renewed phases of faulting that facilitated movement of mineralizing solutions and extensive alternation of the host rocks, with the emplacement of the Mississippi Valley-type, lead-zinc mineralization.

Abstract of re. 2094:
Carnian reef biota and brachiopods of the Misfah Formation (Hawasina complex) from a locality near the town of Al Aqil in Oman are described. A new brachiopod species, Oxycolpella arabica n. sp. is described. The composition of the Carnian reef biota in Oman is similar to those known from the Alpine-Mediterranean region. However, differences exist in the microfauna of reef dwellers, e.g. foraminifers. New stratigraphic data based on reef organisms and conodonts are presented.

name: Off SW Florida, Gulf of Mexico
Erd-Diosd, Budapest
remarks:
Corals, coralline algae, diverse bryozoans, microbes.
Bioclastic debris without corals and algae

The first visible level of the reefal unit is formed
by coralline algal thickets associated with a number of coral colonies belonging to the scleractinian
genera Porites and Tarbellastraea. The overlying
unit exhibits more distinctive reef features through
the presence of metric-sized coral patches and
scattered coral colonies. Two different growth
forms of Porites occur (possibly two species): one
with densely packed finger-thick branches, the
other partly massive, partly ramose (often within
the same colony), with branches about 5-10 cm
thick. Coral constructions also contain globular to
ramose colonies of Tarbellastraea with frequent
Lithophaga borings. Thin Porites colonies domi-nate
near the top of the reefal unit. Scleractinian
colonies and mollusc shells (especially bivalves)
are often invaded by a network of boring sponges
corresponding to the ichnogenus Entobia. Among
the samples from Dio'sd, Oosterbaan (1990)
identified the following scleractinian species:
Porites collegniana, Tarbellastraea reussiana, and
Siderastraea crenulata.

Coralline algae also play a major role in the
construction of the framework. They encrust the
surface of coral colonies with up to centimetre-
thick sheaths around thin Porites colonies, or give
rise to bushy outgrowths. Coralline algae are some-
times also associated with bryozoan crusts.
1

The amount of siliciclastic material decreases upward, and at a distinct masses of red algae appear as encrustations covering an area of some 100 m2, possibly a hardground (which is not exposed). Upon parts of this algal build-up coral colonies occur, and locally become dominant (Müller, 1984). The algal-coral build-up is capped by a pebbly horizon and no further beds are exposed here. Further to the NW, a possibly coeval slightly clayey limestone contains abundant Turritella moulds, probably deposited in a sublittoral setting. The transition zone between the build-up and clayey limestone is not exposed. The clayey limestone is covered by a calcarenite ( Müller, 1984),partly grainstone, partly wackestone,with some faunal evidence for slightly decreased salinity.

name: Wangjiaping, Yichang, Hubei
remarks:
Tianheban epoch
33% archaeocyaths but only one genus
Abstract of ref. 2127:
The limestone of the Tianheban Formation on the Yangtze Gorges belongs to open shelf marine deposit in middle Early Cambrian age. Two distinct types of archaeocyath reefs are preserved - an isolated archaeocyath mud mound, and a patch reef. The reefs are composed of irregular archaeocyathids and calcified microbial microfossils such as Epiphyton, Renalcis, Givanella, etc., belonging to baffling reef mounds. The patch reef succession shows the hydrodynamic changing from low energy to moderately high energy, and then to a low energy environment.

name: NE Amadeus Basin, Northern Territory
remarks:
Abstract or ref. 2129:
Two distinct types of archaeocyathan buildups occur within the Lower Cambrian Todd River Dolomite: a high energy, intemittently emergent, bioherm and grainstone reef-shoal (30-50m thick), and low energy open-shelf bioherms and patch reefs up to 8m thick and 20m across. The primary fabric of these buildups has been largely destroyed by dolomitisation. Facies relationships indicate that high and low energy buildups are temporal equivalents, and that the high energy reef-shoal now present in the N'Dhala Thrust Sheet was flanked to the east and south by a low energy shelf studded with bioherms and patch reefs. The reef-shoal was capped locally by microbial mudflats. The best potential for hydrocarbon accumulations appears to be local open-shelf buildups draped by thick halite deposits in autochthonous and para-autochthonous areas.

name: Lost Cabin, Spring Mountains, Nevada
remarks:
Stromatolitic mounds in normal marine environment.
Maximum thickness 2 m (= syndepositional relief).
Virgin Member of Moenkopi Fm.

Ref 2184: These microbial structures from the Virgin Limestone Member of the Moenkopi Formation have been recently reinvestigated to determine if they represent true reefs. In places microbial mounds occur as isolated patch reefs, although elsewhere they coalesce to form tabular biostromes. These mounds are an agglomeration of smaller subunits that have wavy laminations and thrombolitic textures. Measurements on isolated mounds show that they attained a relief of 1-2 meters above the seafloor.

Partial abstract of ref. 2181:
Sedimentary facies in the Carboniferous part of the Omi Limestone are generally highly diverse, but their diversity varies in each age. The Upper Carboniferous part consists of highly diversified facies including fore reef, reef front, reef crest, sand shoal, and lagoon facies, while a simple facies assemblage, composed only of fore reef, reef front, and sand shoal facies, occurs in the Lower Carboniferous.

 The first phase, comprising the coral-bryozoan-crinoid community, occurs in the Endothyra spp. Zone to the Eostaffella kanmerai Zone (Visean to Serpukhovian).

Also associates with some chaetetids and other sponges (sphinctozoans/inozoans). 
Taisyakphyllum and Pseudopavona dominant
Second reef phase in Omi Limestone, represented by the problematic skeletal organism-microencruster community, is developed in the Millerella sp. Zone to the Akiyoshiella ozawai Zone (Bashkirian to lowermost Moscovian),

name: SW Virginia
remarks:
Bioherms are 30 cm to 1.5 m high and range from club-shaped heads 30 cm to 2 m in diameter to coalescent forms 10 m wide. Bioherms consist of branching digitate stromatolite columns (1 cm wide, 2 to 4 cm high), lesser sponge and calcareous algae, and interstitial carbonate mudstone and skeletal wackestone.

Bioherms overlie flat-pebble breccias that are underlain by ripple-laminated shaly-pellet limestone and interbedded breccia lenses and sheets. Shaly limestones locally overlie fossiliferous marine shale. Bioherms are overlain by ripple-laminated shaly-pellet limestone that also fills interbioherm depressions, and locally by ooid grainstone sheets (up to 8 m thick).

Includes Linde klint hill locality to the west

name: Waukesha County, Wisconsin
remarks: Very fossiliferous. This is a typical Wenlockian carbonate mud mound community, in which the core contains mostly carbonate mud, sometimes with Stromatactis-like structures, and echinoderm debris and the flank beds are echinoderm-dominated. Skeletal grains in the flank beds which contain this community can be either moldic or dolomite-replaced, and the texture ranges from non-cherty, porous dolowackestone to dolopackstone, with some grainstone present also in the flank facies, to crystalline dolomudstones and sparse dolowaxkestone to dolopackstone, with some grainstone present also in the flank facies, to crystalline dolomudstones and sparse dolowackestones in the cores. Skeletal grains show the full range from well to poorly sorted, and some graded bedding is present in the inclined beds of the echinoderm facies. Corals, which tend to surround the mound core, are sometimes overturned (Philcox, 1970), and in any case, are not abundant enough to form an organic framework. As noted by Witzke (1981b, 1987b), the general absence of skeletal boundstone fabrics precludes interpretation as an organic-framework reef, but the presence of apparent penecontemporaneous cave and fissure-fills in the core, often with thick trilobite or nautiloid concentrations, plus wedge-shaped debris flows in some facies, suggests that the mounds were rigid features, possibly resulting from submarine cementation processes (Witzke, 1987a). Dolomitized botryoidal and fibrous marine cembents are present. Sedimentary features are consistent with episodic high-energy conditions, such as would result from storm action in depths generally at or slightly below fair weather wave base.

name: Central Carnic Alps
remarks:
Mounds with cystoid crinozoans and trepostome bryozoans.
Position unclear.

Normalograptus extraordinarius graptolite zone

Abstract of ref. 2275:
The Late Ordovician stratal succession in the Carnic Alps, an area that lay at about 50 degrees south latitude in the Ordovician, includes bioclastic carbonates derived from reefs. Two distinct facies have been distinguished in the Carnic Alps Late Ordovician succession: an inner shelf, Wolayer, facies and an outer shelf-upper slope, Uggwa, facies. Wolayer facies carbonates are massive, structureless, and accumulated as reefs which developed as thickets of crinozoans, primarily cystoids, and trepostome bryozoans. Cystoid calices are common at some sites. Conodonts, chitinozoans and trilobites are present in the reef rocks. These crinozoan-bryozoan reefs developed in relatively shallow-shelf, subtidal environments. Reef-derived detritus was swept downslope from time to time to accumulate in a sequence of graded debris flows in deep shelf-upper slope settings. These carbonate clast debris flows are a characteristic component of the Uggwa facies. Siliclastics subjacent to the Uggwa carbonates bear Rawtheyian shelly faunas. Blocks within cross-bedded sandstones and siltstones superjacent to Uggwa carbonates bear Hirnantia faunas. Persculptograptus persculptus and Mucronaspis occur in interbedded silty shales. Correlations based on faunas in strata subjacent and superjacent to the carbonates indicate that the reefs developed during the Normalograptus extraordinarius graptolite zone. Late Ordovician glaciation on Gondwana occurred during that zone. Siliclastics are absent from the reefs and reef-derived carbonates. If the source for the siliclastics was a portion of Gondwana, then reef development during glaciation suggests that the reef-building organisms were permitted to grow because the reef sites were not impacted by fluxes of siliclastics. The abundance of crinozoans and bryozoans suggests that small plankton were plentiful and nutrient availability high.

name: Cody, Indian Pass Triangle, Wyoming
remarks:
Thrombolite patch reefs in mixed carbonate-evaporitic sequence (restricted inner ramp setting).
Part of abstract of ref. 2353: The observed buildups are approximately 3 meters across and 1 meter thick. Each buildup is composed of circular 'heads' of layered microbialite with an internal clotted texture (i.e. thrombolite). Individual heads are approximately 0.5 meters in diameter and 0.25 meters thick. Environmental interpretations of these microbial buildups suggest that they developed in shallow water (< 1 meter water depth).
As many Jurassic thrombolite reefs discussed in the literature have been interpreted to have developed in deep-water settings, examination of these well-exposed Wyoming reefs provides important contributions to extend the distribution of thrombolite reefs into shallow-water environments.

name: Arrow Canyon Range, Clark Co., Nevada
remarks:
Reef from old Trempelauan

Lithistid sponges prevailint (Lee pers. comm. 2023)

A sponge-microbialite reef horizon occurs in the upper Cambrian (Millardan) strata of the Arrow Canyon Range, Clark County, Nevada. This horizon represents one of the few metazoan reefs occurring between the extinction of the Archaeocyathids at the end of the early Cambrian and the proliferation of Calathium-sponge-microbialite reefs in the late early Ordovician.

Good exposures of the reefs occur discontinuously on the western slopes of the Arrow Canyon Range. Uneven dolomitization obscures some reef structures while creating patches of well-preserved reef rock that are up to 15 m thick by 50 m wide. Some dolomitic intervals between reef mounds reveal faint reef-like textures and structures, therefore the shape and extent of the original reef(s) is uncertain. The interval may have extended into the overlying dolostone and the original reef may have formed distinct mounds larger than 50 m wide, or a single continuous biostrome over the 8 km exposure. 

The reef(s) show an ecological succession from basal-domal stromatolites (0.5 m wide, 1 m tall) to digitate stromatolites (5-20 cm wide, 10-20 cm high), a core of sponge-thromolite reef (3-7 m thick), and a cap layer of columnar stromatolites (20 cm w., 1-2 m h.) with attached and detrital sponges between the columns. Sponges in the core have thin walls (1-2 mm), and are broadly conical to bowl-like in shape, (5-10 cm w/h). They form a closely packed framework that is in-situ with pendent microbialites; Renalcis and Epiphyton. 

Age determination is currently supported by 4 conodont collections from strata underlying the reef through the reef core. Strata below the reef have Proconodontus muelleri and are assigned to that zone. Eoconodontus notchpeakensis occurs in the stromatolitic base and indicates the E. notchpeakensis Subzone of the Eoconodontus Zone. Palaeobotryllus taylori, also from the Eoconodontus Zone, occurs in the core.

name: Wadi Ashkar, South Galala
remarks:
Coral patch reefs in zones SBZ3 and basal SBZ4.
Data from sections A5 and K3b.  the reefal limestone is composed of three depositional facies. These depositional facies are from base to top: 1) fore-reef facies, consists of hard, massive, marly coralline limestone with low diverse, small isolated corals heads, 2) reef-core facies, which consists of very hard, bioturbated coralline limestone with exclusively huge coral colonies of Porites and Tarbellastraea spp. and, 3) back reef facies, consists of sandy to pebbly massive, bioturbated limestone with very low diverse, scattered, small dendroid and massive heads of corals. The studied reefal limestone was deposited in fore-reef framework in an open marine environment with moderate to high energy conditions and changed upward to shallow marine facies with accumulation of skeletal grains by storms during regression.

name: Gavu Fm., Mushgai
remarks: For the Silurian, four reef-complexes were investigated. They are situated as lens bodies within crinoid limestones. The lenses are 150-250 cm long and 80-150 cm tall. The composition of fossils is repeated in each lens: Stromatoporoidea, Tabulatoidea, Favositida, Thamnoporida, Bryozoa, Crinoidea, Algae, rare Heliolitoidea, solitary Rugosa and Brachiopoda. The dominate taxa are Stromatoporoidea and Tabulatoidea (Favositida) with a variety of colonies: laminar, hemispheric, spheric, massive. The dimensions of the colonies varied from 2-3 to 20-30 cm across. The laminar and incrusting colonies dominated the periphery of the reef-complexes; the hemispheric, spheric and columnar dominated the central parts, where the colonies were large in size.

name: Sharchuluut Fm., Shine-Jinst
remarks: See reef 3360. Details from poster at exhibit.

name: Orgol Fm., Mushgai
remarks: It forms a biostrome that is 5 m height and 1000 m long. The bottom 1.5 m consists of small lenses of crowding Thamnoporida. Some of lenses are 10 m long, and they rise up to 20-40 cm in the center. The upper 1.5 m of the biostrome consists of lenses full of Thamnoporida as well. In the middle part of the biostrome, there are massive colonies of Stromatoporoidea and Favositida with Thamnoporoida in the interstices. The following taxa were also found in the biostrome: brachiopods, single trilobites, solitary and fragments of massive colonies of Rugose, Crinoidea and Algae.

This bed is interpreted as a low-relief mud-mound deposited on the Middle Jurassic depositional slope in quite deep-water environments.
