remarks:
Age indicated as Namurian E-G by conodonts.
Mound surrounded by shales. Interpreted as cold-seep mound

name: Kuh-e Bagh-e Vang, Shotori Mountains
remarks:
Age indicated as Uralian (Kungurian).
Reefal boulders described as sponge-Tubiphytes-Archaeolithoporella-boundstones. Only sponges described. Microbial micrite evident from thin sections.

name: Manosque, Alpes de Haute-Provence
remarks: Paleontological description of bivalves, gastropods and echinoids.

name: Caracoles, Antofagasta
remarks: Coral patch reefs

name: Großmehring near Ingolstadt, Southern Frankenalb
remarks:
Dolomitic reef facies. 
Only bivalves described in detail.

name: Vadi-Bala, Tapsa River basin, Tuva
remarks:
Two reefal bands:
1. Limestones, dolomitized, massive, archaeeocyathit-algal, white, gray or cherry-red, and also limestone breccias and bioherms with archaeocyathids, which are evenly distributed through the band.

2. Tuffs, tuffites, and more rarely dacite porphyries of dirty-brown, gray or greenish-gray color, with lenses of algal and archaeocyathid-algal-limestones, massive and dolomitized.

name: Beroun, Prague Basin
remarks: No description of reef facies

name: Sabkhat Lafayrina, Samara, Western Sahara
remarks:
Distinct vertical zonation. Coral beds (Philippsastrea), small stromatoporoids, large stromatoporoids (up to 3 m in diameter).
Six reef cycles separated by ref. 2488. Data refer to fourth cycle, which is the thickest (up to 50 m?).
Included are data from third reef cycle

name: Gavdos Island, South Greece
remarks:
11 coral species from 6 small outcrops.
Corals from marls, thought to be inner part of atoll reef structure.
Minor bioerosion evident on pictures.

name: Urushten River, Caucasus
remarks: Only brachiopods are described

name: Gefo Mountain, Caucasus
remarks: Only brachiopods described

name: Arrondissement of Mirebalais
remarks: Reefal limestone indicated. No detailed description.

name: Pisang reef, dredge 403, Licupara Block
remarks:
Dredge sample said to be early to late Oligocene and estimated to be 30 Ma.
Dissolved corals with thick red algal and foram incrustations; plenty of micrite; some quartz.

name: Drab-Beavertown, Blair County, Pennsylvania
remarks: Microbial reefs, rich in trilobites

name: Dyminy reef, Grabina, Kielce, Holy Cross Mts.
remarks: Only gastropods reported. More data in Racki (1993) $

name: Xintan, Hubei
remarks: bigger patch reefs 4 m thick and 15 m wide, smaller reefs 0.5 m thick and 1 m wide, bryozoan framestones in the lower part of the reef core, sponges and Calathium as main reef builders in the upper part of the reef core.Slice change (was Arenig before)

name: Mt. Ptoon, Marmeiko, Booetia
remarks: Three stacked biostromes form complex

name: Treskelen, Hornsund, Spitzbergen
remarks:
Treskelodden beds ranging from Gzhelian to early Sakamarian. Most coral rich horizons probably Asselian.
Corals mostly in clast. Reefal nature uncertain

name: Diebu, S Gansu
remarks: Some patch reefs of tabulate/rugose corals and stromatoporoids

name: Katuura area, Tokushima
remarks: Reef blocks with tabulate corals

name: Dobrogoszczyce, Polish Jura
remarks: Siliceous sponges described but presence of 15 coral genera noted

name: Birow + Dymnik + Niegowonice + Wysoka, Polish Jura
Livadia + Perakhorion, Helicon Mountains, Boeotia
remarks: Reefal debris as boulders

name: Sienna, Roznow, Stramberk blocks in flysch
remarks: Reefal blocks in flysch

name: Ai-Petri, Crimea
remarks:
650 m thick reefal complex with coral-stromatoporoid patch reefs, stromatoporoid-Lithocodium patch reefs, packstones, grainstones, calcareous sponges, Tubiphytes and foraminifera.
Age poorly constrained between late Kimmeridgian and Berriasian. Bulk of reef is probably Tithonian. Two reefs added to give double weight to Tithonian.

name: Ai-Petri II, Crimea
remarks: See reef 3442

name: Nzala, High Atlas
remarks:
Mud mound in upper member of Idikel Fm.
Lower part of upper Sinemurian.

name: Jebel Tamesmida, Kasserine
remarks:
Two rudist reef horizons marked as bafflestones. Douleb member of the Aleg Formation.
Reefs sensu stricto are made up of rudists (Hippuritidae and Radiolitidae) and they show a height:lateral extension ratio of about 1:50.

name: Oued Saquia Al Hamra, West Sahara
remarks:
Sixth reef cycle 
'We interpret this buildup as an erosional remnant
of a larger patch reef or biostrome.'
Only rugose and tabulate corals mentioned.

name: Jebel Azroual, Midelt
remarks:
Coral patch reefs with hexactinellid siliceous sponges (''lithistids?'').
Extension of second reef cycle

name: Tazigzaout, Rich
remarks:
Third reef cycle. Upper member of Tazigzaout Fm.
late Bajocian-Bathonian.

name: Chargey-lès-Port
remarks:
Coral-microbialite reefs with up to 70% microbialite.
7 reef units. Four basal bioherm, three upper biostrome

name: Kunigami-misaki, Okierabu-jima, lower unit
remarks:
Ages only broadly constrained between 900 and 400 ka.
Two reefal units, arbitrarly assigned to 800 and 500 ka.
Taxonomic data for coral (genus level) and red algae (species level). Incomplete!

name: Toku-no-shima, Unit 1
remarks: Data refer to coral limestone of unit 1

name: Yoron-jima, Unit 1
remarks: Equivalent to unit 1 on Toku-no-shima

name: Ahmetler, Antalya Basin
remarks: Thickest reef in the area grown at shelf margin

name: Walker Flat, Padthaway Ridge, South Australia
remarks:
Upper Member of NW Bend Fm.
Monospecific oyster bioherms (Ostrea angasi) and biostromes in marginal marine setting.

name: Stepanow Creek, Ellesmere Island, Nunavut
remarks: Bryozoan mounds of Atokan age (late Bashkirian-early Moscovian)

name: S2 Gold Point, Esmeralda Co., Nevada
remarks:
Archaecyath bioherms with Renalcis and coralomorphs.
Composition: 
7% archaeocyaths
24% Renalcis
4.5% coralomorphs (calcitic)
36% lime mud
12.6% cement
10% quartz sand

name: Yatton, Bristol, England
remarks:
Thrombolite-Ortonella reefs, originally deposited as biostromes. In beds up to a meter in thickness. Mound-like structures also present. 

This comprising the sites: Yatton, Backwell, Flax Bourton and Avon Gorge.

Restricted lagoonal setting inferred.

name: Chipping Sodbury, Bristol, England
remarks:
This comprising sites: Wick and Chippind Sodbury
See also reef 3463

name: Cerros de la Proveedora, Sonora
remarks:
cryptalgal boundstones and oncoidal wackestone-packstone and ooid grainstone
probably formed subtidally above storm wavebase
trilobites and echinoderms reported to be present, but not listed

name: Pwepon Hill, Myanmar
remarks: Dolomitic biostrome

name: Lake Champlain region, Vermont
remarks:
small mounds up to 3 m in diameter, separated by bedded calcarenites
The mounds contain chiefly stromatoporoids, corals and bryozoans but sponges and algae are also common.

name: Arnold Ranch, USNM700g, Glass Mountains
remarks: Small bioherms with sponges, rugose corals and many silicified brachiopods

name: Wolfcamp Hills, Glass Mountains
remarks:
Uddenites shale member
limestone beds with shaly intervals; possibly of biohermal origin but not expressed as a mound

name: Old Word Ranch, Hess Ranch, Glass Mountains, Texas
remarks: Bioherms at base of Road Canyon Formation. Lower part of Road Canyon Formation contains conodont Mesogondolella idahoensis lamberti, indicating Kungurian age according to Henderson & Mei (2003).

name: St. Corneli, Tremp, Cataluna
remarks:
Coniacian to lower Santonian.
Rudist bioconstruction

name: St. Corneli, Tremp, Cataluna
remarks: 25 rudist species listed. Corals mentioned but not described

name: Wadi Bani Kharus, N Jebel Akhdar
remarks: Rudist Unit, 24 m thick

name: Pietrasecca, Carseolani Mountains
remarks: Nine rudist species constructing biostrome

name: Ferdows reef, Taher-Abad, Tabas area
remarks:
Biostromes were formed mainly by corals and subordinate sponges.
Collection contains sponges only

name: Oyonnax and Hauteville areas, sponge bioherms
remarks: Transversarium zone sponge-microbial mounds

name: Demascota well, Nova Scotia
remarks: Coral-sponge reef at shelf margin

name: Moinho de Cotovio, Faro, Peral Beds
Amendoeira, Faro
remarks: Small lagoonal patch reefs

name: Santa Catarina area, Algarve
remarks: Coral biostromes with many bivalves in a lagoonal envrionment

name: Cerro de Sao Miguel, Faro
remarks: Marly limestones with coral-stromatoporoid biostromes

name: Lagoa de Santo Andre, S-104, Setubal
remarks: Calcisponges, corals and Tubiphytes

name: Baltow I, N Holy Cross Mountains
remarks: Early upper Oxfordian coral biostromes

name: Bukova, S Holy Cross Mountains
remarks:
Coral-algal (solenoporacean) reefs with nerineid gastropods
Includes Brzegi, Sokolow

name: Kodrab, W Holy Cross Mountains
remarks: Only described as coral limestone

name: Pulau Bayur, Tembesi River Basin, Jambi
remarks: Described as coral-calcisponge mud-mounds

name: Asai River, Tembesi River Basin, Jambi
Sungaimanau, Tembesi River Basin, Jambi
remarks: Incomplete description, diversity unclear

name: Tapaktuan II, Aceh, Sumatra
remarks: Mud mounds according to ref. 2105

name: Jebel Bou Arhous Srhir, Atlas
remarks: Lotharingian, Oxynotum zone

name: Jebel Tagount, Atlas
remarks: Small hextinellid sponge bioherms

name: Draga, Kocevje area, Dinaric Platform
remarks: Small patch reefs behind barrier reef tract

name: Korinj, Ribnica area, Dinaric Platform
remarks: Small coral patch reefs in back-reef lagoon

name: Novo Mesto area, Dinaric Platform
remarks: Inner and outer barrier reef

name: Postojna area, barrier reef, Dinaric Platform
remarks: Inner barrier reef

name: Trnovski gozd, Dinaric Platform
remarks:
Inner barrier reef
Comprising Selovec and Otlica localities

name: Slovenski vrh, Kocevje area
remarks: Coral patch reef in the back-reef area on the Dinaric Platform

name: Lipica, Slovenian Karst
remarks: Rudist-coral patch reefs and biostromes

name: Perbla, Zadlascica Valley
remarks: Upper Julian-Tuvalian well cemented dark grey reef limestone blocks and fragments which passes into reef breccia in the upper part

name: Mt. Razor area, Northern Julian Alps
remarks: Reef thickness from up 150 m to up to 300 m

name: Parador, Sierra de Cazorla, Jaen, Andalucia
remarks: Micritic limestone with corals, stromatoporoids and nerineid gastropods

name: Kuybyshevo, Belbek River, Crimea
remarks: bioherm with hydrozoans as the main reef builders

name: Beshterek, Simferopol area, Crimea
remarks: reef of unkown compositin. Crinoids described

name: Tonas River (Alekseyevka and Krasnoselovka), Crimea
remarks: small bioherms in the clays and sandstones

name: La Grosse Romaine Island, Quebec
remarks: Sainte-Genevieve member dolomitic,stromatolitic lithified wackestone small anthaspidellid bioherms

name: La Hermida, Cantabria
remarks: single .1m diameter bryozoan reef block, 50 standard thin sections were prepared

name: San Sebastian, Puerto Rico
remarks:
Formation is late Oligocene to early Miocene; crabs are from early Miocene based on Miosorites americanus
indurated, very pale orange, fine to medium grained calcarenite stratified in beds 10 cm to 1 m thick

name: Totara area, South Island
remarks: Reef founded on a volcanic sea mount rising abrupt from comparitively deep water to within reach of the sorting and winnowing action of waces and shallow enough to be colonized by polyzoans brachiopods and molluscs. Presumably bryozoan mound.

name: Serra Sbregavitelli, Matese Massif, S Apennines
remarks:
The top of the Late Aptian limestone sequence consists of a reef layer (0.5 to 2 m thick) with a calcarenitic and rarely calcilutitic matrix.
Dominated by Mathesia tertiicolloquiirudistarum. Some requienids

name: Goodsir Creek, Cornwallis Island, Nunavut
remarks: small mudmound and flanking crinoidal packstone

name: Hydra
remarks:
small sponge bioherm in middle shelf environment, wackestone matrix.
Rich associated fauna

name: Kruhel Wielki, Przemysl, Skole nappe
remarks:
exotic block within the Maastrichtian flysch sediments of the Skole
The limestones are the remnants of a reef or reef-like structure formed in a high-energy environment

name: Sarnia Skala, Maly Kopieniec, Carpathians
remarks: medium and thick-bedded limestones of grey or dark-bluish colour, intercalated with dark shales

name: Giewont, Kobylarz, Wysoka Turnia, Carpathians
remarks: light or grey colour, reef breccias, product of destruction of reef or reef-like structures

name: El Madrono (Laguna Colorada), Querétaro
remarks: W part of the Valles-San Luis Potosi Platform; El Abra Formation includes the Taninul facies (reefal environment at the margin of the platform) and the El Abra facies (lagoonal or back reef environment)

name: Analipsis (Sourpi), Boeotia
remarks: biostromes up to 2 m thick, exposed 10 m above the base of the section, and pseudocolonies (bouquets)

name: Makhtesh Ramon, Negev Desert
remarks:
lack, massive limestone reefs, formed by lamellibranchs
 Myalina ramanensis =  Ramonalina ramanensis

name: Rottnest Island
remarks:
coral-reef limestone and associated shelly limestone. Accumulated in a reefal setting in as many as a few metres of water depth.
Coralline algae encrust most of the corals, and contributed significantly as binding organisms in the reef framework; some shells are heavily encrusted and bound into the reef framework by coralline algae.
Dated by U/TH method as 132 ka

name: Catombal, Back Creek, N.S.W.
remarks:
Bioherms with stromatoporoids, tabulate corals (together 55% area), micobialites (13%). 32% are matrix and cements.
Microborings common, but no macroborings reported

name: Yass area, Canberra, N.S.W.
remarks:
Red algal-calcimicrobial-stromatoporoid bindstones.
Stachyodes as main reef builder
20% stromatoporoids, Rothpletzella (5%), Renalcis (5%), Wetheredella (2%) and Graticula-like red algae ( 1%) as encrusters. Stromatolites and Girvanella (1%) present. 

The conodont fauna,
obtained from the limestone lenses, includes
Icriodus woschmidti and indicates an early Gedinnian
age for the upper half of the formation
(Link & Druce, 1972). The underlying Cowridge
Siltstone is of Late Ludlovian to Pridolian age,
suggesting that the Elmside Formation ranges in
age from Late Pridolian to Early Gedinnian
(Pickett, 1982).

name: Benicàssim, El Molto, Maestrat Basin
remarks:
Microsolenid laminar framework reefs with stromatolitic crusts (with clotted micrite and microspar). Corals encrusted by coralline and peyssonneliacean red algae, encrusting foraminifers, and stromatolitic crusts.
Microbes 20% of reef volume. 
Burrows in semi-consolidated stromatolites interpreted as borings by me.
Microborings present

name: Sharyu River section, Chernyshev Ridge
remarks:
Microbial boundstone, stromatolite boundstone, peloidal limestone, interpreted to having formed under nutrient-rich conditions.
Starts in upper Frasnian but largely Famennian

name: Innisfail, Alberta
remarks:
Stromatoporoid shoal or reef flat, 
Stromatoporoid margin buildup, Margin-derived
debris
Producing reservoir since 1957

name: Orangeburg County, South Carolina
remarks:
Probably Lutetian
Offshore bryozoan mounds in nutrient-rich settings
Some oysters associated

name: Sierra Plomosa, Chihuahua
remarks:
late Wolfcampian-early Leonardian (Sakmarian-Artinskian) reef blocks in basinal sediments. 
Dominated by Tubiphytes
Sphaerocodium and platy algae present
Solenopora texana
Bryozoans
Girvanella, some sponges

name: Lambton County Pinnacle reefs, Ontario
remarks: Pinnacle reef belt of stromatoporoids and corals, capped by stromatolites

name: Akimiski Island, Hudson Bay, Nunavut
remarks:
Frame builders of the reefs are mainly stromatoporoids,
tabulate corals, and colonial rugose corals. Bryozoans and
calcareous demosponges, albeit common, are only minor
components volumetrically.
Rich brachiopod fauna associated.

name: Heart Lake, Great Slave Lake, N.W.T.
remarks:
Stromatoporoids slightly dominating. Outer ramp setting.
Reef complex #2 of ref. 2545
Borings limited to hardgrounds

name: Aramda Reef Member
remarks:
Late Pleistocene to Holocene coral reef with abundant rhodolites. 4 m thick.
Radiocarbon ages are 41.2 and 18.3 ky. Four reef units:
1. Coral framestone
2. Algal framestone
3. Coral bafflestone with algal debris
4. Rudstone with algal debris

name: Villafeliz, Leon, Asturia
remarks: bioherms with abundant sponge fossils.

name: Digerhuvud2, Gotland
remarks: reef core facies with thick tabular to domical stromatoporoids, cerioid-phaceloid rugose and massive to delicate ramose tabulate corals

name: Gran Bajo, Santa Cruz
remarks:
Oyster reefs (Crassostrea? hatcheri) in Gran Bajo member. Shells strongly bored and encrusted.
Reworked oysters also at other localities (probably also from reefs):
Meseta Chica, Gran Bajo, Nido deAguila, Seccion 5, La Colmena, Cabo Curioso.

name: Estancia 25 de Mayo, Santa Cruz
remarks: Crassostrea? hatcheri reefs

name: Sicakbük reef bouldes, Karaburun
remarks:
Solonepora and alga Aternasus seem to prevail. Additionally porostromate algae (=microbes), sponges and corals
The reef boulders, found in Sicakbük locality (Fig. 1) are
most probably Anisian in age. They contain different reef
organisms (e.g., sponges, corals, etc.) associated with algae
described in this paper. The samples were collected in
an outcrop (Anisian Gerence Formation, Koyutepe Unit of
Brinkmann et al. 1972, samples K1 and KAB)
about 12.5 km south of Mordogan.

name: Tahta Iskele, Karaburun
remarks:
Probably lower Norian reef of 150 m lateral extent.
Abundant microbial crusts associated with coralline sponges and corals

name: Benicàssim, El Molto, Maestrat Basin
remarks:
Platy coral reef with red algae (2%) and stromatolites.
Could be same reef as 3536

name: ENE of Xuyong, Sichuan Basin, Guizhou
remarks:
Exact position unclear.
Mud mounds with Stramatactis in open shelf environment, deeper water. Mound cores composed of clotter micrite.
Individual mound small but composite up to 35 m. Mound tops dolomitized

name: Longmenshan, Ganxi, Sichuan
remarks:
Position unclear. Stromatoporoids, rugose corals and tabulate corals indicated as reef builders. 2 reef intervals, each 2-3 m thick in highstand systems tract.
Distinct brachiopod community in reef (Clathrocoilona-Hexagonaria)

name: Bianping, Houchang, Ziyun, Guizhou
remarks:
Coral reef composed of rugose corals Fomichevella and microbes. Overlying phylloid algal reefs with Ivanovia cf. manchurica
Two reef bodies laterally separated by a fault.
Top of upper Carboniferous.

name: Kudirka atoll structure, Vilkaviskis
remarks:
Atoll-like reefal structure of 5 x 8 km in area and up to 88 m thickness. Described as stromatoporoid-crinoid reef. 60% of bulk rock are crinoids.
Reservoir quality reduced due to calcite cementation. 2-14% porosity

name: Camposilvano, Monti Lessini
remarks: age stated as Aalenian, but below middle Aalenian unconformity.

name: Muddy Mountains Overton locality
remarks:
Placunopsis bioherms in Virgin Limestone Member

The heights of the Placunopsis buildups range from 12 to 26 cm, with the majority of the bioherms attaining a height greater than 20 cm. The widths of the buildups range from about 0.5 to 1.5 m. Where exposure is continuous, distances between the centers of adjacent bioherms range from 1 to 1.5 m; adjacent bioherms do not appear to connect laterally.

name: Prayon, Vesdre area
remarks:
6.7 m-thick biostrome composed of laminar Alveolites-stromatoporoid bindstone with some Frechastraea.
The biostrome formed under or near the storm wave
base and was subjected to an input of limestone
sediments, perhaps triggered by storms (it will
be discussed later in the section devoted to the
biostromes).

name: La Mallieue
remarks:
The second unit is a 3.7 (Engis) to 4 m-thick (La Mallieue) coral biostrome sensu stricto. The rugose coral colonies are laminar, discoid, of various sizes, from a few centimetres to 70-80 cm in diameter (and possibly more).
The density of the frame builder can reach 90% of the rock; the matrix is a shale or a slightly argillaceous packstone more or less dolomitized.

name: Sierra Agua Verde, Sonora
remarks:
Equivalent to early late Moscovian (Podolskian) and fusulinid biozone A3.
Chaetetid reef mound with phylloid and other calcareous algae

name: Microconch reef, S of Liege
remarks: The framework of these small domal-shaped reefs was owing to microconchids and calcimicrobes (Garwoodia, Mitcheldeania).

name: Engihoul Quarry, Liege
remarks:
Local stage Livian (approximately Holkerian).
a massive lens (2 m high, 5 m across) composed of massive, dark
grey limestone. Microscopically, the
central part of the lens consists of microbe-bryozoan
boundstones.

name: Kirchfidisch, Burgenland
remarks: huge amounts of accumulated serpulid tubes

name: Weiße Wand, Graz Paleozoic
remarks:
Basally developed 'reef pioneer settlement', some 10m in thickness
dominated by densely packed Stachyodes and auloporids in a black bituminous limestone matrix. This sequence passes into
dark-grey fossil-rich limestones with special rugose coral consortia dominated by Mesophyllum and Stringophyllum. A thin horizon
(approximately 30-50 cm) with small colonies of the phaceloid rugosan Thamnophyllum terminates the 'pioneer sequence', which is overlain by 20-30 m-thick, white and slightly dolomitized limestones. The latter contain accumulations of various reef-building organisms
(stromatoporoids, rugose and tabulate corals).

name: Hohe Warte, Carnic Alps
remarks:
Microbial mounds are documented
in the Lower Devonian Rauchkofel Limestone.
Baffling organisms, especially calcareous green
algae (Hubmann 1994) and ramose-branching
tabulate corals, predominate.
The dimension of the lensshaped body is about 60-80 m in length and 8-10m in height.

name: Pimento Hill near Beecher Town, St. Ann parish
remarks: Coral patch reef

name: St. Ann and St. Andrew parish
Notre Dame de Beauregard, Orgon
remarks: Rudist limestones with corals and hydrozoans, overlying coral biostromes

name: San Luca area, Vicenza
remarks:
San Luca Unit dated as 'middle Oligocene'. Assignment to late Oligocene herein.
Very rich coral faunas in several levels.

name: Crosara area, Crosara unit, Vicenza
remarks: Coral-rich marls and algal limestones,

name: Cabanes reef, Saint-Paul-les-Dax, Landes
remarks: Small fringing reefs with rich coral fauna

name: Merignac, Bordeaux, Gironde
remarks: Two reefal levels

name: Thil, Eau Blanche Valley, Gironde
remarks: Small reefs

name: Martillac, Breyra Valley, Gironde
remarks: Small coral reef

name: Ripiceni, Prut Valley, Moldavia
remarks: Sarmatian serpulid-microbialite mud-mounds

name: Plopis Mountains, Simleu Basin, Salaj
remarks: serpulid-bryozoan-microbial bioherms 2-10 m thick.

name: Schela, S Carpathians, Gorj
remarks: serpulid-microbial bioherms

name: Sidi el Mahdjoub Reef, Ain Temouchent
Ain Oumata Reef, Sidi Bel Abbes
Boudinar Basin
remarks: coral lenses and bioherms embedded in marls^

name: Kebdana Platform reefs
remarks: narrow fringing reefs with constant detrital influx (coarse-grained sandstones)

name: Oued Kell reef, Meknes
remarks: Late Tortonian-Early Messinian. Coral reef, up to 10 m thick.

name: East Java
remarks: Lenses of reef limestone

name: Ngampel, North Java
remarks: Reef debris in marls

name: Nanggulan, Yogyakarta, Java
remarks: lenses of coral limestones and foraminiferal marls in volcanic tuff beds

name: Guantanamo, Cuba
remarks:
No details on age or composition.
Probably late Oligocene, because E Cuba was land in Early Oligocene.

name: Southern Marion Platform, ODP 194, Sites 1196, 1199
remarks: Rudstones and floatstones only. Pointing to close-by coral reef

name: Buenos Aires area, Limon Basin
remarks:
small reef lenses, coral thickets and coral rubble in clayey sediments.
Quebrada Chocolate Member and Buenos Aires Member

name: Lomas del Mar, Limon Basin
remarks:
samll patch reefs in sandstones, siltstones and claystones
Santa Rosa, Empalme and Lomas del Mar Members

name: Colon Island, Bocas del Toro
remarks:
Reef limestones are fore-reef rubble.
Bocas del Toro Group
Includes Paunch and Hill Point localities

name: Valiente Peninsula
remarks: coral reef lenses intercalated in coarse volcaniclastic facies

name: Unda and Clino Wells, Great Bahama Bank
remarks: coral floatstone in high-diversity skeletal packstone/grainstone matrix with zones of very fine-grained skeletal packstone

name: Battleship Wash patch reef, Nevada
remarks:
Small encrinitic patch reef.
Tubiphytes not mentioned but probably present.

name: Rasenriff, Telegraph Canyon Fm., Nevada
remarks: Small tabulate-stromatoporoid biostrome (Rasenriff) in sandy dolomitic limestones.

name: Buonvicino section, N-Calabria
remarks: Small 'sphinctozoan' bioconstructions, re-interpreted as algae (Calbricodium) by ref. 2600

name: Terziler cipits
remarks: Cipit block morth of Terziler at the margin of the Carnian locality of Riedel (1990)

name: Monti della Maddalena
remarks:
buildups at the margin of a carbonate platform facing a deep basin having good connection with the open sea.
bioclastic rudstone, floatstone and possibly boundstone from the destruction of nearby small buildups

name: Kasal
remarks:
Sponge-tabulozoan boundstones
small discontinuous, lenticular reef knolls or banks on a muddy sea floor

name: Mesici, Dinarides
remarks: 'Reef facies'. Only forams described

name: Las Juntas, Sierra de Baza
remarks:
Mounds consist of a core of bafflestone texture, with abundant sphinctozoans, hermatypic corals, inozoans, hydrozoans, solenoporaceans and dasycladaceans, covered on top by a boundstone formed by clusters of tubular organisms (serpulids) encrusted by Spongiostromata and with abundant interspace voids filled in by synsedimentary cements. At the top of the bioconstructions there exists a micrite facies with abundant fenestrae. The thickness of a single mound ranges from 1 to 10 m.

The mounds developed at the edge of a platform seaward of a calcarenite barrier.

Diversity in PBDB list refers to large area of several biostromes combined.

Milverton carbonate platform

The buildups developed on the Milverton carbonate platform, whereas the Waulsortian buildups in the S Co. Dublin developed in a deeper ramp setting of the Dublin Basin.

name: July Lake area, British Columbia
remarks:
Recent drilling in the Helmet and July Lake areas of northeastern British Columbia has found sizeable reserves of natural gas in the Upper Devonian (latest Frasnian) Jean Marie Formation. Patch reefs form a principal reservoir facies in this limestone. These reefs more closely resemble Carboniferous aged Phylloid-algal mounds than the more typical Givetian and Frasnian age buildups.

The patch reefs attained a maximum thickness of 25 m and had a maximum relief above the sea floor of approximately 13 m. The dominant reef formers were platy stromatoporoids which grew in an upright, interconnected manner similar to that of phylloid algae. Renalcis typically grew on the underside of these stromatoporoids, partially filling the shelter cavities while finer sediment accumulated on the tops of these stromatoporoids in a geopetal fashion.

name: Pardonet Hill Patch Reef
remarks: Ref. 2751:Bioclastic accumulations composed of crinoids, brachiopods, molluscs, spongiomorphs and scleractinian corals at Pardonet Hill. These small buildups (~100 to 500 m3) have planar bases and broadly convex tops (3 small reefs). These mounds are interpreted as small patch reefs composed of packstone, bioclastic floatstone/rudstone and carbonate breccia intercalated with mixed siliciclastic carbonate sediments deposited in a shallow subtidal setting. RCM Edit in May 2015.

name: Belaya-Pshekha Rivers, Caucasus
remarks: Coral reef boundstones, together with coral rudstones and floatstones. Massive and branching corals acted as the main component of vertical reef growth and provided the skeletons on which  abundant  microorganisms  and  microbialites  were    encrusted. The encrusting microorganisms (mainly   microproblematica) are identified as Bacinella-Lithocodium, Iberopora, Koskinobullina, Prismenproblematikum, Tubiphytesand serpulids, and  are heterogeneously distributed. Microbialites    are commonly encrusted. bioclastic  grainstones  have  been  observed in the reef matrix. Growth cavities are commonly developed and filled with early marine isopachous fibrous cement and occluded by blocky calcite cement. Tubiphytes and microbial fabrics overgrown corals.

remarks:

asymmetricus zone

name: Penaguila, Valencia
remarks:
Coral reef developed in HST on top of deep shelf limestone sequence. 
Buried coral reef also inferred for between Ibi and Carrasqueta.

coralgal buildups interfingering with miliolid-rotaliid limestones. The top shows a thickening-up bedding pattern and consists of packstones and grainstones with exclusively rotaliids and some coral debris. The unit of pebbly rotaliid limestones with coralgal reefs is considered to represent a highstand prograding barrier with fore-reef, reef and interreef subenvironments.

age indicated as early late Ordovician.
Corals, stromatoporoids, solenoporaceans and calcimicrobes as reef builders.
Largest oil field in China. oil in reef-flat and grainstones.
Reef facies in well Tazhong-30: Reef mounds are coral framestones coral bafflestones in 10-20 m thick horizons. Mud mounds are up to 30 m thick.

name: Goznitsa, Lovech
remarks:
Small biostromes and patch reefs in lagoonal marls, siltstones and sandstones.

They are built of colonial corals, faceloid and dendroid, adapted to a soft substratum (clayey bottom). They are preserved in the rock in situ, the dimensions of the colonies varying from several centimeters to several tens of centimeters.
Massive colonies dominate the central parts, and dendroid corals, the peripheries.

Mound cores exhibit microbial (mainly Epiphyton and Renalcis) patches, up to 0.8 m thick and 1 m long, surrounded by massive microsparite bearing scattered shelly debris. Archaeocyaths, both
preserved in life position and forming parautochthonous accumulations, are dominated by simple forms.
Abundant stromatactis

name: Pamyatno-Sasovskoye oilfield, Zhirnovsk

Intrabasin buildup.
flat-topped, narrow, and extended reef
steep (southeast) foreslope composed of relatively deep-water deposits and more gentle inner (north-west) slope represented by lagoonal deposits.
Upward increase of the role of stromatoporoids, corals, crinoids, calcareous algae (green and red), and cyanobacteria.
8% porosity, 10% detritus (fossils), 32% algal, rest is spar (dolomite)

name: Godavari quarry

name: Santa Teresiola, Taranto
remarks: The bank (or 'open frame reef') is formed by numerous, contiguous colonies of coral embedded in a sandy matrix up to 1 m high covering a surface of nearly 0.6 km².

name: NE Taebaek Basin
remarks: Described as siliceous-sponge microbial reefs. Epiphyton dominant, followed by Siliceous sponges, Renalcis and Epiphyton. 170 m thick section with several intervals. Described is only 14 m thick example. Ooids indicate shallow marine deposition. late Stage 5 to middle Guzhangian.

name: Lake Georgetown Spillway
remarks:
Outcrops of rudist-bearing shallow water carbonates. Weakly cemented, circular, flat-topped radiolitid–caprinid–toucasid mounds developed above the toucasid mounds and low relief, often sucrosic-dolomitized mounds.
Low diversity, with each biohermal stage being composed
of one dominant species—caprinids, toucasids, or caprinid–toucasid–
radiolitids, respectively.

name: Sant Onofre
remarks: Dendropoma and Spongites are the main builders

name: Rocky Camp Mound
remarks: Micritic components of the mud-mound were predominantly produced in situ by autochthonous algae and/or other skeletalorganisms. Green algae and stromatactis,together with sponge spicules in the lower facies of this mound - “microbial mud-mound” model

name: Marsica
remarks: Biota - corals and calcified demosponges. Sedimentary features - grain size, sorting and reworking degree, bioerosion, cement crusts and cavities.

name: Gosausee
remarks: Probably part of the same reef tract as Gosaukamm reef (Rf #28), however, the Gosausee site is only lower Rhaetian. Also, although the microbialites are volumetrically the most abundant reef builders, corals and sponges are more important in certain zones

name: Zhangzhai
remarks: The small-scaled reefs are generally domical or lenticular in shape, ranging in height from tens of centimeters to several meters, and in width from less than a meter to more than 10 m. They are chiefly built by benthic microbes, lithistid sponges, the quasi-sponge fossils Calathium as well as bryozoans and are usually surrounded by skeletal/intraclastic grainstones and packstones. Skeletal fragments of ostracods, trilobites, gastropods, brachiopods, nautiloids, and echinoderms are found within the reefs and surrounding sediments. Three reefal types are recognized.

name: Zhangzhai Calathium
remarks:
intraskeletal crypts of a lithistid sponge-Calathium
reef

name: Nanyigou section
remarks: Bioclasts are rare in the lower part of the reef. In the middle part of the reef bindstones are common and stromatolitic structures are becoming more abundant than in the lower part- which can be observed especially on weathered rock surfaces. In the top part of the reef thin-bedded micritic mudstones occur with rare bioclasts.

name: Børglum Elv, Peary Land
remarks: The individual mounds rarely exceed 1m in height. In terms of the rock fabrics, the North Greenland mudmounds show some similarity to the “thromboid”–bryozoan–worm tube association in the thin interval of “Red River reefs”

name: Vasalemma Nordkalk quarry
remarks:
Hemicosmitenkalk or cystoid limestone - the rock building abundance
of echinoderm (mainly Hemicosmites, Rhombifera) bioclasts
in this limestone

name: Aggtelek
remarks: No comment

name: Taebaeksan Basin
remarks: Stromatoporoids and bryozoans comprise more than 50 areal percent of these frameworks. Cystostroma stromatoporoids -34%, Nicholsonella bryozoans -16%, unidentified tubular organisms - 4% and siliceous sponge <2%.

name: Capo Colonna
remarks: The Capo Colonna deposits include rigid build-ups, rhodolith accumulations, and a maerl bed. The build-ups, identified as a fossil example of the present day Mediterranean coralligenous, are primarily formed by Mesophyllum alternans

name: Ainsa-Jaca Basin
remarks:
upper part of Arguis Fm
Mesophotic reef

name: Dunmore
remarks: The local trend, which occurs only in the two southern localities (deeper water), expresses differences between the skeletal grain content of the various lithofacies. These differences result partly from increased sensitivity to substrate texture by organism groups suffering southward attenuation (notably gastropods, hyalosteliid sponges, aoujgaliids, Earlandia and kirkbyacean ostracods) and partly from selective colonization, particularly of the transition facies, by tabulate corals and stick/ramose bryozoans. However, the developmental sequence of precursor carbonate muds is the same at all localities, indicating that the mud-making process (probably microbial) was independent of water depth.

name: Tiandong 10, Kaijiang, east Sichuan
remarks: ?Microbialite

name: N of Port Sudan, Red Sea coast
remarks: terraces which are exposed in the coastal plain north of the city of Port Sudan, between 19° 54' N and 21° 50' N and 36° 51' E and 37° 17' E, until near to the border between Sudan and Egypt

name: Monte Postale
remarks: Diverse corals Actinacis

name: Topuk Tepe, near Pinargözü
remarks:
tectonically
isolated carbonate block composed of Dachstein-type limestones with megalodonts and large dendroid corals. At the top of this
sedimentation a reefal fauna is developed with similarities to the cipit fauna. The Topuk Tepe locality is surrounded by reef
boulder bearing shales of Kasımlar Formation.

name: Vojsko Plateau
remarks:
The major biostrome builders are medium-sized coralline sponges, Demospongea and Calcarea, encrusted by smaller sponges, tube worms, sessile foraminifera, calcareous algae - Archaeolithoporella - and Shamovella - Tubiphytes-, all of which are typically covered by microbial crusts. The biostromes are characteristically composed of bafflestone and bindstone, incorporating sporadic framestone.
Narrowbelts of floatstone surround the buildups, and sponge debris is also present in lenseswithin the mud matrix between metazoan bafflestones

name: Yeongwol County, Yeongheung Fm
remarks:
A fabric composed of peloids up to several tens of micrometers in diameter, micrite, patches of calcite cement, and ghosts of either in-place or dissociated cyst plates and pillars occupies areas where the internal textures of stromatoporoid skeletons are poorly preserved. This fabric commonly grades intowellpreserved stromatoporoid skeletons, or rarely replace the bulk of each
skeleton.
Framework basically just Labechia, rare calcimicrobes and bryozoans

name: Yadana field, offshore Myanmar
remarks:
The Aquitanian marks the onset of renewed volcanic activity associated with the development of fringing
carbonate reefs during the Burdigalian. The rapid (~6 My) development of these wide (~5e70 km) and
thick (~300e850 m) carbonate platforms has been mainly controlled by the subsidence.

name: Precordillera
remarks:
Coralomorph (Amsassia colonies) in thrombolite mounds. Amsassia intpreted as calcareous green alga by Lee et al. (2021).
Stromatolites, and particularly thrombolites, are ubiquitous and very common components of the higher-frequency cycles.  Calcarenites are mainly composed of peloids, well-rounded intraclasts, aggregate lime grains, micritized ooids, and a few bioclasts. Bioclasts are very scarce and include rare calcareous algae such as Nuia sp. and scattered fragments of gastropods, trilobites, and nautiloids within the cross-bedded subtidal grainstone-packstone intervals.  Abundant in situ gastropods seem intimately related with domical thrombolites.

name: Lombardina 1
remarks: Reef generation 5. Continued growth of islated atolls

name: North Scott Reef 1
remarks: Reef generation 4. Reestablishment of reef belts, atolls

name: Wubaiti, (TD021-4, TD021-X7), eastern Sichuan
remarks:
Comment from Dong at al., 2021: 
TD021-4 reef: carbonate ramp-open platform-platform margin shoal-open platform-platform margin reef facies

name: Gyanyima Section, Burang County in Ngari, Tibet
Baidar Valley, Crimean Mountains
remarks:
Trombolites, incrusted Crescentiella morronensis, and Terebella lapilloides, subordinate corals and
sponges, which are interpreted as deep-water
(mainly microbial) bioherms and a new type of forereef apron deposit discovered in limestones
of the Baidar plateau. Such aprons include
gravitation flow sediments. intraclast rudstones
and floatstones with clasts of various reef-builders, as well as sorted grainstones, rudstones, and microbreccias that bear structural signs of unidirectional current and gravitation flow in some places.

name: Pavasaris and South Bliudziai
remarks:
The Minija Regional Stage forms the lower part
of the Pridoli (Paskevicius 1997). Carbonates of
the Minija Regional Stage serve as a good example of a
carbonate ramp system with a stromatoporoid-crinoid-
brachiopod-dominated carbonate factory. According to the
lithofacies distribution, the ramp can be subdivided into
five main facies belts...

name: Jablonna
remarks:
Consists of three separate reef bodies, as established by a 3-D seismic
study.

name: Bonikowo
remarks:
The drillcore section is a mixture of boundstones (microbial and bryozoan), wackestones, packstones
and grainstones, which often co-occur.

name: Tebaga of Medenine
remarks:
the northern edge of the Saharan platform. The exposed Permian sequence at Jebel
Tebaga of Medenine and Baten Beni Zid consists at least of 850m of marine strata grading to nonmarine red beds. It is made up of local biohermes, thin carbonate beds, bioclastic limestone, sandstone and shale. The main feature of Permian
sequence is the abrupt and complex facies changes due to presence
of obscure and inferred faults. Particularly, presence of the fusulinacean Yabeina at Oum el Afia section suggests that these rocks are younger than those outcropping at Baten Beni Zid.

name: Penglaitan -Tieqiao
remarks:
The overlying Heshan Formation, 150 m
in thickness, is composed of black cherty limestone of
basinal facies in the lower part and white bioclastic carbonate
of sponge reef facies in the upper part. The Late
Wuchiapingian reefal carbonates about 91 m in thickness
at the Tieqiao Section are reduced to 10 m in thickness
at the Penglaitan Section.

name: Gundara valley
remarks:
Our preferred palaeoenvironmental reconstruction is one of agglutinated
microbial reefs to cluster reefs. The microbial reefs are formed by
the cyanobacterial microbialites Tubiphytes and Archaeolithoporella, with a few large
cavities filled by botryoidal cements and subordinate skeletal elements. The cluster
reefs are made by in-place conical skeletons of Gundaria insolita n. gen. n. sp. that
were adjacent but not always in contact with the substrate. The Gundaira insolita
were also able to trap loose sediment, which indicates that the reefs are matrixsupported.
In-place, pedicle-attached species contributed to the framework and helped
trap the matrix. These reefs were likely laterally extensive despite their low
topographic relief, which is consistent with the mostly bedded nature of the Gundara
Formation. The abundance of matrix and the reduced cementation and bioerosion
suggest muddy depositional environments, which were probably deeper and more
turbid than those of the Safetdara Formation.

name: Dugway
remarks:
In the Dugway Range, the massive, cliff-forming, peloidal, stromatoporoid-
bearing reef facies is intercalated between thick-bedded,
carbonate-platform rocks of the lower Famennian, upper Guilmette
Formation below and thin-bedded, upper-slope rocks of the Famennian
West Range Limestone above. The carbonate facies in the
Dugway Range represent the southernmost extension of carbonate bank
that is equivalent to and continuous with the so-called False Birdbear
unit of the upper Jefferson Formation in Idaho, the upper limestone
unit of the Logan Gulch Member of the Three Forks Formation in
Montana, and the Morro Member of the Palliser Formation in Alberta,
Canada. Carbonate-bank facies deposition persisted
in an extensive, north-south–trending belt from the northern Great
Basin into southern Alberta for at least 3 myr until the middle
Famennian lower Palmatolepis marginifera biozone.

name: Agrio, Pilmatué Member, Loma Rayoso Area
remarks:
Coral biostrome (1.7 m thick) interbedded between two oyster shell beds. Only one coral species identifed, but one oyster and bryozoan species also indicated.
The biostrome is laterally continuous for more than 600m.
The studied section belongs to the upper half of the Pilmatué. The coral bed is interpreted as a coral biostrome. It is composed by low ramose coral colonies that did not form a rigid barrier, lacking lateral coalescence and overgrowing.

name: Rietoog
remarks:
Omkyk Member of the Kuibis Subgroup of the Nama Group, at the
Driedoornvlagte pinnacle reef complex, near Rietoog. Reef-building by the earliest known skeletal metazoan, the globally distributed Cloudina

name: Tangwangzhai
remarks: Two outcrop sections (Tangwangzhai and Laopozhuang sections) in Shandong Province. Microbial components comprise microstromatolites, calcified Girvanella filaments, and Renalcis-like botryoid forms. Microstromatolites, which are one of the most common components of the maze-like structures, mostly exhibit convex-up laminae composed of alternating micrite and microsparite

name: Tangwangzhai
remarks: Two outcrop sections (Tangwangzhai and Laopozhuang sections, about 20 km distant) in Shandong Province. Microbial components comprise microstromatolites, calcified Girvanella filaments, and Renalcis-like botryoid forms. Microstromatolites, which are one of the most common components of the maze-like structures, mostly exhibit convex-up laminae composed of alternating micrite and microsparite

name: Fox Cove
remarks:
At the Fox Cove locality, a series of archaeocyathan patch reefs of the lower Forteau Formation. Common components of all thin sections include microbial fabrics, carbonate cement, echinoderms, brachiopods, archaeocyaths and trilobites. Grainstone samples often contain
abraded and broken fossil material as well as detrital
grains; reef samples are characterized by
abundant microbial fabrics with archaeocyathans.

name: Herefordshire
remarks:
The central part of the buildup is formed by coral bafflestone, partly overlain
by brachiopod-rich facies III. The buildup is formed by several pillow-shaped units. The transition
to surrounding bedded facies V is gradual. The buildup framework is formed by complete, in situ colonies of rugose and tabulate corals, stromatoporoids and branching bryozoans. The sediment baffled between the framework builders consists of very poorly sorted echinoderm ossicles, brachiopods and rare ?Dimorphosiphon fragments, but the buildup fabric is distinguished by a high (ca 50%) micritic matrix. Allonema and Rothpletzellaare present as crusts and Rothpletzella also as loose
accumulations within the matrix. These are associated with mottled, peloidal-like structures containing
structures tentatively identified as sponge spicules. The mottled fabrics contain multiple small
(up to 0.4 cm wide) stromatactis-like cavities filled with spar, characterized by sharp basal parts and irregular undulating upper parts. In SEM images, oncoids and Rothpletzella
accumulations floating in the matrix are built by tubes filled with sparitic cement. The tube walls
are 5-6 µm thick, formed by regularly arranged needleshaped calcite crystals oriented perpendicular to the porostromate tube in longitudinal sections and radially in cross sections. In contrast, the mottled, peloidal matrix of facies IV is composed of chaotically arranged microcrystalline calcareous mud containing a high proportion of clay particles and scattered fragments of skeletal grains. The buildup is overlain by nodular wacke- to packstones composed of well-sorted echinoderm,
brachiopod, gastropod, trilobite and coral fragments (facies V) and onlapping the units represented by
facies II, III and IV.

name: Saaremaa
remarks:
Due to constant southwards regression and infilling
of the BSB, the lagoonal-littoral facies became increasingly
dominant all over Saaremaa towards the end of Wenlock. At that time, the shoal facies only reached Saaremaa during short transgressions. A series of upwards shallowing cycles with shoal to lagoonallittoral
sediments, often bracketed by discontinuity surfaces, therefore characterizes the Jaagarahu and Rootsiküla stages on Saaremaa

name: Saraburi, Siam City Cement quarry along Highway 2
remarks:
Peritidal zone deposits consist of dark carbonaceous mudstones-wackestones and dolomitised laminated algal boundstone beds. Secondary Fe-calcite camouflaged the original depositional texture in some parts. Fossils include Schubertella, Girvanella and Gyroporella algae, Hemigordius, Globivalvulina sp. along with other microscopic non-fusuline foraminifera. Peritidal settings were interpreted within Logs 1 and 4 with ages constrained between the late Murgabian to Midian.
Platform interior contains three sub-environments: lagoon, the outer platform and the higher energy backreef. The low-energy lagoon is comprised of bioturbated skeletal and peloidal wackestones and packstones with localised interbedded shales. The fossil assemblage contained abundant algae including Girvanella, bivalves (including alatoconchids), fusulinids (N. simplex) and microscopic non-fusuline foraminifera (Globivalvulina, Schubertella, Cribogenerina and Textulariida). The lagoonal environment is interpreted for lower Log 4 and upper Log 6 and deposited in the Murgabian with possible extension into the Midian.
The outer platform sub-environment is a non-parallel bedded bioclastic limestone grading from wackestone through to grainstone with boundstone interbeds. Isolated coral clumps were also observed within the grainstone sections. Inner platform settings were interpreted within Logs 1, 2, 5, 7 and 8. The age of the environment was constrained using the fusuline foraminifera (Neoschwagerina simplex, other Neoschwagerina sp., Neofusulinella, Nankinella, Kahlerina, Armenina). The fossil assemblages gave an age within the Murgabian Stage.
The higher-energy backreef sub-environment is defined by parallel bedded wackestones and packstones. Backreef settings are interpreted within Logs 5, 6 and 8. Each major fossil group is present in the Highway 21 backreefs: crinoids, fusulinids (Nankinella, Schwagerina, Colania, Neoschwagerina and Gifuella), bivalves (Alatyoconda), non-fusuline foraminif

name: Akiyoshi and Taishaku
remarks:
Palaeoaplysina–microencruster reef community.  In a reef-core area
of the atoll, the alga Palaeoaplysina acted as a framebuilder and was associated with various binders (e.g., Tubiphytes,Archaeolithoporella, cystoporate bryozoans, and microbialites) and sediment-bafflers such as fenestrate and cryptostomate bryozoans and phylloid algae. In a subtidal environment of the back-reef area, Palaeoaplysina and phylloid algae flourished as sediment-bafflers. A microbial community, including Tubiphytes and sessile foraminifers, was predominant in a very shallow, peritidal environment of the back-reef area.

name: Longdianshan Hill, Liuzhou
remarks: The mud banks are composed of a mixture of two basic micro-facies: (1) spiculitic wackestone with diverse fauna includingcryptostome and fenestellid bryozoans, crinoids, ostracodes, andbrachiopods; (2) fine-grained bioclastic wackestone and pack-stone containing crinoids, bryozoans, sponges, brachiopods,ostracodes, and corals. The mud banks developed during a rela-tive sea-level rise in an outer deep platform margin, and died asrelative sea-level fell evidenced from the bioclastic wackestoneand packstone overlying the banks. The mud banks at Longdian-shan are similar to typical Waulsortian mud mounds, as indicatedby the presence of bryozoans, crinoids, and sponges, mud gen-erations and spar-filled cavities

name: Gandongzi village and Xiadong village,, Langping, Guangxi
remarks:
Reef complex of various reef types stacked. Largest reef is R6, which is 19 m thick.
Cumulative thickness is 30 m

Built mainly by the colonial rugose coral Thysanophyllumand the bryozoan Fistulipora, and less frequently by Syringo-pora (tabulate coral) and Lithostrotion (colonial rugose coral). Reef-dwellers include crinoids, brachiopods,solitary rugose corals, cryptostome bryozoans, foraminifers, gastropods, ostracodes, and green algae.Reefal units show four growth stages with the predominantframeworks of Thysanophyllum, Fistulipora, Thysanophyllum,and Fistulipora-Thysanophyllum, intercalated with intraclastic-crinoidal or crinoidal bank facies. The reef-crest is composedof gray thick-bedded algal peloidal packstones, fine bioclasticwackestones interbedded with brachiopod grainstones and pack-stones. The reef was formed at shallow isolated platform marginand died resulting from relative sea-level fall and rise respec-tively, which may be caused by regional rift activities. At Xiadong village, Langping, reef is about 260 m wide and 50 m thick andthe major reef-builders are colonial rugose corals (Diphyphyl-lum, Siphonodendron, and Lithostrotion), and the tabulate coralSyringopora. Reef-dwellers are solitary rugose corals, crinoids,ostracodes, brachiopods, gastropods, bryozoans, and calcareous algae.

name: Yashui
remarks: The middle Viséan coral biostrome from the Shangsi For-mation at Yashui, which is variable from 2.5 m to 3.9 m inthickness and more than 500 m in width, is composed mainlyof Kueichouphyllum (solitary rugose coral), Syringopora,and Siphonodendron. Associated fossils include brachiopods,crinoids, foraminifers, calcareous algae, gastropods, bryozoans,and ostracodes. In the biostrome, three growthstages have been distinguished, which in ascending order areKueichouphyllum growth stage, Kueichouphyllum-Syringoporagrowth stage, and Siphonodendron growth stage. The biostromeoccurred at shallow DQGX platform margin with its growthand demise controlled by relative sea-level rise and fall, asevidenced from the increasing of micrites and sparry calcitein the biostrome and its overlying limestone, respectively. Compared with the coral reefs, the coral biostromelacks calcimicrobe encrustation and sparry calcite cementation

name: Mengcun and Helü
remarks: Morphologies of these stromatolites include laminar, wavy-laminar, domal or hemispheroidal, bulbous, and flabellate-growth columns. Individual stromatolites are generally 3–6 cm thick, which can grow upward upto 60 cm thick in the core facies. The core-facies of stromatolite mounds were formed by calcimicrobes, with initially horizontal laminar and tabular growthforms later becoming domal and bulbous forms, and finally flabellate columnar forms indicating a gradual relative sea-level rising. The occurrence of talus breccias under and above themounds suggests that they were located at a deep slope setting.

name: Beibuwan
remarks: One 300 m thick core of the late Bashkirian-middle Kasi-movian red algae reef crops out in the Dabu and Huanglongformations at Beibuwan. It is located at shallow SW plat-form margin. Themain constructors are the red algae Parachaetetes and Ung-darella. Reef-dwellers include crinoids and fusulinids. Fivesimilar growth stages, characterized by Parachaetetes and Ung-darella bindstone, can be identified, which are separated by fourgrowth intermissions dominated by dolostones, and the fifthgrowth stage also has some small growth intermissions.

name: Xinzhai and Longjiangdong Langping
remarks:
Coral patch reef, whichis 15 m in width and 20 m in thickness, is composed mainly ofcolonial rugose corals: (Lonsdaleia and Antheria), and Syringo-pora with crinoids filling around them. 
Longjiangdong biostromal reef is about28 m wide and 15 m thick, grows on crinoidal banks, and hasthree cyclical growth stages. Diphyphyllumis abundant and accessory organisms are crinoids, brachiopods,calcareous algae, and foraminifers (Fig. 5B). The coral patchreef at Longjiangdong is about 20 m wide and 8 m thick. Themain reef-builders are Thysanophyllum and Lithostrotionella(Petalaxis) (colonial rugose coral) with Caninia (solitary rugosecoral) secondarily incorporated. Thysanophylum and Lithostro-tionella successively occur in the reefs in clusters, and Caniniarandomly grows near the clusters. Reef-dwellers are mainlycrinoids. TheLongjiangdong reefs were formed at shallow SW platform margin, and grew and demised due to relative sea-levelrise and fall, resulting from the increasing micrites and sparrycalcite in the reefs and their overlying limestones, respectively

name: Lianyuan and Lengshuijiang, Hunan Province
formation: upper Zimenqiao Formation to lower Dabu Formation
remarks: In Lianyuan and Lengshuijiang cities, HunanProvince, the Serpukhovian-middle Bashkirian massive lime-stones (about 5 m thick) from the upper Zimenqiao Formation tolower Dabu Formation contain abundant benthic fossils includ-ing fasciculate colonial rugose corals, fasciculate tabulate corals,and chaetetids. They locally form bounded frameworks whichresemble the contemporaneous reefs in Akiyoshi, Japan. Besides, stromatolites also occurred in Lianyuan-Lengshuijiang areas during this time

name: Yashui
remarks: formed by in situ upright fasciculate colonial rugosecorals. Preliminary data indicate that dwellers of this coralboundstone include crinoids, brachiopods, foraminifers, ostra-codes, gastropods, bryozoans, calcareous algae, and solitaryrugose corals. This coral boundstone was located at shal-low SW platform margin during the early Bashkirian, and it grew and died as relative sea-level rose and fell respec-tively, evidenced from increasing micrites and sparry calcite inthe boundstone and its overlying limestone, respectively. Therefore, the Serpukhovian-middle Bashkirian has the poten-tial for reef development, and the discovery of reefs is to be made

name: Benxi Area, Liaoning
remarks:
Benxi Area, Liaoning Chaetetes – coral reef. At the beginning of the Pennsylvanian, a massive south-north transgression occurred in this region. The sedimentary environment changed from fan delta to fiord coast and then into a carbonate platform, and thus several reefs with
a nearly east-west trend were built on the nearshore side of the platform. These reefs are relatively small, with thickness of 2–4 m. There are abundant benthic organisms found in these reefs, and the biotic content is up to 60% of the reef volume. Arachnastraea manchurica and
Chaetetes penchiensis are the dominant building organisms in these reefs. Their colonial skeletons are tabular in shape with varying thickness. Multithecopora penchiensis is the secondary building organism in the reefs of this region, and it mainly occur in the spaces between Chaetetes and Arachnastraea. There are also such binding organisms in the reef as Archaeolithoporella and Girvanella. The organisms associated with the Chaetetes coral reef are fusulinids, foraminiferans, brachiopods, ostracodas, bryozoans, gastropods and various genera of algae.

name: Eastern Tianshan, Xinjiang
remarks: occurred in the Tianshan-Xingan active ocean trough. Coral pach reef, bryozoan-calcareous algae mound

name: Beibuwan Area, Guangxi
remarks:
Parachaetetes and Ungdarella are the main reef-building
organisms. Calcareous green algae are also associated
with these reefs

name: Mineral Mountains, Utah
remarks:
Early Smithian reef deposits are characterized by more diverse sponge morphologies. The oldest sponges are embedded within
microbialites forming reefs, tens of centimetres thick, distributed
throughout a massive (up to 10m high) microbial carbonate unit.
These microbialites are composed of centimetre-scale stromatolitic
domes and thrombolites sealed off by micrite. Complete cup- to
flat-shape and dendroid centimetre-scale sponges are preserved,
resting on micrite matrix or encrusting microbialitic crusts. They
show an internal re-crystallized spiculitic network and are often partially to completely dissolved and replaced by calcite-cemented
cavities.

name: Pahvant Range, Utah
remarks:
the oldest reefs consist of small (ca. 5mm) sponges
encrusting thin bivalve shell layers, which probably facilitated
their settlement and enhanced their preservation. Although
these sponges are preserved in life position, their initial essentially
globular shape now seems compacted. The sponges are associated with small serpulids within a very abundant micritic matrix, and with common echinoderm plates (probably crinoids) locally reworked as bioclastic accumulations in storm-induced deposits. These biostromes, tens of centimetres thick, are formed by alternating gregarious settling and hydraulic reworking. The latter leads to multiple short-term events of hard-part concentrations in a low to moderate energy mid ramp environment.
Isolated sponges are also found within overlying beds, identified
only by sparse bundles of spicules. Sponges occur a few metres
higher in recurrent large (ca. 50 m of lateral exposure) lenticular ca. 5-
cm-thick layers, throughout a ca. 20 m-thick stratigraphic interval. These sponges are preserved in situ as lenticular reefs composed of small coalesced spheres (ca. 1 cm in diameter) that resemble lyssacine hexactinellids bound by submillimetre-scale biofilms. Within the lowermost Spathian PR beds, serpulids form small millimetre to centimetre-consortia with abundant ostracods, brachiopods and rare gastropods, alternating
with tempestite deposits

name: Willow Spring locality, Olds Ferry terrane, Blue Mountains Province, northeastern Oregon
remarks:
Upper member of the Huntington Formation (Olds Ferry terrane) at a locality. Corals at the site include a high-growing, dendroid-phaceloid
species that acted as either framework or sediment baffles, and a lowgrowing, cerioid, encrusting coral and a sponge that acted as sediment herein named Willow Spring. binders. Together, these organisms produced at least a 10–50 cm high reef-like or reefal framework. Framework mineralogy of sandstones and clast types in the
conglomerate suggest that the source of these Triassic coral-sponge reef faunas was intrabasinal. The occurrence of the same two coral taxa in the Wallowa and Olds Ferry terranes may support the proximity of these two regions in the late Triassic, but the presence of these taxa in other Cordilleran terranes suggests that they are probably cosmopolitan and therefore not good indicators of terrane proximity.

name: Paluma Shoals, Halifax Bay
remarks:
The palaeoecological assemblages of the PSRC are representative of inner-shelf reef communities across the central GBR, which are characterised by mixed assemblages of acroporids (Montipora, and locally abundant Acropora), dendrophyllids (Turbinaria), euphylliids (Euphyllia and Galaxea), and poritids (Goniopora and Porites). The composition of
inner-shelf coral communities distinguishes them from those associated with mid- and outer-shelf reefs, which are predominantly characterised by assemblages of Acropora

name: Stadion locality
remarks: diverse assemblage that includes corals, foraminifers, coralline algae, bryozoans, and mollusks. In addition, some echinoid spines, serpulid tubes, small brachiopods, and crustacean chelae were found within the sediments or cemented to coral surfaces. low-relief patch reef

name: Jiulongshan, Laiwu
remarks:
lower part of the Zhangxia Formation (Crepicephalina Zone: Drumian of Cambrian Series 3). The coralomorph-bearing lithistid demosponge-microbial reefs are intercalated within bioclastic wackestone beds. Thin veneers of stromatolites. In places, sheet-like micrite layers and knobshaped stromatolites consisting of vesicular and globular clots pave the
underlying wackestone. The underlying wackestone was stabilized by microbial consolidation, which then provided suitable substrates for the microbial reefs. Bioclastic wackestone is thus conformably overlain by the basal parts of the microbial reefs.

name: Ile de la Grosse Romaine
remarks: Mostly composed of peritidal and open-shelf carbonates. Well-developed thrombolite mounds occur in the middle part of the Romaine Formation either as small submeter isolated bioherms or as closely spaced buildups forming larger bioherm complexes up to 6 m high and several tens of meters wide.

name: Ile à la Chasse
remarks: Coalescent metersized thrombolite heads with a distinctive macroscopic clotted appearance exhibiting a cerebroid pattern in plan view and a digitate branching pattern in cross-section. They are flanked by a ripple-laminated to cross-bedded skeletal dolograinstone interpreted as coarse bioclastic haloes or channels separating individual bioherm complexes.

name: South end of the Franklin Mountains at El Paso, Texas
remarks: Small metazoan-microbial reefs, massive, barrel- to lens-shaped bioherms a few meters high and 2–5 meters across. in situ biotic builders are microbialites (mainly thrombolites) and lithistid, calathid, and pulchrilaminid sponges; many are dominated by thrombolites, some are dominated by Calathium, and a few are dominated by lithistid sponges.

name: Hudson Platform on Southampton Island
remarks: At the northern end of the Hudson Bay, the massive cores have been loosely described in the past as micritic, algal, or microbial limestones with metazoans. The Red Head Rapids Formation mounds are locally partly  dolomitized. The reefs contain large voids and vugs that are locally filled with bitumen and dead oil, composed of boundstone and cementstone  with various proportions of early calcified sponge tissues, microbial encrusters, synsedimentary cement and small  metazoans. The accretionary mechanisms of the Red Head Rapids Formation were mainly the result of frame building by early calcified sponges and small colonial corals and binding by calcimicrobial elements for the boundstone facies, and of marine cement precipitation near the seafloor for the cementstone facies.

name: Wadi Al-Ain 6
remarks: Carbonate ramp. Close (~150 km) to large commercial hydrocarbon fields in Saudi Arabia

name: Wadi Dirab
remarks:
Bioturbated spiculitic wackestone/mud-dominated packstone facies. The facies is characterized by crumbly appearance and nodular bedding produced by
bioturbation. Hardground surface encrusted with oysters. Sponge spicules in a micritic matrix. Mud-dominated packstone with sponge spicules, echinoids, and the foraminifera species, Redmondoides lugeoni, Photomicrograph of wackestone with sponge spicules, echinoids and brachiopods

name: Jabal Al - Abakkayn
remarks: Coral facies-capped cycles with bioherms

name: Dalmiapuram limestone quarry
remarks: Ostracods, bryozoans, gastropod fragments. Grey shale with frequent interbeds of fossiliferous grey limestone (the thickness of which increases upwards) and to a minor extent it is composed of a significant admixture of silt-sized siliciclastics. Coral algal limestone.

name: Raghbah
remarks: Coral buildups. Prominent bench formed by the cross-bedded peloidal-skeletal grainstone facies. Grainstone and bioherm facies that can be traced over relatively long distances

name: Brattefors
remarks:
Limstone reef. Oil samples from the Brattefors quarry are characterized by pyrene concentrations higher than phenanthrene. Oil samples from Brattefors quarry in south central Sweden were heated by volcanic intrusions with high pyrene/phenanthrene ratios and have C29 S/R sterane ratios significantly
beyond the normal thermodynamic threshold.

name: Bernatai
remarks: Reservoir oil. Limstone reef.

name: Adze-6
remarks: Limstone reef.

name: Rute-1
remarks: Limestone reef.

name: Nanjiang, Shatan section
remarks:
Microbial reefs containing archaeocyaths, up to 1.5 m thick, are composed of massive to lenticular thrombolites with densely distributed, millimeter- to centimeter-scale darker mesoclots and rare archaeocyaths. These microbial reefs are enclosed by wackestone–packstone, intraclast packstone– grainstone, ooid packstone–grainstone, calcareous shale, and
fine sandstone. The thrombolites are composed mainly of Girvanella, micritic
clumps, and subordinate Epiphyton.

name: La Désirade Island, Lesser Antilles
remarks:
The coral layers are dominated by either scattered domal and thick lamellar
colonies of Diploria spp., in life position or elkhorn Acropora palmata
represented by up to 2-m-thick coral patches or coral breccia. An irregular
erosive surface incises up to 2 m depth into the top of Unit 1. Unit
2 consists of the three following layers. Scattered thick lamellar
Diploria sp. and domal Orbicella colonies in life position, columnar Orbicella
spp. patches up to 4 m thick and 100 m long, and rare, scattered
Acropora palmata. Coral patches form bioherms and are surrounded
and overlain by m-thick-bedded, coarse-grained calcarenites
with clay, and by dm-to-m-thick-bedded and clayey, sand-supported
red breccia. These breccia include pebbles from the substratum, dm-toover-
m-sized coral fragments, and a few bioclasts.

name: Kampung Lembah Tuwi, near Kangar
remarks: These dome-shaped microbialites grew directly on skeletal packstones and grainstones with abundant oncoids. Laterally, the massive microbial boundstone grades into surrounding bioclastic limestones. The microbial reefs are mainly composed of cylindrical columnar stromatolites (8- 35 cm wide and 30-105 cm high), with a distinct laminar texture present over the weathered surfaces. Several stromatolites usually occur alongside each other and are packed together, creating a frame-like cluster structure. Interspaces between stromatolites are often filled with Calathium. lithistid sponge-microbial bafflelbindstones that generally lack recognizable lamination and are characterized by in situ sponges

name: Blue River, East Greenland
remarks:
The East Greenland bioaccumulations developed within a restricted Boreal mid-paleolatitude seaway, and comprised a monospecific primary framework of microconchid ‘lophophorate’ tubes with shell fragments and phosphatic debris cemented by biogenic
calcite.
Wordie Creek Group

name: Baimiaozi, Jialing River, Beibei
remarks:
10 microbial mounds
Conodont fossils such as Hindeodus parvus?
and Isarcicella staeschei were found in the microbial mounds, and these fossils indicate
that the age is that of the lower Griesbachian Stage.
The microbial mounds in this study can be considered to be composed of three facies, namely, a
mound base, mound body, and mound cap.
Growth below normal" wave base."

name: Jebel Toksine, Dades Valley
remarks:
Two main intervals dominated by lithiotid
and lithiotid-coral biostromes. Lithiotid intervals are characterized by alternating ooid-, peloid- and skeletal-rich wackestones to grainstones
interbedded with thick lithiotid and lithiotid-coral rudstones to framestones. Bivalve fauna, rare megalodontids.

name: Fath
remarks: Constructed coralgal build-ups.

name: Ganjgon, Late Rupelian
remarks: Further down-dip, larger benthic foraminifers (large Nummulites test, Operculina and Neorotalia) packstone-grainstone along with discrete coral patches and coralline red algae

name: Mt. Ishidate2, Befu-Kito area
remarks:
Massive limestone slab. sponge-microbialite boundstones. Abundance of sponges. The reef framework represents a relatively low volume and does not exceed
33%. High abundances of Tubiphytes and peloidal and clotted micrite.

name: Mt. Ishidate1, Befu-Kito area
remarks: Massive limestone slab.sponge-dominated reefs during the Late Carnian–Norian to Rhaetian?. abundance of Chaetetids, and the presence of Galeanella sp., Microtubus communis, Decapoalina schaeferae, Alpinophragmium perforatum and Actinotubella gusici. significant reef framework (40–60% of the rock volume)

name: Wajiki area, Anan, Tokushima prefecture
remarks: Reef limestone clasts crop out, along with basaltic clasts and limestone clasts of other facies, in a VCM breccia. This unit is in tectonic contact with recrystallized massive limestone slabs. Reef limestone crops out in VCM breccia. The reef framework volume is relatively low (approximately 30%) but sponges are comparatively abundant (21%) and Tubiphytes are rare. Sponge-dominated reefs.

name: Hellnmaria Member
remarks:
Tightly packed round to sub-round microbialites.Microbialites in zone 1 are stromatolitic, have diameters of between 10 to 30 cm at their longer axes, and are typically 20–40 cm tall. Synoptic relief is about 10–20 cm. The interspace material is an intra-bioclastic grainstone with some minor packstone domains. Allochems, predominantly composed of
intraclasts (50%) and trilobite bioclasts (40%), average 0.5–4 mm in length, appear moderately sorted, sub-rounded, but generally are not
spherical. Some trilobite bioclasts are over 1 cm long. Zone 1 microbialites have a small areal distribution of about 1 km2. Microbialites in zone 2, which cover the majority of the bed,
are also stromatolitic, have diameters that vary from 40 to 70 cm across their longer axes, and have heights that fluctuate from a few dm to about 70 cm. Synoptic relief is about 10–20 cm. The interspace material is an intrabioclastic grainstone with some minor packstone domains. Allochems, predominantly composed of intraclasts (70%) and trilobite bioclasts (20%) average 0.5–2 mm in length, appear well-sorted, well-rounded, and are sub-spherical. These microbialites are chiefly differentiated from those in zone 1 by the presence of a central core composed of mini-stromatolites. Sponges are recognized as spicule networks that typically do not exceed a few cm in size, with many not exceeding 1 cm

name: Fins, Sharqiyah region
remarks: The micritic to microspariticmatrix supports fragments of red algae, corals, small bivalves, echinoid with syntaxial overgrowth, monaxon sponge spicules (some made of silica, some made of calcium carbonate) and bryozoans. The vuggy pores of a dissolved coral are partly filled with equant, drusy calcite cement

name: Carysfort Outlier Reef, Florida
remarks:
Substage 5a reef growth recorded from -15 to -11 m MSL, spanning an age range of 86.2-80.9 ka. Shallow fore- and back-reef facies dominated by the head corals Montastrea annularis and Colpophylia natans,
and the branching coral Acropora palmata.

name: Chanakhchi section, near the village of Zangakatun
remarks: Sponge-microbial build-ups, thrombolitic biostromes

name: Vacuum, Lea County, New Mexico
remarks: a calcisponge-microbialite reef

name: Kamień Pomorski platform - Benice
remarks:
Within the Main Dolomite carbonates of Poland, the most common organosedimentary structures are microbial laminites, stromatolites, and thrombolites, mostly developed in inter- to subtidal facies . The intertidal facies are chiefly composed of planar stromatolites (<50 cm [20 in.] thick) and thrombolites (20 cm[8 in.] thick). Planar stromatolites mainly contain
even laminae that consist of light (muddy)-gray and dark (organic) couplets of microsparitic dolomite and darkgray micritic dolomite (deposited in restricted lagoons and intertidal pools). They commonly contain fenestrae
filled with sulfate. Micritic organic layers contain algal
remains (Mizzia), ostracods and rare foraminifera, coated
grains, and peloids, and are built of coccoid-like organomineral
forms and microbial filaments. Oncoids and peloids
formgrainy planar stromatolites (deposited in inner
ooid shoals and tidal channels), dolomitic grainstone, and
packstone.

name: Little Cedar Creek, SW Alabama
remarks:
Hydrocarbon-productive microbial and high energy, nearshore carbonate facies were deposited in shallow subtidal water depths in an inner ramp. The buildups are composed of thrombolites. The microbially influenced facies is present throughout the field area, but the thrombolite buildups are restricted
to the southern part of the field. The microbially influenced facies varies in texture from packstone to lime mudstone. The packstone is a reservoir in parts of the field, and the lime mudstone serves as part of the updip lateral seal in the northeastern area of the field. Upper grainstone and packstone reservoir and lower boundstone and packstone reservoir are interbedded with three lime mudstone and dolomudstone to wackestone units (upper peritidal, middle deeper water subtidal, and lower transgressive subtidal) throughout the field. And to the northeast and updip in well permit 13,976, the Smackover section essentially consists of lime mudstone and dolomudstone, supporting the interpretation that the petroleum trap for this field is stratigraphic. The thrombolites consist of clotted peloidal boundstone and include a microfauna of benthic foraminifera, ostracods, bivalves, and microtubules.

name: Black Warrior Basin of Alabama
remarks: Sponge-microbial boundstone composed primarily of spiculitic clots embedded in a detrital carbonatematrix The mound was buried by foreshoal grainstone, much of which is brecciated. Upper Tuscumbia bryozoan-crinoid grainstone formed in a mobile shoal that quickly aggraded to sea level. Echinoderm debris, brachiopods and bryozoans are  abundant. Rugose corals, trilobites, ostracods, and sponges are less common

name: Assoul, High Atlas
remarks: Microbial mound. Mud mound surrounding by cross-bedded oolitic grainstone. As much as 25% of clastic sediments. Microbialites and sponges and ooids within growth cavities. Inner ramp

name: Assoul coral microbial, High Atlas
remarks:
Coral-microbialsponge reef: scleractinian corals, microbialites,
calcareous and siliceous sponges. Distal middle to outer ramp

name: Assoul - Molluscan-coralsponge reef, High Atlas
remarks:
Oysters, brachiopods, bivalves, scleractinian corals, calcareous
sponges, and demosponges. Local deposition of marl. Microencrustation by microbialites, bryozoans, and cyanobacteria. Geopetal fabric. Distal middle ramp

name: Hadahid fault
remarks:
Poorly cemented, structureless carbonate that contains gastropods, coral,
and bivalves. These carbonates are thin (<2 m, laterally discontinuous (up to ca. 300 m wide), and based on the faunal assemblage, are interpreted to have been deposited in small, patch-reef-like buildups

name: Ermenek area, Mut Basin
remarks:
Corals mostly consist of Porites and a few Tarabestrella and
Faviidae (hemispherical form). The matrix is composed of
fragments of red algae, echinoderms, some bivalves, and
gastropods. Frequent small and large benthic foraminifera are
found depending on the position along the depositional profile. Encrusting algae and rhodoliths are binding a matrix composed of large benthic foraminifera and bivalves, coral fragments, and some gastropods. Abundant red-algae debris associated with common bivalves, echinoderms, and large benthic foraminifera such as Heterestegina and Amphistegina. Bryozoan and oyster debris can be frequent in some place. Occasional Porites
and rare gastropods can be found.

name: Hantang, Guilin platform
remarks:
Hantang  mounds  represent  a  microbe-dominated  reef-building  community
with rare skeletal reef builders. The microbial mounds are composed almost exclusively of calcimicrobes, including Renalcis, Rothpletzella, Girvanell, Izhella, Ortonella, Wetheredella and a Stenophycus-like microbe. Mound-building metazoans and metaphytes include receptaculitids, solenoporoid algae, spiculate and stromatoporoid sponges, and massive corals, but the volumes of these skeletal organisms  are low. Synsedimentary cements are volumetrically important in the mounds and supported  and  reinforced the microbial  frameworks. The microbial facies can be divided into five sub-facies. In roughly ascending stratigraphic order, they are:(i) Rothpletzella-receptaculitid fabric; (ii) Rothpletzella boundstone fabric: (iii)stromatolite-thrombolite fabric;(iv) Rothpletzella-encruster fabric; and (v)Renalcis fabric.

name: Napoleon quarry
remarks: Small build-ups composed primarily of micrite and benthic skeletal remains, termed micro-bioherms.

name: Paojianggou, SW Tarim Basin
remarks: A Beresella-dominated algal mound. Komia bafflestone of the foremound facies further increased the relief of the crinoid bank on the seafloor. The lower part of the mound framework is dominated by Shamovella–Archaeolithoporella boundstone, while the main (upper) mound framework consists predominantly of Beresella boundstone. Grainstone–packstone characterizes the windward mound flank facies. The mound capping facies include a lower skeletal packstone–wackestone and an upper lagoon facies marlstone and black shale. Various algal colonies performed different roles in the formation of the mound. Komia colonies were the mound constructors that baffled higher energy currents and entrapped fine sediment. Archaeolithoporella, Shamovella and possibly microbes (cyanobacteria) acted as the binders to stabilize mud and fine-grained sediment. Beresella colonies were the major framework constructors whose network entrapped the mud to build the mound.

name: Kasim and Walio
remarks:
Carbonate fabrics include skeletal wackestones,
skeletal packstone, framestone, lime mudstone, and
bindstone in order of decreasing occurrences. The
skeletal grains are strongly modified by
dolomitisation, but were originally dominated by
corals and red algae, echinoderms, large and
planktonic foraminifera. Lime mud matrix has been
recrystallised. The widespread occurrence of corals
and red algae is strongly suggestive of deposition in
proximity to reefal buildups.

name: Bermejo field, NW Oriente Basin
remarks:
