Carbonate buildup or a patch reef. Dark and rough top surface and irregular edges.
The dip map of the M1 carbonate buildup exhibits
dark surface areas and irregular edges, suggesting
karst features and mechanical fractures, respectively.
The isopach map of the M1 carbonate buildup
is even more complex, suggesting localized carbonate
growth and weathering. The high but variable
seismic amplitude of the top surface of the M1 carbonate
buildup may also suggest weathering. The carbonate buildup can contain bbl of liquid.

name: Götzis locality, 10 km SW of Dornbirn, Vorarlberg
remarks: Facies type 6b. Patch reefs are composed of corals, stromatoporoids, and bryozoans.

name: Jeddah, Sharm Obhur
remarks:
A temporarily exposed 6-m succession of raised
reefal limestone terrace. The clayey layer showed higher species richness (65 species) than the limestone layer (18 species), indicating
a rapid change in the coral reef environment during
the deposition of the interval of MIS 5e.

name: Gawadar and Jiwani, Balochistan coast
remarks: The coral colonies were scattered in large patches on about more than 1-km area. The habitat was mostly rocky, composed of sand stones with fine and coarse sand, boulders and mudstone. Thirty coral species were recorded at this site. Many species were found scattered but a considerable proportion was tightly packed. Coral cover was about 33%. Prominent genera were Favia (11%) and Favites (4%).

name: Subeigo section (Thrombolite), Wuhai
remarks:
Thrombolite, characterized by meter-scale lenticular mounds composed of millimeter- to centimeter-scale mesoclots and wackestone matrix. Thrombolite mesoclots are composed of microstromatolites with alternating dark gray and light gray micritic laminae. Bioturbated micrites that occupy spaces between the mesoclots contain trilobite fragments. Three
types of bioturbation are recognized.

name: Subeigo section (maceriate), Wuhai
remarks: Maze-like maceriate reef with siliceous sponges and microstromatolites

name: Yangba section
remarks: Microbial carbonate. Thrombolites, laminites, oncolites and stromatolites dominate. The microbial dolostone reservoirs are low in porosity and permeability.

name: Katnikova Cave, Nizhnie Sergi
remarks:
Packstone bed cropping out near the waterline of the Serga River,
with a high content (60%) of crinoid stem fragments.
This bed represents the base of a series of 15 thin
gradational members separated by beds of dark calcareous
clay shale. The bed of bioclastic argillaceous
limestone sedimentologically represents fore-reef proximal
carbonate debris.

name: Shijiezigou section, Guyuan City
remarks: Patch reef in an open platform has a variety of corals that are preserved in situ. Reef-dwelling organisms include dasycladaceans, crinoids and gastropods. Other layers of the section are bedded limestones, many of which bear corals and crinoids, while others bear dasycladaceans or only the Dasycladacea genus Vermiporella. It contains abundant and diverse tabulate corals, which form bafflestones

name: Barzok section
remarks:
Coral boundstone, formed by in situ fauna as organic patch reefs, in openmarine
settings.

name: Gebel Raghawi section
remarks:
Toucasia bafflestone, which is dominated by complete valves of requieniid rudists (Toucasia sp.). The inner aragonitic layer of the rudist
shell is replaced by blocky calcite, and the outer foliated layer is calcite. The matrix is mainly lime mudstone with abundant benthic foraminifers, rudist fragments and rare dasyclad algae (Fig. 9c). This facies is dominated by low energy micrite and benthic foraminifers. We interpret it as an isolated biostrome developed in the back-reef environment.

name: Meregh-1
remarks:
Isolated pinnacle reefs where the limestones are
commonly fractured, leached and dolomitized with porosities of up to 19%. The reef builders are predominantly coral and algae.

name: Stetten
remarks: Shell accumulation comprising about 54,000 shells of the giant oyster Magallana gryphoides

name: Niau, Tuamotu
remarks: Slightly raised atoll with rich shell mollusc assemblage

name: Zebra River Farm
remarks: Microbial reef buildups. The lower reef occurrence appears as isolated mounding biostromes with poor fabric retention while the upper reef is sheetlike and forms a resistant bedding plane that exposes mounds of thrombolites and associated stromatolites. The mounds exhibit directional elongation and contain skeletal material within the fill between individual microbial buildups.

name: Panlongdong
remarks:
Number of spcies unknown due to dolomitization

Reef flats/caps contain mainly light gray crystal grain dolomites and sparry calcarenite. Reef cores are mostly sponge reef dolomites with the framework filled up by bioclasts and sand cuttings and contain a low content of calcilutite. Reef bases are less dolomitized and largely bioclastic limestones with bioclasts dominated by metacrinus and foraminifera.

Original Interval (Lopingian) was changed belated (Xuesong Tian, Yue Wang). 

Coordinates, environment and subenvironment changed according to Tian-Wang 2021 (see 3th. paper attached)

Reef builders:
Frame-building and baffling organisms: hypercalcified sphinctozoan and inozoan sponges, sclerosponges, bryozoans, and hydrozoans. Binding organisms: Archaeolithoporella, Tubiphytes, Fenestella, and cyanobacteria.

Reef dwellers:
Echinoderms, ammonites, bivalves, brachiopods, gastropods, benthic foraminifera, calcareous algae, and single rugose corals

Rock type and reef-related depositional characteristic:
Fore-reef slope: spiculitic-calcispherical cherty wackestone with reef breccias
Reef core: sponge framestone and bafflestone, Archaeolithoporella and cyanobacteria bindstone, and sponge framestone with the encrusting Archaeolithoporella
Reef flat (reef crest): packstone with reef breccia. 
Reef base: crinoidal packstone to grainstone. 
Back-reef: bioclastic dolostone with calcareous algae, gastropods, and foraminifers.

Reef type: 
Metazoan reef at the shallow carbonate platform margin

name: Amu-Darya Basin
remarks:
carbonate ramp, wherein the thickest sedimentary
formations were deposited, and organic reefs, bioclastic shoals, and oolitic shoals
were mainly developed. Rudists (50%)- ???, coral, red algae, bryozoans, sponges.

name: Skelya and Kamyshlak, Kerch Peninsula
remarks: Oval, up to 2 m in diameter, bioherm bodies in the Early Chokrakian basin were formed by bryozoan colonies of cheilostomates (Membranipora, Schizoporella, Cellaria, Scrupocellaria, Celleporaria) and cyclostomates (Crisia), red algae (Belokrys, 1986), and calcareous worm tubes.

name: Mayak, Kerch Peninsula
remarks:
The main reef forming organisms in bioherms  included seven species of Schizoporella
(Schizoporellidae, Cheilostomata) and quite common
cyclostomes Diastopora, Tubulipora, and Pustulipora.
The majority of the bryozoans have membraniporiform colonies. Vinculariform types are also present. These bioherms occurred at the transition from the upper to lower sublittoral zones.

name: Lake Tobechik, Kerch Peninsula
remarks: Bryalgal bioherms. The deposits covering bryozoan bioherms contain detrital limestones.

name: Cape Kop-Takyl
remarks:
Serpulid-microbialite buildups (nodular
carbonate bodies). Mollusks assemblage, in addition
to mass Crypromactra and rare poorly preserved
imprints of cardiids, commonly includes gastropods.

name: Cape Tuzla, Taman and Cape Popov Kamen, Taman Peninsula
remarks:
Bryozoan bioherms are formed by Membranipora elliptica,  bivalve mollusks (Polititapes abichi)
gastropods that form mass accumulations. Early Maeotian

name: Belaya River
remarks:
bryozoan colonies of cheilostomates (genera
Membranipora, Schizoporella, Cellaria, Scrupocellaria, Celleporaria), cyclostomates and calcareousworm tubes.

name: Chimbulat quarry, Kirov Region
remarks: bed of yellow bioclastic limestone with numerous bryozoan imprints, crinoid columnals, brachiopod and molluskan shells

name: Tastuba-Mitrofanovo quarry
remarks:
The Mitrofanovo and Tastuba Reefs are composed of organic limestones containing large amounts of diverse fossil animals (foraminifers, brachiopods, bryozoans, gastropods, crinoids, bivalves, trilobites). In
the Tastuba Reef, the records of trilobites are restricted
to the lower member of massive, cavernous limestones. In the Mitrofanovo Reef, they occur throughout the thickness of the sediments.

name: Reinecke field, west Texas
remarks:
Two types of dolomite are observed.One type is stratiform, replaced micrite-rich facies, and is interpreted as early dolomite that recrystallized in hydrothermal brines. The second type crosscuts stratigraphy and depositional facies and has vertically continuous morphologies that trend northwest-southeast. The latter dolomite is interpreted as forming in hydrothermal brines
derived from latest Permian-aged highly evaporated seawater. Lower porosity but much higher permeability.

name: Browse Basin, Unit 4
remarks:
Internal seismic reflections in the build-ups are highly discontinuous, producing high-variance, circular to sub-circular depressions. The subtle chaotic appearance on the slope suggest the presence
of a debrite. After the generation of this latter debrite, build-ups were onlapped by, and buried under, low-amplitude strata.

name: Browse Basin, Unit 3
remarks:
Intra-platform seaways were established between build-ups, and evidence exists for large-scale ripples in the southern part of the study
area.Fringing reefs, and build-up interiors
develop discontinuous seismic reflections with high-variance, and circular to sub-circular depressions

name: Browse Basin, Unit 2
remarks:
carbonate build-ups with topographic highs marking focal points of aggradation. In
such a setting, topographic lows within build-up interiors are indicative of marine incursions. Patch reefs within the interior lagoon to the east were also drowned. Prolonged aggradation resulted in significant margin retreat on the southeast margins. The barrier reef was then drowned and buried, likely establishing open-ocean conditions across the southeastern part of the study area. Southwest striking
faults are observed.

name: Browse Basin, Unit 1
remarks:
Topography prior to the Miocene initiation of carbonate build-ups shows flat-topped bryozoan
reefs, and a sharp break in slope to the northwest. This break in slope is regularly incised and controls the northwesterly extent of the Miocene carbonate sequence. Circular to sub-circular topographic highs represent carbonate build-ups with a patch-reef morphology.

name: Pre-Caspian Basin
remarks: Reef limestone predominately developed with limy mudstone present at the basal part. The platform margin reef (bank) is located in a transition zone between the platform and the deep- or deeper-water slope, with the water depth at and near the wave base, where good circulation of water body is available. This environment provides a strong hydrodynamic force, due to the joint control of wave and tidal, and hence allows grain-dominated bank facies bodies to deposit, with locally present organic reefs formed by substantial in-situ biogroups.

name: Muang Long, Sukhothai Zone
remarks: Cement-rich reefal sediments composed of Carniphytes multisiphonatus-microbial boundstone and sparse-allochem grainstone, the latter consisting mainly of fragments of Plexoramea gracilis, are common in this limestone. They suggest open-marine sedimentation on a shallow carbonate platform.

name: Lysakow bryozoan reef
remarks:
Bryozoan bioherms attaining up to a few meters in length and one meter in thickness. The bioherms are built up by cyclostomate and cheilostomate bryozoans but the frame-building assemblage is monospecific in places, consisting of Fasciculipora janinae sp. n. Branching colonies of the new species are so
variable that their isolated fragments might be easily misidentified as belonging to distinct species, or even genera.

name: Lop’yu Kyrta, Ilych River
remarks:
Among Biohermal limestones stromatolitic ones are predominate, coral, Fistulella-microbial,
and stromatoporoid-microbial ones are rarer. The comparison and correlation of transect series allow us to establish the landscapemorphological
zonation of Lop’yu Kyrta buildup, an outer slope and a reef-flat are distinguished.

Valganskaya Fm. is turbiditic with reworked reef clasts. No formation name given for in situ reef facies

name: New Pass, Nevada
remarks: Sponge-Bivalve-Coral reef mound. Sponges dominated the reef mound followed by bivalves, corals and echinoid fragments. The skeletal content within the overall middle ramp environment is low. Micrite comprises 79% while sparry calcite comprises 2%. Radiolarians, and ammonoids dominate this environment. Thus, we categorize this section as the Radiolarian-Ammonoid Biofacies. The sponge reef mound is largely matrix supported with skeletal content.

name: Lesno Brdo Quarry
remarks:
Presence of three facies types: fine-grained
limestone as a groundmass, blocks and globular masses of sponge-microbialite boundstone, and lens-like aggregations of polychaete (terebellid) tubes. Sponge-microbialite boundstone contains a rather small number of cosmopolitan sponge
taxa, solenoporacean red algae, microproblematica, bryozoans, and a small proportion of dwelling fauna. Instead, stromatolites represent the main constituent.

name: Eastern Tianshan, Xinjiang
remarks:
The coral fauna is composed of mainly large
dissepimented solitary corals, accompanied by a few colonial forms. In total, 47 species belonging
to 22 genera in the families Adamanophyllidae, Aulophyllidae, Axophyllidae, Amplexidae, Bothrophyllidae, Cyathopsidae, Palaeosmiliidae and Lithostrotionidae were identified. Among these genera, 16 are solitary, and 6 are colonial. In the latter group, 4 genera are massive,
and 2 are fasciculate.

name: Tabynsk, Voskresenka Mount
remarks:
Bioherm facies are represented by bryozoan
limestones (baundstones and rudstones) with
brachiopods, algae, and ammonoids. They are underlain by layered crinoid limestones (wackestones and grainstones). The rocks contain a foraminiferal assemblage

name: Dark Canyon brachiopod mound
remarks:
The small bioherm is about 8 m long, 5.5 m wide, and elongate toward the northwest. 
Built by brachiopod Sestropoma cribriferum

name: Marmorbruch Niederehe, Eifel
remarks:
Stromatoporoids, tabulate corals and some rugose corals. Mostly reworked reefal debris.
Complex encrustation pattern
Zisterzienser Marble previously quarried as building stone.

name: Staryi Oskol, Novovasil’evo area, Orenburg, Ardatovo horizon
remarks: Stromatopore–coral limestones. Clayey and bituminous limestones with tentaculites, radiolarians, spongioids, ostracodes, pelecypods, and lingules.

name: Rybkino
remarks:
Biohermal stromatopore limestones, biohermal algal
(Shuguria) limestones;

name: Quingdao Depression, CZ12-1-1
remarks: Reef-bank. Dolomites contain abundant dissolved pores and are mainly micritic dolomites. These indicate that there are dolomite reservoirs with good porosity distributed in the lower Triassic and lower Carboniferous of the South Yellow Sea.

name: Well WX5-ST1
remarks:
Dolomites with high porosity and high
permeability

name: Ganjgon, Lower Rupelian
remarks: Build-up (main body and flanks). Further down-dip, larger benthic foraminifers (large Nummulites test, Operculina and Neorotalia) packstone-grainstone along with discrete coral patches and coralline red algae

name: Jowzar
remarks:
Polygenetic conglomerate. Meter-thick bedded to massive limestones rich in coral and coralline
red algae fragments confining to the platform margin.

name: Lower Monte Baria Reef, Cala Gonone, N Oresei Gulg
remarks:
Carbonate (bioclastic) debris, microbialites and microencrusters, and reef-building organisms (mainly corals and stromatoporoids).
Microframework -rich(microbialites and microencrusters) facies, with abundant skeletal organismus in place. Corals dominate, followed by stromatoporoids, bivalves (including Rudist diceratids), gastropods (including nerineids), echinoid spines.

name: Core XK-1, Stone Island
remarks: Coral content varies between 25% and 74%.The corals are dominated by Turbinaria and Favia, with colonies mainly displaying massive morphologies. Accessory components are debris of frequent to rare benthic foraminifera, red algae, echinoids, brachiopods. Red algal and coral frame- to bindstone, red algal bindstone, floatstone, and wackestone.

name: Falcona Alta, Malaguide Complex
remarks:
Mainly bafflestones with clotted microbial
grainstone to packstone matrix. Reef builders
are ramiform thamnoporid corals and twig-like stromatoporoids both with frequent microborings.

name: Hönne Reef, Beul near Eisborn. Loc. 4
remarks: Terminal reef limestones with colonial rugose coral, biostrome blocks and with the overlying top-middle Frasnian, post-reefal nodular limestones, with shark and pelagic conodont fauna

name: Hönne Valley Reef Complex at Asbeck Quarry
remarks:
The Asbeck Quarry exposes a sequence of more
than 600 meters of reefal limestone.
There are six major facies sets: 
1. limestones with evidence of subaerial exposure (e.g., vadose cements, drying and contraction cracks), 2. laminites without macrofauna (but with
parathuramminid foraminifers and ostracods), 3.
micrites with few components and irregular
microbial fenestrae (“birdseyes” to Stromatactis”), 4. fossiliferous micrites, with various reef builders, gastropods, specialized brachiopods, parathuramminids, and ostracods, 5. sublagoonal limestone, mostly rich in dendroid stromatopores (Amphipora, Stachyodes), and 6. reef-core limestones (boundstones), with large stromatopores in growth position.


Mudstones to bioclastic wackestones with some
tabulate corals, rare colonial Rugosa, very rare
stromatoporid fragments, some crinoid debris,
ostracods, and some mollusk debris.

name: Core XK-1, Stone Island
remarks:
coral framestone and floatston with minor wackestone and packstone. The corals are dominated by Turbinaria and Favia, with
colonies mainly displaying massive morphologies. The coral content can reach 100%. Matrix containing some bioclastic debris. Accessory components are debris of frequent to rare benthic foraminifera, red algae, echinoids, rare green algae, brachiopods, bivalves.

name: Laga Beach, Ibarangelu
remarks: Marls with coral biostromes.

name: Kouquan section
remarks:
massive micritic limestone and calcareous
mudstone

name: Sampaguita-1, Reed Bank
remarks: Carbonate platform reef

name: Sampagita‐1
remarks: Carbonate platform reef

name: Huwaiza-1 well
remarks: Very coarse-grained bioclastic rudstone dominated by rudistid debris with abundant of benthonic foraminiferal grainstone in the lagoonal facies.

name: Halfaya-1 wall
remarks: Rudistid biostrome with open shelf lagoon facies. Abundant of benthonic foraminiferal packstone, that indicates to open lagoon environment.

name: Amara -1
remarks: Rudistid biostrome with open shelf lagoon facies

name: Abu Amood -1
remarks: Skeletal and non-skeletal carbonate grains, rudistid debris.

name: Dujaila -1 well
remarks: Skeletal and non-skeletal carbonate grains.

name: Wennan, Xintai area
remarks: Sponge–microbial boundstones, containing lithistid sponges (areal percentage, approximately 14%) and microbial components (areal percentage, approximately 39%). The sponges in this section are anthaspidellid demosponges. The microbial components consist mainly of frequently branched columnar stromatolites. Vacant spaces among frameworks formed by a combination of stromatolites and sponges are filled with lime mud and rare bioclasts, including trilobites, chancelloriid sclerites and sponge spicules.

name: Tipperary area, Kordephyton-Jawonya-Wagima
remarks: Microbialite columns with Kordephyton bushes (fan pattern) and sporadic Jawonya and Wagima both attached to column surfaces and immured within columns; vagrant Latouchella accordionata on right margin of central column; intercolumn cavity with geopetal infill.

name: Soudan area, Undilla Sub-basin, locality NTGS4648
remarks: Reef fabric comprises mainly explanate and in some cases conical Rankenella, encrusted by more or less distinctly laminated, generally non-skeletal stromatolites. Angulocellularia-type microbial mesoclots and Angulocellularia locally intergrades into Taninia. Stromatolites appear to encrust upper surfaces of Rankenella skeletons, as well as those of other bioclasts such as calciate brachiopods, hyoliths and molluscs.

name: Yazd locality
remarks: Small reefs formed by dendroid and ceroid corals and differents droups of sponges. Chambered sphinctozoans and noc-chambered sphinctozoans are the most abundant sponges. One chambered hexactinellid sponges was also found.

name: Dagestan, Shakhdag Massif
remarks: Bioherm buildups, represented by the dense gray and greenish grain limestones with a great amount of corals.

name: Well YB1 and Well YB2,Yuanba, Cangxi
remarks:
The main reservoir rocks are reef-bank dolomite and dolomitic limestone, which are characterized by
medium-low porosity and medium-low permeability.

name: Le Perthus
remarks:
Coral-microbialite patch reef with fragments of crinoids and dacycladacean algae but profuse
ooids.
Includes Mas de Messier locality. Chondrocoenia clavellate dominant

name: Wadi Aynouna, near Al Khuraybah
remarks:
Massive bioturbated coralline limestone with low diverse, medium isolated corals heads of Favites, Heliastraea, Tarbellastraea, Porites, Thegioastraea spp. Coralline red algae occur as free-rolling or partly attatched rhodoliths and debris of Lithothamnium and Mesophyllum spp. Red algae play a significant role in construction of
the reef facies, where they bind and connect coral colonies and other skeletal and non  skeletal constituents into a coherent mass. The bivalves, gastropods and echinoids act as essential rock forming constituents in this lithofacies. Fore-reef sediments mainly gave bioclastic wackestone, algal wackestone, bioclastic packstones, coralline framestone, coralline rudstone and grainstones. Most of these sediments are driven from the reef-core framework. Thin sections show fragments of corals, red algae, benthic foraminifera (miliolids) and ostracods. Most of these fragments were recrystallized due to diagenesis.

name: Al Bada
remarks: Massive limestone with low diverse, scattered, small dendroid and massive heads of corals of Heliastraea, Tarbellastraea spp. Microfacies analysis of this facies gave coralline framestone, bioclastic grainstone, bryozoan grainstone, bioclastic wacke/floatstones and bioclastic rudstones. The skeletal grains are dominated by reworked moderately preserved small branched, massive and phaceloid corals, bivalves, gastropods and red algae. Matrix in most back reef is made up of peloidal micrite with abundant organic matter.

name: Station 15, Ash Shaykh Humayd
remarks:
MIS5e coral reef terraces, expose reef-edge and
back-reef lagoonal deposits with various stony
corals, molluscs, echinoids, melobesians, etc.

name: Station 6, 12 South of Ra-s Suwayhil as Saghir
remarks: Large boulders overgrown by reefal carbonates with variety of well-preserved scleractinian corals and molluscs, gastropods. Large mamelon-like aragonite botryoids are found.

name: Station 20, North of Wadi Tayyib Ism
remarks: reefal carbonates with conglomeratic layers sitting on Arabian basement granitoids with abundant scleractinian heads, gastropods, epifaunal and infaunal bivalves.

name: Station 27, south of Al Maqnah
remarks: Porites-dominated reefs and intervening sandy sediments host abundant and diverse associated fauna which includes large bivalves and gastropods.

name: B reef and J reef, Madura Strait Basin
remarks: Reefal facies, composed of a coral framework, larger foraminifera, red algae, echinoderm plates, and other minor carbonate bioclasts.

name: O-1Madura Strait Basin
remarks:
porosity of the Mundu carbonate rock can reach more than 40%. Mundu is composed of bioclastic
grainstone, wackestone and packstone and has been
intensely bioturbated.

name: Blue Mountain Inlier
remarks:
Rudists as large bouquets of Biradiolites
mooretownensis yielding tens of thousands of
specimens

name: Atar Group, unit I-5
remarks: Stromatolitic bioherms.

name: Pizzo Croce Limestone
remarks: Rudist biostrome/buildups, highenergy shelf-margin rudist patches. Caprinidae-Radiolitidae floatstone grading up into amalgamated beds of angular bioclastic rudstone/grainstone. Alternations of foraminifer/ostracod mudstone/wackestone and bioclastic grainstone/fine-rudstone.

name: Wadi Mujib
remarks: Peritidal (mudstones with monotypic ostracodes or microbial lamination) and agitated shallow subtidal environments (rudist patch reefs).

name: Nallıhan
remarks:
Patch reefs and locally fringing type
reefs comprise abundant hippurits and other rudists, algae, bryozoans, coelenterate, echinoid, gastropods, ammonoids.

name: Bird Road, Miami
remarks: More biohermal in form, the reef system appeared to have distinct zonation. coral fauna was present, including Diploria sarasotana, Septastrea marylandica, Septastrea crassa, Porites furcata Lamarck, and the hydrocoral Millepora alcicornis, and over three hundred species of mollusks along with several species of echinoids and crustaceans.

name: Tangjiahe
remarks: The Tangjiahe section contains three levels of reefal buildups that were constructed by aconsortium of archaeocyaths and calcimicrobes in varying proportions. The lowest (oldest) reefal buildup is acalcimicrobial biostrome, possibly in the form of a wide mound with a low relief (unconfirmed due to outcroplimitation), which was formed byEpiphytonwith rare small archaeocyaths, and is sandwiched by flat-pebbleconglomerates. The middle reefal buildup is a high-relief calcimicrobial mound, enclosed by oolites, that was built byintergrownRenalcisandTarthinia.

name: Kano-yama limestone, Kanto Mountains
remarks: Algal-microbial mound composed of Anthracoporella, Palaeoaplysina, Tubiphytes, Archaeolithoporella, and bryozoans. The limestone is characterized by abundant micrite, implying a low-energy back-reef depositional environment.

name: Fossil Hill
remarks: Serpulid build-ups: massive deposits composed of fossil serpulid worm tubes (Annelida: Serpulidae) and bivalve shells.

name: Xikou section
remarks: Lower stromatolite bed, lying on the oolitic grainstone, 0.2 m thick. Columnar stromatolites.

name: Xikou section
remarks:
Very-thick-bedded sponge framestones and thick-to-very-thick-bedded bioclastic grainstones. Fossils are diverse and abundant and include calcareous sponges, calcareous algae, echinoderms, corals, small foraminifers, fusulinids, brachiopods. Clarkina yini zone. Shallow marine, low- to middle
energy zone. Coordinates stated in the text, decimal.

name: Mtwara Bay
remarks:
Coral bioconstruction with two principal facies:
siliciclastic sheetstone facies dominated by platy
colonies, and carbonate mix-platestone facies including a variety of growth forms (platy, tabular-massive, branching and solitary. Tabular-massive corals can reach a size of up to 50 cm across.

name: Kotouč Quarry, Štramberk
remarks:
Coral-microbial bindstone passing locally to poorly sorted pelbiointraclastic packstone. Corals and micro-encrusters (Lithocodium aggregatum and Crescentiella morronensis) form a framework
that supported the sediment during deposition. Bioclasts belong to trepostome bryozoans
(colonies and isolated zooecias), calcareous sponges, crinoids and gastropods. Ooids and
calcareous dinoflagellate cysts are rare. Cavities are filled with radiaxial-fibrous calcite cement,
chalcedony and blocky calcite.

name: Jebel Taabest
remarks: subtidal lagoon paleoenvironments with olistoliths that show a boundstone to floatstone texture, with solitary and colonial corals, sponges, gastropods, serpulid worms, crinoids, brachiopods, echinoids tests and spines, and occasional chaetetid sponges and microbialites.

name: Koudiat Ech Chehem
remarks:
Giant bioherm made of interlayered boundstones
(pillarstones and mixstones) and crinoidal grainstones and packstones. Environment in the
optimal reef window, at the boundary between shoreface and offshore. Well-lit and diverse communities.

name: Mihangaoqiaogaolu section, West Ujimqin Banner
remarks:
Reefs are superimposed upon each other in the lower part of the section, but are isolated in the upper part. They developed on and are overlain by
medium- to thick-bedded skeletal wackestone that contains phylloid algae and Shamovella, foraminifers, echinoderms, bryozoans, Rectangulina, and Epimastopora.

name: Cioclovina–Bănita area, MFT2
remarks: Platform margin environment, crest—shallow-water patch reefs. Crustose fabrics, biogenic encrustations and perforations; clotted, agglutinated and dome-shaped microbial microstructures, small cavities; the intra-reef sediment is mostly micritic; scarce geopetal structures; radiaxial- fibrous cements and late diagenetic druse/ mosaic spar occur locally

name: Gunung Subis
remarks:
Massive and branching corals, coralline red algae, benthic foraminifera, bivalves, gastropods, echinoids, and occasionally bryozoans and sponges. Eight microfacies types and four environments were defined to describe the Subis Limestone: outer talus, inner talus, reef rim, and lagoon.
Nine genera of benthic foraminifera.

name: Kuh-e Siah section, Borazjan city
remarks: Angular rudist and coral with minor amounts of echinoids and benthic foraminifera fragments. Middle shelf and ramp environments

name: Kuh-e Mond well, Fars Area
remarks:
Bioclastic pelloidal packstone consists mainly of pelloid with small benthic foraminifera, such as textulariids, alveolina, plaealveolina, conical orbitolina, echinoderms and rudist fragments. The pelloidal nature of this facies together with rudist
and echinoid bioclasts indicate shallow open marine environment with good water circulation.

name: Northern shore of the Cíjara dam
remarks:
Bioherms, shelly-microbial buildups.The reef-core facies consists of Cloudina-thromboid to stromatoid-thromboid boundstones and floatstones. Due to neomorphism, the calcified
microbial communities are heterogeneously preserved, with clotted pseudospar textures
occurring directly encrusting both microsparitic substrates and shelly walls. The
microbial framestone is dominated by clotted, peloidal, fenestral textures, and subsidiary
stromatolitic microsparite/sparry textures. Predominant skeletal components are
Cloudina carinata, C. hartmanae (probably C. xuanjiangpingensis), Sinotubulites
baimatuoensis, and rare Protolagena sp.

name: Phu Pha Sing and Phu Pha Noi hills
remarks:
Phylloid algal reef mound association is mainly composed of massive phylloid algal boundstone dominated, up 30% of bioclasts, by cup-shaped phylloid algae with locally common algal-skeletal
packstone and wackestone. Red algae,calcimicrobes, forams, rugose coral, peloids, echinoderms,
brachiopods,fusulinds, ostracods can be found.

name: Değirmençay, Mersin Province
remarks: Red  algae, coral  and  benthic  foraminifera  bearing reefal limestone.

name: Lumazhai and Zhongxinzhai locality
remarks:
Skeletal–cement–microbial reef (SCMR-1) in lower part of section
Grey thick-bedded microbial carbonate and phylloid algae boundstone. The substrate is composed of grey thick-bedded wackestone and packstone. Peloids, microbial mat debris, bioclasts constitute most of the volume of the lower part. Bioclasts, including bryozoans, small brachiopod shells, gastropods, ostracods, crinoids, and foraminifera. The substrate becomes clotted wackestone towards
the mound and the biodiversity decreases. Skeletal grains have micritic envelopes.

name: Mahmudia Quarry, Caeracul Mare Hill, sample 114
remarks: Tubiphytes-microbial buildup with bivalves, gastropods, brachiopods, ostracod fauna

name: South of Al Ain locality
remarks: Massively bedded floatstone/rudstone is interbedded with packstone to floatstone. Coral and calcisponge clasts of pebble to boulder size are abundant.

name: Finucane-1 wells
remarks: Carbonate buildups and reef facies consisting largely of skeletal grains including foraminifera, bryozoans, molluscs and corals.

name: Finucane-1 wells
remarks: Giant barrier reef system containing carbonate buildups and reef facies. The reef was extinguished and buried by shelfal sediments.

name: Picard-1
remarks: Giant barrier reef system containing carbonate buildups and reef facies. The reef was extinguished and buried by shelfal sediments.

name: Picard-1
remarks: Giant barrier reef system containing carbonate buildups and reef facies. The reef was extinguished and buried by shelfal sediments.

name: IODP-U1464
remarks: Giant barrier reef system containing carbonate buildups and reef facies. The reef was extinguished and buried by shelfal sediments.

name: IODP-U1464
remarks: Giant barrier reef system containing carbonate buildups and reef facies. Reef was extinguished and buried by shelfal sediments.

name: Minilya-1
remarks: Giant barrier reef system containing carbonate buildups and reef facies. The reef was extinguished and buried by shelfal sediments.

name: Minilya-1
remarks: Giant barrier reef system containing carbonate buildups and reef facies. The reef was extinguished and buried by shelfal sediments.

name: East Mermaid-1
remarks: Giant barrier reef system containing carbonate buildups and reef facies.

name: East Mermaid-1
remarks: Giant barrier reef system containing carbonate buildups and reef facies.

name: Barcoo-1
remarks: Giant barrier reef system containing carbonate buildups and reef facies.

name: Reşiţa–Moldova Nouă zone
remarks: Reef built by platy corals. The coral units are underlain by bioclastic limestones interlayered with thin rudist-chaetetid biostromes, separated by a 15–30 m thick interval of bioclastic limestones and overlain by upper Aptian conglomerates. Mostly dense, rarely sparse, platestones are composed of a low diversity coral assemblage mainly represented by the suborder Microsolenina. Small, branching corals are very rare. The matrix mainly consists of fine bioclastic-peloidal packstones and wackestones. Dominance of microsolenine corals, their flattened morphology, the presence of epibionts on coral undersurfaces and occurrence of red algae Sporolithon rude and Polyastra alba.

name: Brecknock 1
remarks: Giant barrier reef system containing carbonate buildups and reef facies.

name: Brecknock 1
remarks: Giant barrier reef system containing carbonate buildups and reef facies.

name: MioR-3 - Rowley Shoals
remarks: Buried late Miocene isolated pinnacles and atolls

name: MioR-3 - Rowley Shoals, near Cunningham island
remarks: Buried late Miocene isolated pinnacles and atolls

name: MioR-3 - Rowley Shoals, East of Mermaid Reef
remarks: Buried late Miocene isolated pinnacles and atolls

name: MioR-3 - East of Rowley Shoals
remarks: Buried late Miocene isolated pinnacles and atolls

name: MioR-3 - East of Rowley Shoals
remarks: Buried late Miocene isolated pinnacles and atolls

name: Saal Quarry
remarks: Mostly reefal debris

name: GL1, Tazhong (Katake) Uplift, central Tarim
remarks: Hydrocarbon reservoir

name: Z11, Tazhong (Katake) Uplift
remarks: Ostracod-oyster-algae floatstone interbedded with bioclastic limestone

name: Lumazhai section, Houchang area
remarks:
Patch reef consisting of a simple coral framework and a low biodiversity community. The substrate is composed of bioclastic grainstone and rudstone 
Fomichevella, phacelloid and with an erect growth habit, form the reef framework. Asexual reproductive budding of Fomichevella is visible. Foraminifers and crinoids are common fossils. The spaces in
the coral framework are filled with bioclastic wackestonepackstone.
Bioclastic grainstone covers the coral patch reef, in which some coral debris are seen.

name: Pippu limestone, NE of the Asahikawa city
remarks:
Tubiphytes-calcimicrobe rudstone, dominated by Tubiphytes spp. and associated with large echinoderm ossicles. Poorly preserved calcimicrobes, reworked mud grains, micritized clasts and coated or aggregate grains are abundant. Other bioclasts are
Soleporacean, red algae, microproblematica and the sponge Uvanella sp. Serpulids and bryozoan debris are rare. Microbial crusts were observed on a recrystallized framebuilder.

name: Jiwozhai reef
remarks:
Patch reef with high biodiversity: stromatoporoids, rugose corals, tabulate corals, chaetetids,
brachiopods, bryozoans, calcified cyanobacteria and tubeworms.
83 species were mentioned but only 35 are considered reef building

name: WC55 reef, Belaya River gorge
remarks:
It comprises mudstones interbedded with thin–medium-bedded bioclastic limestones, with abundant coral and sponge fragments, and plentiful bivalves. These grade upwards into massive reef facies that consist of coral-sponge rudstones in the lower part and platy coral reef limestones in the upper part. The reefs comprise thick biostromes. The bedded
carbonates consist of lagoonal bioclastic and micritic limestones that grade upward into gastropod and oncoidal limestones.

name: WC6a-b, Akhtsu Zone
remarks: Oxfordian–Tithonian. The principal reef organisms are corals and calcisponges. In the middle part of the succession, the facies consist of lithoclastic and bioclastic grainstones in the southern flank of the anticline and bioclastic packstones with sponges and coral fragments in the northern flank. The upper part of the succession on the southern flank of the anticline consists of intertidal-supratidal bioclastic limestones, abundant fenestral grainstone-packstones and algal packstones.

name: WC114 - WC115, Bolyshaya Laba River
remarks: The mound consists mainly of siliceous sponge-microbialite and microbialite boundstones. It is made up of a cluster of much smaller lenticular bodies or bioherms. The top of the reef succession is capped by thinly-bedded microbialite floatstones and bioclastic limestones.

name: Shitouzhai section, Ziyun region
remarks:
Reef formed largely of calcisponge floatstones and/or framestones. The spaces between the rigid framework formed by the sponges are filled with wackestones and packstones that contain numerous benthic foraminifers (Palaeofusulina, Colaniella, Glomospira), green algae (Dasycladales and Mizzia), and crinoids and bivalve fragments.

Formation original was Changhsing. 
Comments from Tian & Wang, 2021:

Reef builders: Frame-building and baffling
organisms: hypercalcified sphinctozoan and inozoan sponges, sclerosponges, bryozoans, and hydrozoans
Binding organisms: Archaeolithoporella, Tubiphytes, and cyanobacteria.

Reef dwellers: Echinoderms, ostracodes, bivalves, brachiopods,gastropods, benthic foraminifera, calcareous algae, and single rugose corals.

Rock type and reef-related depositional characteristic: Fore-reef slope: packstone with
floatstone and reef breccias
Reef core: sponge framestone and bafflestone, Archaeolithoporella and cyanobacteria bindstone, and sponge framestone with the encrusting Archaeolithoporella.
Reef flat (reef crest): algal-foraminiferal packstone with reef breccia.
Reef base: bioclastic packstone to grainstone.

Reef type: Metazoan reef at the shallow carbonate platform margin.

Coordinates stated in text.

name: Lagonaki Highland and vicinity
remarks: Moderately  thick  reefal carbonates.

name: vicinity of the city of Sochi and northern  Abkhazia
remarks: Massive carbonate deposition with coral reefs

name: Basins of the rivers Belaja and Laba
remarks: Massive carbonate accumulation

name: Barranco de Losilla
remarks: Buildup of thin-shelled bivalves

name: Longgang area
remarks:
Grey dolomitized reefs or dolomitized boundstone
facies, with an average porosity of 4.0%.

name: Shaghap piggyback basin
remarks:
Outcrop with conglomerates and breccias, reefal blocks of branching coralline limestones, siltstones, claystones and calci-mudstones. With small planktonic foraminifers, discocyclinids as well as numerous red algal, coralline algal fragments. Additionally, some echinoids,
bryozoans, bivalve fragments and gastropods are present. Few fragments of Bryozoans are observed in microbialites. Microbial peloids and encrusting filaments form incipient branching structures

name: Roztoka (S1)
remarks: light-beige, porous, sponge–microbial limestones. There are two main types of microfacies: Sponge–microbial framestones–floatstones and fine-grained bioclastic wackestones–packstones. Depositional environment: low- to moderate-energy mid ramp

name: Lanckorona
remarks: Light-beige, porous, sponge–microbial limestones. There are two main types of microfacies: Sponge–microbial framestones–floatstones and fine-grained bioclastic wackestones–packstones. Depositional environment: low- to moderate-energy mid ramp

name: Sulow
remarks: Light-beige, porous, sponge–microbial limestones. There are two main types of microfacies: Sponge–microbial framestones–floatstones and fine-grained bioclastic wackestones–packstones. Depositional environment: low- to moderate-energy mid ramp

name: Esashi limestone
remarks: Large echinoderm ossicles, debris of calcimicrobes, debris of bivalves, bryozoans and calcimicrobes indet. Remobilized framebuilders (i.e., recristallized corals and spongiomorphids).

name: Quarry 23, Dent Peninsula, Sabah
remarks: Loosely cemented rubbly reef limestone, with well-preserved and rich fauna of molluscs, echinoids, foraminifera, gastropods and corals in apparent growth positions.

name: section J reefs, Ibex area, Millard County, Utah
remarks: Sponge-Rich Patch Reefs. Two conspicuous 1.5 m and 3 m thick reef intervals, with reefs rich in lithistid sponges.

name: Mt. Tului
remarks: Type 1 build-ups developed in the proximal middle ramp and consist of 45 m thick, 100 m wide, coral-stromatoporoid boundstone associated with coral–stromatoporoid rudstone–grainstone. Type 2 build-ups, colonizing deeper environments in the middle ramp, are lens-shaped coral–calcareous sponge–diceratid boundstone including stromatoporoids and chaetetid sponges, 1–2 m thick and 3–4 m wide, associated with bioclastic packstone–grainstone. Type 3 lens-shaped calcareous and siliceous sponge–coral–microbialite boundstone build-ups (1 m thick and a few metres wide) formed in lower energy, distal middle-to-outer ramp settings.

name: Gold Point Reef, Nevada
remarks: Reef built by massive branching archaeocyaths and dense renalcid thickets.

name: Wudang, western Yangtze Platform
remarks: The stromatolites are 40 cm thick and flat column shaped, but strongly dolomitized.

name: Letca and Băbeni–Cuciulat
remarks:
The reefs occur within a shallow‐water succession composed mostly of bedded limestones, dominated by bioclastic (coralline) packstones. Branching ramose colonies, branching low‐integrated phaceloid, and sheet‐like (foliaceous) corals dominate.
Rupelian

name: Qincaiyuan, Gendan, Tanluzhai, Ziyun, Guizhou
remarks:
Reef builders:
Frame-building and baffling organisms: hypercalcified sphinctozoan and inozoan sponges, sclerosponges, bryozoans, and hydrozoans
Binding organisms: Archaeolithoporella, Tubiphytes, and cyanobacteria.

reef dwellers:
Echinoderms, ostracodes, bivalves, brachiopods, gastropods, benthic foraminifera, calcareous algae, and single rugose corals.

Rock type and reef-related depositional characteristic:
Reef core: sponge framestone and bafflestone, Archaeolithoporella and cyanobacteria bindstone, and sponge framestone with the encrusting Archaeolithoporella.
Reef flat: algal-foraminiferal packstone with reef breccia.
Reef crest: ancient weathering crust.
Reef base: bioclastic packstone.
Back-reef: bioclastic packstone with calcareous algae,gastropods, and foraminifers.

Reef type: Metazoan reef at the shallow carbonate platform margin.

Coordinates stated in text.

name: Bure
remarks: Coral reef complex. Coordinates estimated from map.

name: Sirogojno Melange in the Zlatibor Mountain
remarks:
Dachstein Limestone forereef block is part of the upper carbonate-clastic Sirogojno Melange. The succession starts with coarse-grained rudstones followed
by meter-sized reefal blocks intercalated in partly layered resedimented grainstones
and packstones with abundant reef-building organisms like calcareous
sponges, corals and encrusting organisms. Inside this part of the succession
open-marine influenced layers are rare. The succession continues with a partly
turbiditic sequence and chaotic rudstones, densely packed with reef-derived
material like broken reef-building organisms and shallow-water material like
gastropods, bivalves and foraminifers. Grainstones with clear open-marine influence
(e.g., thin-shelled bivalves, crinoids, conodonts) appear in between those
rudstones, in cases lumachelle layers consisting of halobiids were deposited. To
the end of the succession some layers show turbiditic bedding with mixed shallow-
water and deep-marine grains and organisms, i.e. filaments and crinoids.
Coordinates stated in text.

name: Araetgol section, Yeongwol
remarks:
The thrombolitic mounds are domes up to 100 cm high and 40–60 cm wide embedded within within lime mud and shale (ribbon rock). Analysis of slabs revealed that the mounds consist of cm-scale thrombolitic “clots” and homogeneous micrite with several intraclasts and bioclasts filling the interclot spaces.
Two types of clots are recognised: keratolite–microbialite and lithistid sponge–microstromatolite clots. Keratose and lithistid sponges rarely occur together in the Mungok reefs.

name: Cortes section
remarks:
Well-developed reef system, with significant diversity of reefal faunas (crinoids, corals and stromatoporoids). The calciturbidites include frequent fragments of crinoids and common coarse-
grained calciturbidites. Base of the slope.

Coordinates estimated from map.

name: Jebel Serdj-Bargou
remarks:
high carbonate productivity with the development of biostromal buildups. The carbonates of this unit show net northward facies and thickness changes. The biota is dominated by corals, orbitolinids,
miliolids, gastropods and oysters, reflecting the oligophotic conditions on a homoclinal carbonate ramp.

name: Cruz

Biohermes of different thickness (decimetric to metric) and less lateral continuity are developped, highly colonized by corals, that are associated to oncolitic, bioclastic and oolitic of high energy
facies, in marginal areas, near the litoral developpment.

name: Jaulin
remarks:
Within the inner shelf, in agitated subtidal conditions close to the coastal oolitic
development, coral bioherms (boundstone corals) grow
(coral boundstone) associated with bio-clastic, oolitic and oncolitic high energy facies.

name: Qujing
remarks: No comment

name: Muli reef,  Wenshan-southeast Yunnan
remarks: Sb-ore deposits

name: Dongwan section
remarks: Microbialite (2.5 m thick) is composed mainly of dendrolite. The basal layer of the microbialite is flat and layered, and its upper part is strongly domed. Shell beds are intercalated between domes. At the top, the dome-shaped microbialite flattens horizontally, and is overlain by muddy limestone. Conodont H. parvus was found in the horizon 0.45 m above the bottom of the microbialite.

name: Mesa de Roldán + La Molata de las Negras
remarks: The reef unit onlaps the erosion surface and consists of small Porites patches that grew dispersed in oolitic shoals together with microbial carbonates. These low-diversity reefs are the last zooxanthellate coral reefs in the Mediterranean basin and constitute the endpoint of decreasing coral diversity in the region during the Miocene due to disconnection from the Indian Ocean and global cooling.

name: Djebel Ouarkziz
remarks: Biostrome in shallow-water platform. A diverse set of microfacies have been observed in thin sections. The most abundant one is rudstone; bindstone and packstone are also common. More rarely, grainstone occur, mainly in the upper part of the bed. The identified components are the same as those occurring as macrofauna, plus foraminifers, calcareous algae, ostracods and scarce fragments of molluscs. Frequently, there is recorded the intergrowth of gigantoproductid brachiopods, rugose corals and chaetetid sponges.

name: Xiushui section, SW of Dongling village near Sidu
remarks:
Microbialite consists of a lower thrombolite (1.5 m thick) and an upper dendrolite (0.5 m thick). Hindeodus parvus conodont is present. the putative keratose sponge consortia were identified
from a thin-bedded, spar-cemented oolitic limestone below the basal microbialite unit. It overlies unconformably above the uppermost Changhsingian bioclastic limestone. Above this oolitic limestone layer, the thrombolite is characterized by a clotted texture of reddish sparitic patches embedded in a grey micritic matrix, whereas the overlying dendrolite texture consists of brownish sparitic patches embedded within a yellow micritic matrix (weathering colour). Several shell layers containing microgastropod and bivalve fragments, ostracod tests, and intraclasts occur above the microbialite unit (Fig. 2). Above these shell layers is the succession dominated by micrites interbedded with peloidal wackestones. In the oolitic limestone layer, single ooids are 0.2–0.6 mm in diameter and round to oval in outline, occupying 55–65% of entire petrologic texture, and they are unevenly distributed. These ooids are strongly micritized so that concentric lines or radial structures become vague. Some grains retain outline of bioclast remains, mostly gastropods. The pores between the ooids are normally cemented by sparites and micritic clumps (micrite aggregates) are interspersed occasionally, indicating an intermittent high-energy environment. Light-coloured sparitic structures are rather common and evenly scattered and almost fill the dark-coloured micritic clumps. Some elongated individuals show vermiform shapes, while others are filamentous and branch occasionally. These dot-shaped and filamentous structures form maze-like networks. Single filaments vary in length, ranging from 100 to 500 μm, while their thicknesses are relatively consistent, except for tapering ends. Individual filaments are 10–70 μm (averagely 33 μm) in diameter, with filaments of 20–30 μm in diameter being most frequently occurring (nearly 20%). About 60% filaments are 20–40 μm in diameter. Filament is slightly inflated at the junction when branching, and these filamentous sparitic structures tend to be distributed parallel to the edge of the micritic clumps.

name: Xiushui section, SW of Dongling village near Sidu
remarks:
Massive reefal carbonates with framestone of
reef-core facies built by calcareous sponges. The matrix of the framestone is micritic, indicating that the wave energy on the reef was not strong.

name: Santa Cesarea Terme
remarks:
Coral fauna is moderately diversified (only 14 genera) associated with coralline algae and larger foraminifers (mainly dyscocyclinids). Tue sequence is represented by three main fades (from the bottom upwards): 
1 - Grainstone-packstone facies (ca. 15 m thick) rich in discocyclinids, nummulitids, scleractinian corals, and bryozoans. Large subglobose coral colonies (Actinacis, Antiguastrea, Astrocoenia, Favites and Agathiphyllia) and sublaminar and globose colonies of bryozoans are typically in life position. The displaced colonies are rare and typically bear no evidence of transport (bush-like colonies of e.g.,Actinacis seem to be only fallen down). Generally colonies preserved in situ are immersed in a bioclastic packstone that, with a sharp contact, passes to a grainstone wich disoriented discocyclinids. At the top of this fades present are also debris ßows with branching corals like Acropora, Stylophora and other large bioclasts. Abundant coralline algae and specimens of pectinids and other molluscs are also associated with this facies.
2 - Bioclastic limestone (rudstones and/or floatsrones) facies (ca. 4S m thick) rich in scleractinians and coraline algae. 
3 - Wackestone-mudstone facies (ca. 12 m chick) with planktonic foraminifers, in which are debris-flows composed mainly of larger foraminifers and broken coral colonies.

name: Line M1507-07
remarks: Biogenetic reefs. The carbonates of biogenic reefs in the Andaman Sea are widely distributed, among which the carbonate platforms in the eastern terraces are mostly developed in fault blocks and volcanoes. The eastern terrace carbonate platform is mostly developed on the fault block and volcanic uplift, and the fault activity on the edge of the platform.

name: Line M1507-20
remarks: Biogenic reef carbonates

name: Line M1507-03
remarks: Biogenic reef carbonates

name: Wadi Araba
remarks: Mounds formed by filamentous microbes and phylloid algae. Phylloid algae are loosely accumulated and supported by micritic encrustations that were formed by filamentous microbes. The filamentous microbes growing perpendicularly to the phylloid algal surfaces produced concentrated areas of peloids-A. The spaces between the phylloid algal-microbial frameworks were filled with concentrated areas of peloids-B (peloid-B aggregations) oriented perpendicular to the phylloid algae surfaces.

name: Ruby Creek- Bornite deposit, Brooks Range
remarks:
Stratigraphy uncertain.
Age given as Wenlock-Lower Devonian

name: Test 4
remarks: Test 4

name: Arroyo Uitpa, Arroyo Ekieps at the foothills of the Serranía de Jarara in the Cocinetas Basin
remarks: The Arroyo Uitpa paleoenvironment is characterized by patch reefs developed in a shallow lagoon close to the shore-line, while Arroyo Ekieps was a barrier reef system, which offered a wide variety of microhabitats enhanced by the structural complexity of the reef framework. This suggests an increase of bryozoan diversity with higher reef complexity.

name: Chenluzhen
remarks: Age is roughly identified. Maybe Sandbian?

name: Beiquanzi
remarks: Occurs as patches within Epiphyton-dominant microbial reefs that are >10 m large

name: Zargar area, Section A
remarks: The sedimentary succession consists of two informal units: the conglomerate unit and calcareous unit (Lower and Upper Units).The conglomerate unit is composed with subangular to rounded pebbles of foraminiferal limestone and red chert. A large number of mollusk fragments, mainly gastropods and bivalves were identified. The calcareous unit is composed of thick limestones (wackestone) bearing foraminifera occurring in the lower one-third part of the unit which passes upward into thick gray limestone containing foraminiferal fauna alveolinids and orbitolitids and continues with very thick coral limestones in the middle part of this unit. The upper one-third of the calcareous unit is composed of well-bedded bioclastic gray to yellow wackestone and biomicrosparite which is characterized by the presence of coralline red algae, Nummulites globulus Leymerie and rare miliolids. It continues with gray micritic limestone (packstone to grainstone) defined by the presence of disc-shaped orthophragminids.

name: Kaboudeh area, section B
remarks:
Coral dominated macrofacies consting of two units - conglomerate and calcareous units. The conglomerate unit contains with various rock fragments such as cherts, basalt and fossiliferous limestone bearing small Nummulites. It is followed by medium grain sandstone including chert fragments and terrigenous detritus (quartz, feldspar and mica). The lower part of calcareous unit contains the small benthic miliolid foraminifera in a micritic matrix. The middle part consists of a succession of thick bedded and massive reefal limestones (boundstone) containing an autochthonous facies. Other components include encrusting
coralline red algae and common small Nummulites, frequent rotaliids and miliolids. This part is formed by thick bedswith wavy bedding plans and is characterized by red coralline algal bindstone. It passes upward into upper part of calcareous unit composed of bedded limestone bearing larger foraminifera.

name: Hole 966F
remarks: Coral reef facies near its base and lagoonal facies toward its top. The succession was deposited in an oligotrophic environment and exhibits a general shallowing-upward trend

name: Zhongxinzhai section
remarks:
The Zhongxinzhai section (25° 30′ 33.5″ N, 106° 12′
08.0″ E), s 78 m thick with a skeletal–cement–microbial reef (SCMR-3, bed 4) in the upper part.
microbial–phylloid algal reef at the base
Cement-rich microbial carbonates and colonial
rugose corals (Ivanovia) are the main reef builders in the lower middle part
The upper part of the reef is mainly constructed by small scale cement-rich microbial boundstone, including phylloid algae, bryozoans, calcisponges, and tube-shape algae

name: Sunmayu, Stage 4,     Shandong, China
remarks:
These reefs are inferred to have formed in a high-energy shoal setting
The calcimicrobes Kordephyton and Epiphyton and tubiform microbes are dominant at the Sunmayu section. The calcimicrobe Amgaina is locally abundant

name: Jinhe, Stage 4, Shandong, China
remarks:
The calcimicrobes Epiphyton and Kordephyton and tubiform microbes are the main components. Tubiform microbes occur sporadically or as tangled
aggregations.
Calcimicrobes occupy a maximum of 30%–78% of thin sections.
This reefs slightly deeper than 4405

name: Yanbanzhai coral reef, Guizhou
remarks:
Fomichevella framestone.
late Kasimovian base on fusulinids
The coral (Fomichevella) framestone is considered to have developed in a platform-margin slope environment.

name: Maustrenk, Lower Austria
remarks:
Sarmatian Bryozoan–serpulid–algal–thrombolite bioherms of up to 50 cm size.
The buildups are globular, lense-like or columnar in shape and reach more than 50 cm in height and width. Along the outcrop of approx. 20 m 8–9 individual buildups can be observed

name: Ricklow Quarry, Monyash, Derbyshire
remarks: The Ricklow mud mound complex originated during a period of creation of accommodation in an intraplatform middle-ramp dysphotic environment with dispersed food resources. The mud mound complex growth was interrupted by a subaerial exposure due to a relative sea-level fall.

name: Dunmore boreholes
remarks: Waulsortian limestones occupy a little more than half the thickness of the sequence in which they lie in the two Dunmore cores. There is no sure way of determining whether individual banks extend from one core to the other, but if they do then they number about 10; if not then the number could rise to about 15. Banks of both flat-lying and clinoform depositional structure are present. Their individual thickness ranges from <1m to about 10m; units up to c.20m occur but as they are of flat-lying structure they may include more than one bank. The banks probably resembled in type and dimensions those seen in natural and quarry exposures in the Loughrea area about 60km away.

name: Vel-ky Lipnik
remarks:
The age of this reef complex is contracted
into the interval 57-58 Ma, i. e. lower part of the
Thanetian.
Corals are the main constructors of reef framework. Their surfaces are bearing also encrustings of coralline algae and sessile foraminifers, but their volume portion on the construction of rigid reef buildups is small.

Peculiarity of this locality consists from the fact that deposits of reef complex are probable in situ on the place of their origin (under the deposits of Early Eocene) and they were not transported into younger deposits as is a
rule in other Paleocene reef deposits of Slovakia.

name: Usabide complex, Pyrenees
remarks:
Growth phase 4. Indicate as early Thanetian, but should be Selandian.
Bioconstructions within the Usabide and Legunbe
complexes (growth phases 4 and 5) appear as lowrelief, tabular-shaped bodies of variable dimensions.
The former (Usd-1 and Usd-2 in Fig. 2B) are of
relatively small size, being between 5 and 7 m thick and 70 and 110 m laterally

name: Shouxinghu
remarks: coral-stromatoporoid patch reefs

name: Test1
remarks:
Test test test
Nochmal 4,59

name: Seer Southern Reef
remarks:
Stage 4

Interesting example of a large archaeocyathan reef lacking typical kalyptrate structures.

Another specific feature of the Seer Reef is its principal composition of solitary archaeocyaths and synsedimentory fibrous calcite cement, enveloping their cups, with subdued calcimicrobal
patches. Mud fillings are restricted to the reef top and some areas of lava breccia development. Such composition indicates higher-energy conditions.

name: Queensland Plateau, Site 811A
remarks:
The Middle Miocene rimmed carbonate platform was dominated by a tropical photozoan skeletal assemblage, including green algae, corals, and large benthic foraminifera. Bryozoans occur as a minor component.
Drowning due to excess heat.

name: Serdrar reef, Amellago
remarks: A pinnacle coral reef (220 m high), located in an open marine environment on a paleo-rim of a tilted block, drowned during the lattermost Sinemurian (Oxynotumto Raricostatum Chronozones) and progressively capped by lower offshore deposits

name: Castle olistoliths, Jebel Taabest
remarks: Coral bioherms

name: Dades Valley 1
remarks: Coral reefs with rare lithiotid bivalves.

name: Koudiat Ech Chehem
remarks: Reef mounds. Giant complex bioherm composed of interlayered boundstones (pillarstones and mixstones) and crinoidal grainstones and packstones. Optimal reef window at the boundary between shoreface and offshore. It is a ca. 100 meter high buildup.

name: Coral biostrome
remarks: The biostrome contains a 10 m-thick coral biostrome in its middle unit formed by Siphonodendron, Diphyphyllum and Lithostrotion.Few brachiopods and solitary corals are found as dwellers within the biostrome. The coral biostrome records a quieter setting at the interface of middle and outer ramp settings, as seen in the co-existence of in situ coral growth, input of reworked material, deposition of carbonate mud, and sparitic textures.

name: Hippuritid reef, l-Espa, Pyrenees
remarks:
This late Campanian reef is exposed along some 20 × 6 m outcrop. Builders are mainly Hippurites radiosus, although other rudists, such as Hippuritella lapeirousei, Hippuritella sp. and Mitrocaprina sp. are also present together with corals. The orientation of 325 specimens of mainly H. radiosus was plotted in stereographic and cartesian projections. Orientations and microfacies permit to differentiate 5 vertically stacked intervals (settings) along the outcrop.

Vertical succession of environments depicts a complete rudist reef progradation

name: Yadana Gas Field
remarks:
Upper Burman Limestone Formation, early Miocene in age, that is made up of one single carbonate platform, the top of which corresponds to the gas reservoir of the Yadana Field.
Moderate dolomitization has affected the top and flanks of the platform during the depositional hiatus.
Data from seismics and four wells.
The high (28%) average porosity of the reservoir is dominantly related to strong development of microporosity, moldic and vuggy porosity.
Skeletal grains are dominated by non-geniculate coralline algae and large benthic foraminifers (Fig. 3A, B, C). Corals may be common in a few intervals (Fig. 3D). Non-geniculate coralline red algae are dominated by encrusting to branching forms, commonly forming nodules (rhodoliths) (Fig. 3A). The dominant genera are Lithothamnion, Mesophyllum and Sporolithon. Larger benthic foraminiferal association is characterized by Lepidocyclinids, Spiroclypeus, Cycloclypeus commonly displaying flat-shaped morphologies (Fig. 3C). Scleractinian assemblage includes robust branching or massive forms. Subordinate components include echninoderms, bryozoans, green algae and rare planktic foraminifera.

name: Gelati, Tertiary Piedmont Basin
remarks:
Brown mesophotic coral reefs in prodelta setting.
late middle Chattian according to Sr-isotope stratigraphy.
Coral-bearing beds are in general alternated with clay-rich horizons and along the measured sections they display a variable overall thickness, from about 4.5 m (Cascine section) up to 10.5 m (Valletta section). Four different coral facies have been identified: branching Stylophora floatstone (BSF), Acropora-Stylophora floatstone/rudstone (ASFR), Goniopora/Caulastraea pillarstone (GCP), mixed-coral domestone (MCD); their descriptions and interpretation are reported below and summarized in Table 1.

name: Nors Stenbrott 1, Gotland
remarks:
Lower Sheinwoodian bryostromatolite reef in midst of positive isotope excursion.
Bryozoan-stromatolite reef. Some tabulate corals and stromatoproids present.
Coordinates and more details provided by Claussen et al. (2022, Sedimentology):
Bryzoans 28-43%, porostromate (0-14%) and spongiostromate microbes (14-46%).
Macroboring and microboring present. Bivalve borings

name: Hallsarve, Gotland
remarks:
Bryostromatolite - bryozoans and spongiostromate microbes dominant. Some tabulate corals.
Surrounded by coarse-grained, poorly sorted reef debris.
High amount of phosphatic components indicated high nutrient input.

name: Maʼahm patch reef
remarks:
Perhaps already starting in Rupelian, but main coral-reef development in the Chattian (dated by Racey 1995). 
Ma'ahm beds 112 m thick. Patch reefs at top.

name: Minami-dai, Akiyoshi Limestone Group
remarks: Stromatoporoids (laminated skeletons made up of cystose or flat laminae and pillar-like vertical structures) are abundantreef-builders together with Chaetetes.

name: D4, Raghama
remarks:
Southern end of reefal sections (4 sections in total)
The fore reef facies in the study area disconformably overlay the clastic sediments of the Raghama Formation and are represented by 6 m thick sandy coralline boundstone and microbial laminites, with rhodolith of red algae, and domal and heads of scleractinian corals of Favites,
Tarbellastraea, Porites, Thegioastraea spp., as well as echinoids, algae, bivalves, and miliolids.

name: D1, Raghama
remarks:
Northern end of reefal sections (4 sections in total)
The fore reef facies in the study area disconformably overlay the clastic sediments of the Raghama Formation and are represented by 6 m thick sandy coralline boundstone and microbial laminites, with rhodolith of red algae, and domal and heads of scleractinian corals of Favites,
Tarbellastraea, Porites, Thegioastraea spp., as well as echinoids, algae, bivalves, and miliolids.

name: St. Paul, Gulf of Suez
remarks:
The Gharamul Formation
consists of a 29-m-thick succession of limestone with an occasional sandstone bed.
The limestone comprises low-diversity
biotas of bivalves, gastropods, corals, red algae, algal stromatolites, echinoids and benthic foraminifera. Corals occur both as in situ patch reefs and as reworked debris (Figure 5d,e).
Stromatolites are 2-to 5-mm-thick
laminations of gently undulating type (Figure 5f). Red algae occur as encrustations on patch reefs or as algal debris in the lime mud matrix (Lithothamnium sp., Mesophyllum sp. and
Lithophyllum sp.).

name: Sugaitebulak, Tarim
remarks:
Archaeocyath-Epiphyton reef-rimmed platform.
Platform marginal buildup facies are mainly composed of massive Archaeocyath-Epiphyton boundstone (AERPF4) and massive dendrolite (AERPF5).
Massive up-convex geometry (up to 70 m thick). Mesofabric characterized by erecting light-coloured aggregates/speckles intergrown with in-situ cup-shaped, branching and massive archaeocyaths or overturned fragments particularly in seaward portion. Bush-like calcified Epiphyton colonies dominate the bioconstructors with subordinate Renalcis elements and build up the skeletal/rigid framework. Inter-constructor cavities lined with submarine cements common. Constituting the core portions of phase S2 buildup complexes.

name: Wirrealpa microbialites
remarks:
Upper Stage 4 (Redlichia cf. versabunda Zone).
The buildup is composed of a series of parallel erected, cylindrical columns that are 1.5–4 m high and 20–50 cm in diameters.
Abundant ooids and calcareous metazoan skeletons, associated with micritic sediments, fill the inter-framework spaces of the microbialite, forming a packstone fabric. The calcareous metazoan skeletons, including chancelloriid sclerites, trilobite fragments, and rare mollusk shells, are scattered in the matrix.

thrombolite-stromatolite complex was formed within an ecosystem lacking archaeocyaths but dominated by microbes (reef builders) and chancelloriids (reef dwellers).
